IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women living in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) suffer extremely high mortality if they are diagnosed with breast cancer, in part because women in these regions are more likely to be diagnosed with late-stage cancer. Programs using clinical breast examination (CBE) to screen for breast cancer have been shown to decrease late-stage diagnoses and improve cancer mortality but are difficult to implement in the resource-constrained healthcare systems of LMICs. This research aims to work with primary care providers and patients to develop strategies for implementing CBE screening programs in South Africa, which is a necessary first step to reducing mortality for South African women diagnosed with breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Fundamental and translational studies have found that dysregulated immune responses are causally associated with intestinal infectious and inflammatory disorders. However, how the immune responses are regulated within the gut to promote intestinal health and prevent infection or inflammation remains elusive. A mechanistic understanding of the immune regulation in the gut is necessary for the development of novel preventative, therapeutic and curative strategies treating intestinal disorders and diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative: A deeper understanding of mechanisms underlying periodontitis, a condition that affects 42% of the US adult population, will enhance management of a significant public health problem. This proposal is structured to test the hypothesis that periodontitis is the result of loss of host/microbiome homeostasis induced by excess inflammation that has direct actions on the composition and function of periodontal bacteria. By investigating host-microbiome interactions, we will identify specific targets and potential molecules for treating periodontal disease and breaking the inflammatory disease cycle. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The presence of high potency synthetic opioids (HPSO) in illicit opioid and other drug supplies presents a grave public health crisis and appears to be compromising the use of available treatments for those with opioid use disorder (OUD). Despite the ubiquity and persistence of HPSO, systematic evaluations of treatment in the HPSO era remain sparse and HPSO physiological dependence and withdrawal remain poorly characterized. Based on this gap in the literature, the primary goals of this mentored research development proposal are to compare buprenorphine formulations among those with OUD who use HPSO and to better characterize factors influencing successful initiation of and retention in treatment with an emphasis on quantitative HPSO levels and biomarkers (body weight, body fat percentage, and plasma buprenorphine/norbuprenorphine levels).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preterm infants are at risk for impaired language development due to physiologic insults, white matter injury, and the atypical auditory environment of the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit. The purpose of the proposed work is to investigate the influence of the auditory environment on attention to and auditory recognition memory for maternal voice as well as auditory cortex development in premature infants and fetuses subsequently born at term while accounting for variables known to impact language development. The ultimate goal of this work is to apply these findings to the design and implementation of interventions in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit, which promote experience-dependent plasticity and improve the long-term outcomes of premature infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PI: Neena Singh PROJECT NARRATIVE The Research Immersion in Brain, Spinal cord (RIBS), and peripheral nerve disorders Program is designed to educate and immerse high school students from under-represented minority (URM) schools in a 8-week hands-on research experience in active laboratories on CWRU campus. The goal is to increase awareness of common neurological disorders, and build the confidence of young students to pursue careers in Neurological Research and Health care. Long-term student-mentor relationships will be an added benefit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hip osteoarthritis (OA) is a painful joint disease and in the absence of disease-modifying drugs, OA is a tremendous burden on our healthcare system. The goal of this proposal is to delineate the functional role of the WNT Family Member 16 protein (WNT16) in hip OA using several novel and integrative single-cell multi-omics approaches. A detailed understanding of the disease mechanisms will provide significant insights into the development of early therapeutic interventions for hip OA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Narrative The role of SGLTs, one of the two types of transporters (molecular gates), to bring glucose (sugar) inside cancer cells is only now starting to be recognized. SGLTs can uniquely concentrate glucose inside cells and may also be used to concentrate therapeutic drugs in cancer cells to kill them without requiring high concentrations throughout the body which make patients sick. We will explore this potential using our new compound that can be labeled for fluorescent imaging, PET imaging, and radionuclide therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Women are more likely to develop Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) and suffer from cognitive decline in later life. Using high-quality longitudinal data collected in Ireland, the UK, and the USA, the proposed set of studies will investigate the role of employment as an unequally distributed resource for maintaining and enhancing cognitive health. Additional training in social determinants of ADRD, quantitative analytic methods, and survey measurement of cognitive outcomes will put me in an ideal position to become a successful independent investigator that will make major contributions to health disparities and aging research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cannabis use and related negative outcomes are disproportionately high among sexual minorities (SM) relative to their heterosexual counterparts; however, our knowledge of mechanisms portending these health risks is nascent. The goal of this K99/R00 is to leverage daily, real-time measures to examine minority stressors, cannabis use, negative outcomes, and psychosocial factors among SM individuals who use cannabis to evaluate putative mechanisms linking stressors to harmful outcomes. Identifying mechanisms underlying known health disparities will inform when and how cannabis use may be harmful, identify possible intervention targets, and facilitate future detailed examinations of the progression of cannabis use among SM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The neocortex controls all high-level aspects of sensory perception, high level cognition and memory. The ques- tion addressed by the proposed studies, how cortical populations continuously adapt to different sensory envi- ronments, is a fundamental aspect of brain function. The proposed work addresses NIH’s mission to advance basic knowledge, medical science, and help reduce individual suffering and the societal burdens of developmen- tal disorders of the central nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to apply artificial intelligence techniques to electronic health records to advance research in diverticulitis, one of the most common gastrointestinal conditions for emergency department visits and hospital admissions. We propose to use natural language processing for clinical documentation and deep learning for imaging to build a prediction model for subsequent external validation to predict recurrence and long-term complications of diverticulitis. Our project will advance our understanding of factors predictive of diverticulitis outcomes and contribute to clinical care by generating a risk prediction model for risk stratification that will guide the appropriate management of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breast cancer is the second leading cause of cancer death among women in the United States, with triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) being the most aggressive and deadly form, and the only breast cancer subtype where immunotherapy is approved. Psychosocial stress, experienced by a large majority of breast cancer patients, remains an understudied and underappreciated contributor to the development of aggressive disease and resistance to treatments, including immunotherapy. The proposed work will provide insights into a novel mechanism of psychosocial stress-induced immunosuppression and uncover promising approaches that could be translated for therapeutic benefit for patients with TNBC.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Children remain a vulnerable group against many illnesses and in particular disease processes that require therapeutic administration of immune modulating agents, (e.g. cancer treatment) have not been studied in the context of the immature immune system. The proposed studies from this application will directly investigate this fundamental gap in knowledge using cellular metabolism to identify mechanisms regulating immune cell development and response to the childhood cancer neuroblastoma. The long-term goal of these studies is to identify metabolic vulnerabilities unique to interactions between the pediatric immune system and childhood cancers to enhance immunotherapy, increase survival, and decrease treatment related toxicity in children with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The mechanism by which Herpes Simplex Virus reactivates from a latent infection to cause disease is not known. This proposal will investigate viral gene expression during the initiation of reactivation and the role of the first viral protein identified that is required for exit from latency. The long-term goals are to understand how the virus co-opts cellular pathways for reactivation and ultimately identify novel therapeutic targets to prevent reactivation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is one of the most common complications of pregnancy and is associated with significant negative consequences for the maternal-offspring dyads. Professional societies recommend screening for GDM; however, guidance is inconsistent and late in pregnancy, thus precluding meaningful time to intervene for maternal-offspring benefit. Early approaches to GDM screening relying on clinical biomarkers in the first trimester exist, and this study will create a protocol for implementation of enhanced first trimester GDM screening and perform a feasibility and acceptability trial in the first trimester among high-risk pregnant women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This mentored career development proposal aims to train and mentor the principal investigator at a critical junction in training. One primary component is focused on the development of the principal investigator into a physician scientist who will be uniquely trained to identify and address clinically and scientifically relevant questions to improve the care of cardio-oncology patients. A second component is focused on identifying mechanisms of cardiac injury and remodeling as a result of cancer immunotherapies that regulate immune checkpoints.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Resilience, characterized as the capacity to recover quickly from highly stressful or traumatic experiences, may lessen the gravity of negative consequences of opioid use disorder (OUD). This study seeks to achieve a better understanding of resilience through the development of a human laboratory model that integrates measurement of psychobiological components of resilience (e.g., emotional flexibility – the ability to flexibly regulate emotions in a context-appropriate manner) with behavioral measures of stress reactivity (e.g., heroin demand on the heroin purchase task – a proxy for heroin self-administration). Developing a laboratory model of resilience will permit investigating whether resilience is stable and if it can be improved—a prerequisite to measure the effects of any new intervention targeting resilience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Recent studies have shown that genetic changes explain only 50% of lung cancer disease progression, strongly suggesting there are unidentified, non-genetic mechanisms that are driving drug resistance and metastasis. In preliminary experiments, we have identified that propionate metabolism, a pathway previously not known to play a role in cancer, is dysregulated in lung cancer, and its dysregulation can drive drug resistance and metastatic programs. This proposal aims to improve our understanding of propionate metabolism in lung cancer by defining the mechanisms and consequences of its dysregulation, potentially identifying a new pathway that can be targeted therapeutically.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative The Amish, as a persistently high fertility population in a low fertility context, offer a present-day opportunity to explore theories addressing why and how birth rates change and, by extension, the heavy investment of women in carrying and bearing children. Furthermore, because of their rapid population growth and preference for rural areas, especially in declining and depopulating regions, many Amish people are underserved, yet have an outsized impact on those rural healthcare systems and public infrastructures that are present. Finally, understanding how Amish fertility is responsive to internal and external mechanisms is important for understanding how, where, and why the Amish population is growing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our brains are hard-wired to prioritize the present over the future—a tendency called delay discounting that often leads us to choose immediate gratification even when we know it is not in our long-term interests. For pregnant women who smoke, the immediate rewards of a cigarette can overwhelm efforts to resist the temptation to smoke, despite most women wanting to quit for both their own and their baby's sake. Among pregnant women who smoke, this study will (1) measure delay discounting using a newly developed method that mimics the experience of addiction, (2) characterize how delay discounting affects smoking during and after pregnancy, and (3) building on evidence from animal and clinical research, test whether high-dose dietary supplementation of omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids reduces delay discounting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project will address a critical need for effective and scalable intervention approaches for adults presenting with suicide-related concerns to Emergency Departments (EDs), many of whom remain at high risk for suicidal behavior following ED discharge. Using a two-arm randomized controlled trial with an embedded micro-randomized trial (MRT), the project will obtain key data on feasibility, acceptability, and initial impact on hypothesized mechanisms to inform an effective technology-augmented intervention package, including ED- initiated safety planning and adaptive post-discharge text messages. Findings from this study will provide the necessary groundwork for a scalable and resource-efficient intervention targeting reduction in suicidal behavior during the high-risk transition after ED care.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will fill a gap by testing iTRAC-SU, a web-based, integrated substance use and emotion regulation training intervention, with adolescents involved with child welfare, to determine impact on substance use, as well as emotion regulation abilities, mental health symptoms, and other risk behavior outcomes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In the US 50,000 infants each year are born less than 28 weeks of gestation, and severe bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) poses a tremendous health and economic burden in these infants. This foundational work seeks to improve severe BPD prediction by a) focusing on kidney-based risk factors of acute kidney injury and fluid overload and b) identifying critical biomarker candidates. Improving severe BPD predication with kidney- based risk factors and biomarkers will facilitate individualized fluid management and improved AKI detection and treatment, decreasing the diagnosis and severity of BPD in prematurely born infants.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: HUGO W. MOSER RES INST KENNEDY KRIEGER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms are common and disabling among autistic children and adults, yet there are important limitations to existing measures of GI symptoms for this population. The proposed research will focus on the development, refinement, and psychometric evaluation of four versions (self-report and parent-report versions of pediatric and adult measures) of a novel questionnaire, the Autism Gastrointestinal and Related Behaviors Inventory (GIRBI). These measures will help promote rigorous epidemiology of gastrointestinal dysfunction, timely screening and diagnosis of GI conditions in research and clinical situations, assessment of safety and effectiveness of clinical trial interventions, and ultimately, health and well-being of autistic children and adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: HUGO W. MOSER RES INST KENNEDY KRIEGER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While the cerebellar dentate is one of the most commonly reported brain regions affected in brain tissue (post- mortem) studies of autism, examination of the dentate in living autistic children has been extremely challenging using standard (“3T”) MRI methods. To overcome this problem, we propose a highly innovative approach, using high-field (“7T”) MRI combined with a novel acquisition method (“susceptibility-weighted imaging – SWI”) and technique (“quantitative susceptibility mapping – QSM”) to successfully image the dentate in autistic children. This approach has strong potential for providing impactful discoveries about the brain basis of autism and provide novel brain-based targets for improving diagnosis, planning, and treatment for autistic individuals.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of this study is to identify the facilitators of coordinated care allowing us to access the levers of change to create a reliable system of care coordination for survivors of intimate partner violence (IPV) that is feasible, viable and, importantly, acceptable to all stakeholders, including IPV survivors, hospital and community-based organization (CBO) staff. We will accomplish this goal by conducting 30 in-depth interviews with IPV survivors, hospital and CBO staff to characterize facilitators and levers of change resulting in a logic model of change informing intervention development for IPV coordinated care in the emergency department setting, and through six focus group discussions with the same key stakeholder groups, we will generate intervention themes, components, scope and sequence. In collaboration with a community advisory board, we will finalize the logic model of change and intervention design for IPV coordinated care, ready for roll out and testing in the intervention production phase of future work.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In the United States, about half a million infants are born prematurely, prior to 37 weeks gestation, annually. Extremely premature infants born before 28 weeks gestation with a birth weight <1000g are most susceptible to complications of preterm birth, including spontaneous intestinal perforation, where little is known about the pathogenesis of this disease, and there are no disease-specific therapies. The proposed research will elucidate how aberrant T-cell activation exacerbates epithelial cell damage in spontaneous intestinal perforation with the hope of providing avenues for future studies into therapeutic targets in at-risk neonates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Urinary Stone Disease (USD) is a widespread ailment with significant health and economic impacts worldwide. However, the mechanisms underlying the condition are still not fully understood, and effective prevention strategies are lacking. This career development grant proposes to address these issues by employing next-generation sequencing technology to systematically investigate both monogenic and polygenic genes comprehensively and develop an integrated mono-polygenic risk model to facilitate precision medicine interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is no effective medical therapy that halt the progression of pulmonary arterial hypertension. We have recently developed novel serotonin 2B antagonists that prevent pulmonary arterial hypertension in preclinical animal models. We propose to identify lead compounds from our novel chemistry series, examine them for safety and toxicity, and determine their efficacy in our pulmonary arterial hypertension preclinical models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The immense public health burden of Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI) requires a better understanding of how variation in the microbiome contributes to disease outcome. The proposed studies will characterize mechanisms of commensal microbiota deterrence during C. difficile colonization and identify microbiome signatures of susceptibility to antibiotic-induced CDI. The results of this work will lead to the development of precise microbiome therapeutics that could be used to prevent CDI and innovative surveillance strategies to predict CDI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT) Patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE, commonly called lupus), a devastating autoimmune disease that preferentially targets African Americans and women of childbearing age, are at high risk for cardiovascular disease due to accelerated atherosclerosis. The proposed project will define mechanisms whereby fat that surrounds the blood vessels contributes to lupus-associated vascular disease. Furthermore, this proposal may lead to new therapeutic strategies directed against cardiovascular disease in patients with lupus.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE DNA double strand breaks (DSBs) pose critical threats to genomic integrity and stability. One critical protein that facilitates DNA DSB repair is the DNA damage response protein, MDC1. These studies will reveal a new model for how DSB repair is regulated by MDC1 which will provide critical insights into how genome integrity is maintained in human cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Targeting RNA polymerase I is a potentially effective therapeutic strategy for the treatment of many cancer types. This study investigates and identifies mechanisms of therapeutic resistance resulting from rewiring of protein translation. The alterations in translation and ribosome function will be determined to facilitate new therapeutic strategies to overcome this resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study addresses a key NHLBI priority, improving the quality of life for people with sickle cell disease globally. To do so, the study will employ mixed-methods, pilot trial to implement and test an integrated sickle cell screening and violence prevention intervention in the Sickle Cell Belt in Central India. The overarching goal of this study is to develop and test strategies to improve the safety of pregnancy and childbirth in stigmatized populations, particularly those with sickle cell disease or sickle cell trait.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly 20% of the more than 30 million Americans with type 2 diabetes face geographic or transportation barriers to diabetes specialty care. Telemedicine has the potential to help more patients access this care, but evidence suggests telemedicine is less effective for adults with type 2 diabetes which is complex, including those who use multiple daily injections of insulin and have multiple comorbid conditions. The objective of this project is to develop an intervention to deliver high-quality virtual diabetes specialty care to adults with complex type 2 diabetes, thereby improving effectiveness of care for patients who rely on telemedicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nanoparticle-based therapies have many potential advantages for treating cancer, but there are currently no clinical biomarkers to predict which patients are most likely to benefit from nanotherapies. This proposal seeks to validate the solute carrier SLC46A3 as a regulator of phospholipid metabolism in cancer cells and the first predictive biomarker for liposomal nanoparticle delivery.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Jail correctional officers experience high stress exposure, adverse mental health outcomes, and health disparities which necessitates addressing CO stress management in jail settings. Using implementation science methods, this study will develop an implementation strategy package to deliver a stress management intervention in the jail. Subsequently, we will conduct a pilot hybrid type II effectiveness-implementation trial of the intervention and the implementation strategies measuring acceptability, appropriateness, feasibility, and fidelity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Coxiella burnetii causes the debilitating disease Q fever, a flu-like respiratory disease that can progress to chronic endocarditis. Although endocarditis is the most severe form of this disease, we currently have no effective therapeutics to combat this potentially fatal disease. The overall goal of this proposal is to characterize the impact of new host-directed drugs on C. burnetii parasitism of primary human alveolar macrophages, which will suggest potential as novel anti-Q fever therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE NIH Public Health Relevance: Parents wield both genetic and social-environmental impact on children’s brain and behavior development and can contribute to both risk and resiliency to alcohol use disorder (AUD)[2] with ample evidence showing that children of alcoholics are four times more likely than other children to develop AUD, emphasizing intergenerational transmission of genetic risk[3]. Aspects of parenting are also critical to the effective development of children’s brain architecture, functions and capacity with neglected and maltreated children manifesting atypical brain development, increased rates of alcohol problems and other neuropsychiatric disorders,[11-19] but positive parenting (e.g., parent-child closeness) has been linked to lower levels of externalizing behaviors and higher effortful control in children, and has been posited as critical for normative development of self-regulatory capabilities, higher-level social, emotional, and cognitive development and the neurobiological systems that subserve them.[20-23] Unlike, extant research on AUD that focuses on studying risk factors, this K01 research proposal will focus on factors that promote resilience for AUD and given that parenting factors are among the most important variables in gene- environment interaction effects on resilience and risk for AUD, I will examine the role and interplay of parenting (e.g., parental bonding) and genetic (e.g., family history density, polygenic risk scores for AUD) factors on the development of neurocognitive function (e.g., response inhibition), and alcohol problems (e.g., alcohol problems) across adolescence and young adulthood, critical neurodevelopmental periods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol and cannabis are often used together such that their effects overlap (known as `simultaneous use') but evidence is conflicting regarding whether simultaneous use promotes increased or decreased alcohol intake, and little is known about the neural mechanisms that underlie simultaneous use. Real-world doses of THC have not been well-studied in the laboratory, and it is unclear how high doses of THC may impact alcohol consumption patterns. The proposed study will explore the effects of oral THC (20mg dronabinol) vs. placebo on neural reward, intravenous alcohol self-administration and naturalistic co-use patterns, and findings could impact public health and inform individual choices regarding co-use of cannabis and alcohol.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is a highly aggressive disease with dismal prognosis due to treatment resistance and disease recurrence. Immunotherapy targeting PD-1 immune checkpoint or its ligand PD-L1 (PD- 1/PD-L1) is an established first-line treatment for NSCLC, yet long-term disease control occurs in less than 25% of patients. Because evidence shows that the typically hypoxic nature of NSCLC tumors contributes to their treatment resistance, we propose to investigate the role of tumor hypoxia as a modulator of immune privilege in treatment-refractory NSCLC tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clear, realistic goals for surgery are not routinely identified during surgical consultations for older adults, presenting a barrier to person-centered surgical treatment. This proposal uses the NIH Stage Model to refine, adapt, and pilot test an existing prototype intervention that supports communication about goals for surgery among older patients, families, and surgeons during surgical consultations. The resulting intervention will advance person-centered surgical care for the growing population of older adults facing major surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  T cells responding to tumors or chronic infection tend to become hyporesponsive, yet T cells retain function despite persistent antigen during autoimmune disease. I propose several experiments to identify the molecular details of transcriptional programs that control the function of self-antigen specific T cells. These analyses will define transcriptional control of autoimmune responses and identify potential therapeutic targets to limit autoimmunity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE High blood pressure during pregnancy can lead to serious health complications during the birthing process, making the decision between attempting vaginal birth (through an induction of labor) or proceeding with cesarean delivery very critical. This study will identify the benefits and risks of each birthing option from multiple perspectives and create a framework that can help predict which approach is better for each patient. This will lead to patients receiving more personalized and safe medical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE γ-Secretase is a key enzyme involved in Alzheimer’s disease (AD). To better understand the γ-secretase biology and assist AD drug discovery, tools to image the γ-secretase in AD human brains will be valuable. The aim of this research project is to develop a potent γ-secretase positron emission tomography (PET) probe with appropriate performance characteristics to support the clinical trial of γ-secretase modulators in AD intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Altered experience or injury in development leads to deficits in speech and language perception that might originate in altered function of the primary auditory cortex. The proposed experiments elucidate how sounds engage these circuits and how subplate neurons shape the developing auditory cortex. These studies lay the groundwork for a better understanding of auditory cortical development, add to the knowledge of normal development in children, and add to the understanding of the effects of deafness and the causes of neurodevelopmental disorders. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Using secondary data from previous studies, we will conduct a detailed analysis of immune repertoire dynamics in patients with post-acute sequelae of COVID-19 (PASC), as compared with patients with a history of COVID-19 without PASC, and with healthy individuals. We will build cohort-specific models of thymic selection, examining how these models differ between cohorts and over time, inferring the dynamics of repertoire size, sharing and diversity, and uncovering the receptor features which drive these differences. In addition, we will develop new methods for the integration of T-cell repertoire and single cell dynamics, which will be of benefit for future research across a wide range of infectious diseases and immune-mediated medical conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Using a community based participatory research approach, we will recruit 1000 individuals from the Somali community in Southeast Minnesota to create a biorepository of plasma, DNA, and RNA. We will perform whole genome sequencing to assess demographic history, calculate polygenic scores and identify and return medically actionable variants to participants. Participants may benefit from learning about their genetic predisposition to disease and receiving timely treatment to reduce risk. By bringing genomic medicine to an understudied population, the proposed work aims to reduce disease burden and lessen health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A deeper understanding of injury processes in spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH), a severe form of hemorrhagic stroke for which there are no effective treatments, is critical. Through serum, plasma, and cerebrospinal fluid measures of maladaptive neutrophil inflammation (neutrophil extracellular traps, NETs), transendothelial neutrophil migration (soluble intercellular adhesion molecule-1), and brain tissue injury (neurofilament light chain, NfL), and by using an innovative high-resolution brain MRI approach in a prospective cohort of patients with ICH, the goal of this proposal is to acquire expertise in biomarker validation, clinical study conduct, and the use of imaging markers as endpoints in clinical trials in patients with ICH. This proposal will identify the contribution of NETs to local (edema) and remote (ischemic lesions) tissue injury, both associated with poor outcome after ICH, which may define novel treatment targets for patients with ICH, at the level of neutrophil migration, activation, or generation of NETs (NETosis).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: The acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a common, often fatal, inflammatory lung injury for which there are limited therapeutic options. In this proposal, I leverage my recent work highlighting neutropenic ARDS as a high endothelial stress population to propose studies that test the hypothesis that “neutropenic inflammation” activates the endothelium toward programmed cell death and the protective role of endothelial necrotic cell death protein receptor interacting protein kinase-3 (RIPK3) in this inflammatory environment. Collectively, these studies will provide novel insight into pathways of neutropenic inflammation and endothelial RIPK3 in regulating vascular injury in ARDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE High-risk human papillomavirus infections cause cervical cancer and other genital and oropharyngeal cancers that account for nearly 5% of cancers worldwide. HPV-positive cancers develop following long-term persistent HPV infections in which infected cells are retained in the proliferative basal layer of stratified epithelia. The goal of this proposal is to use a robust engineered tissue assay to test whether specific activities of HPV E6 and E7 oncoproteins from mucosal and cutaneous virus genotypes drive cell retention in the basal epithelial layer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ROSALIND FRANKLIN UNIV OF MEDICINE & SCI
PHR: Narrative Infections with encapsulated bacteria are responsible for the death of millions of children and the elderly each year. The efficacy of vaccines against these pathogens is severely limited by their inability to induce recall responses upon revaccination or infection. We will use a mouse model to improve vaccination against one of these bacterial infections and create proof of concepts that can inform future development of more effective vaccination strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a phenotypically heterogeneous entity with a broad range of possible clinical presentations and trajectories and a complex genetic architecture that includes multiple rare variants of large effect. This project investigates key domains of cognition and psychopathology in a subgroup of individuals with ASD who have rare genetic variants that are also associated with schizophrenia (SCZ), elucidating the underlying patterns of risk and emergence of co-occurring mental health problems in individuals with ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Skeletal muscle insulin resistance is one of the contributing factors to the development of Type 2 Diabetes; however, skeletal muscle is a complex tissue comprised of multiple cell types and masses of myonuclei, making it difficult to pinpoint where these aberrations occur. This project aims to uncover which cells and which areas of skeletal muscle are dysregulated in skeletal muscle insulin resistance in Type 2 Diabetes. This information will be used to design therapeutic interventions to alleviate skeletal muscle insulin resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Despite much research in this area, cardiac arrest remains one of the leading causes of death and an important cause of neurological disability in the U.S, suggesting the crucial need to seek innovative strategies to improve resuscitation outcomes. This re-submission K23 proposal aims to understand the physiology, impact in clinical outcomes, and the determinants of implementation success of a new resuscitation strategy involving the integration of transesophageal echocardiography (TEE), aimed to improve the efficacy of cardiopulmonary resuscitation in cardiac arrest patients. If successful, this novel approach has the potential to transform resuscitation care and improve clinical outcomes for cardiac arrest.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative A central role for lysosomal dysfunction has been highlighted for neurodegenerative disease mechanisms across multiple genetic forms of movement disorders, including Parkinson disease (PD) and dystonia. The proposed research will investigate the function of BORCS5, a lysosomal gene that we recently identified as a novel genetic cause of neurodegeneration with parkinsonism and dystonia. The project will reveal mechanistic insights into the role of BORCS5 in regulating the complex interplay of lysosomal intracellular dynamics, maturation and degradative properties with the goal of identifying novel therapeutic angles for targeting lysosomal dysfunction in neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In 2016, almost 3 billion people worldwide were estimated to have a headache disorder, the majority of whom were women. This sex difference starts in puberty, a time when neuroimaging has demonstrated brain changes driven by pubertal hormones. Through focus on transmasculine youth, the proposed longitudinal observational study will use neuroimaging techniques to explore the role of pubertal hormones in the development of sex differences in headache and relevant brain structure and function, with the vision of identifying targets for future therapies to reduce risk of headache.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Childhood epilepsy is a common and often devastating disease, and chronic seizures lead to a significant increase in premature mortality and developmental delay. A substantial proportion of children with Malformations of Cortical Development (MCDs) experience medically and surgically refractory seizures. This project will determine whether elongated axons, caused by known genetic changes, directly contribute to the untreatable seizures in children with MCDs and are thus a potential therapeutic target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative: Pathophysiology of gastrointestinal motor function underlies numerous disorders of gastrointestinal system, for example, gastroparesis. In this project, we will develop novel magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) methods for imaging the dynamic motor processes with at a high frame rate and in high resolution, all in the presence of respiratory and other motion. The success of this project will lead to an improved imaging methods to help visualize gastric motor function, enhancing the physiological understanding of a variety of gastrointestinal disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Depression is an independent risk factor for hypertension, and promising evidence suggests that treating depression can improve blood pressure control. This study will develop a community-informed intervention and implementation approach to treat depression among African American adults with comorbid depression and hypertension living on the South Side of Chicago. Results will inform public health efforts to widely disseminate depression interventions to promote blood pressure control among populations with significant cardiovascular disease disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Using cannabis for coping purposes is a problematic use pattern with negative health implications (e.g., greater quantity/frequency of cannabis use), and this behavior has potential for increase due to spreading cannabis legalization. The current project proposes to test several relationships relevant to this use pattern including causal factors, potential outcomes, and what variables may moderate/mediate the relationship between cannabis use and stress. Knowledge from this research can have significant impact on public health via aiding in intervention and prevention efforts as well as gaining information on the harm reduction potential of specific cannabinoid content.

PHR: Project Narrative GPR56, an adhesion G-protein coupled receptor, was recently identified as upregulated in microglia in individuals with early-stage Alzheimer's disease (AD) compared to those with no pathology or late-stage AD, implying its potential function in the disease. In this proposal, I hypothesize that microglial GPR56 limits AD pathological progression in both AD mouse models and human patients. I will use cutting-edge techniques, including single-cell sequencing, mouse genetics, live imaging, and human brain tissues, to reveal the role of microglial GPR56 in AD pathology, shedding light on a novel therapeutic target for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Becoming a successful translational scientist in the field of international infectious diseases is challenging, requiring extensive training in leading field studies, developing and performing laboratory assays, and synthesizing and interpreting the data generated. This K24 renewal will provide Dr. Greenhouse protected time for mentoring and career development, allowing him to help train the next generation of scientists in this area, drawing upon his broad expertise and established research program. He will focus on leadership development, expand the scope of his research portfolio beyond malaria, and establish an interactive, online training platform in genomic epidemiologic analysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite advances in the diagnosis and treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension, morbidity and mortality remain unacceptably high. To improve our currently limited understanding of how complex bioactive metabolite pathways interact to promote or prevent pulmonary hypertension, we will study upstream mediators of endothelial dysfunction in relation to disease risk and progression, in comprehensive study design. These studies can identify novel pathogenic and prognostic biomarkers and future therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Interventions to reduce e-cigarette use (nicotine vaping) among young adults is urgently needed given high prevalence of vaping in this age group, emerging vaping-related harms, and increased risk of tobacco smoking and other substance use escalation. This study innovatively capitalizes on cutting-edge methods of mobile health research to develop and pilot test a smartphone-based intervention delivering messages tailored to risky moments for vaping occurrence. This study will lay the groundwork for evidence-based innovative interventions to curb the vaping epidemic and prevent related harms among young people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a serious complication of several conditions including respiratory failure from pneumonia, other infection, cancer, organ dysfunction, surgery and trauma requiring mechanical ventilation and can lead to mortality in as much as 50% of those affected. ARDS has been described for over 50 years, however its heterogeneity has precluded the identification of effective treatments, and thus categorizing the syndrome based on what signaling cascades are affected may allow for the disease to be classified into subtypes. In deciphering the subtype of ARDS that involves lung vascular function, essential for absorption of oxygen from the lungs and expulsion of carbon dioxide from the body, we may identify therapies that may not have worked for a non-differentiated population of ARDS patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Youth involved in the legal system report elevate rates of cannabis use and are much more likely to develop cannabis use disorder than non-involved peers. The proposed K23 project aims to use Ecological Momentary Assessment to study cannabis use and Ecological Momentary Intervention to prevent cannabis use disorder for youth involved in the legal system. The proposed research will expand the investigator’s capacities as an independent health services researcher with expertise in: 1) cannabis use for youth involved in the legal system, 2) secondary prevention of cannabis use disorder, 3) Ecological Momentary Assessment and Intervention, 4) Personalized Feedback interventions, and 4) mobile health technology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Schizophrenia is a chronic illness with no treatments that interfere with the disease process. To design treatments that will change the course of schizophrenia illness, we need to map the detailed ways in which brains of people with schizophrenia differ. In this project, a new imaging method will be used to test whether there is an abnormality in the number of specific types of connection points between neurons in the brains of people with schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Inflammation plays a pivotal role in the development of HIV-associated comorbidities, including HIV-associated neurocognitive disorders (HAND). The use of substances of abuse, such as cocaine, worsen the neurological outcomes in HIV patients. We propose to develop novel NLRP3 inhibitors that will minimize the neuroinflammation in HIV patients abusing cocaine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As oncology capacity expands in sub-Saharan African countries such as Rwanda, implementation research is needed to improve the quality of patient-centered communication between clinicians and patients with cancer. The objective of this proposal is to develop patient-reported measures of communication quality that are appropriate for the Rwandan context and can be used to empower patients and clinicians to improve communication. Ultimately, a shift toward patient-centered care has the potential to improve cancer treatment outcomes, optimize resource utilization, mitigate clinician distress, and alleviate patient and family suffering. 1

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance The proposed research will examine three biological pathways which may account for the association of maternal childhood abuse with offspring neurodevelopmental deficits: 1) endocrine dysfunction during pregnancy, 2) inflammation during pregnancy, and 3) genetic loading for neurodevelopmental disorders. Neurodevelomental deficits, including autism and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), are major causes of disability, morbidity, and unemployment across the life course. Ascertaining the mechanisms by which mother's abuse affects offspring neurodevelopment will have a profound impact on the design of public health interventions to protect the healthy development of children, specifically: 1) identify targets for potential prenatal and perinatal interventions, 2) improve screening in prenatal and pediatric care, and 3) identify children who will benefit from early intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative (3 sentences): There is a clear and immediate need for the discovery of peripheral molecular signatures linked to central disease processes, core and co-pathologies in Alzheimer’s Disease (AD), that will serve as precision medicine blood-based biomarkers for diagnostic, prognostic, theragnostic and therapeutic purposes. AD is a complex disorder in which many biological pathways are disrupted due to multi-omic perturbations, which can be detected in brain and reflected in blood, i.e. centrally-linked peripheral molecular signatures (CLPMS). This U19 will leverage deeply phenotyped, longitudinal NIH-funded multi-ethnic cohorts and cross-disciplinary expertise for multi-omics data generation and its integration with harmonized AD endophenotypes, will share these data and utilize them in integrated U19 projects to discover CLPMS that will serve as the next generation of AD biomarkers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Though anti-Black racism has been identified as a main driver of perinatal health inequities, no studies have examined how racism experienced at both the individual and structural levels interact to produce preterm birth. In addition, examination of how stressors such as racism affect the epigenome of Non-Hispanic Black women is similarly understudied and essential for guiding interventions to reduce health inequities. The proposed study addresses a key theme of the National Institute of Health’s strategic plan (understanding biological, behavioral, and social determinants of population health) by examining how epigenomic changes may mediate the association between racism and preterm birth.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: More than 55,000 Veterans are living with a cardiovascular implantable electronic device (CIED): pacemaker or implantable cardioverter-defibrillator, which include 1 to 3 implanted cardiac leads. Unfortunately, hundreds of thousands of CIED leads have been recalled because of high failure risk. These recalls have occurred too late, spurred only by adverse event reports after patients suffered consequences such as inappropriate shocks and even death. There is no surveillance system to identify failing CIED leads. Through this research, population-level analyses will be conducted to identify CIED lead models with the lowest failure risk; these data will inform an intervention to support VA physicians in implanting the safest leads in Veterans. This research will also create a system to predict which lead(s) currently implanted in individual Veterans are at risk for early failure, thereby informing strategies to mitigate risk. Overall, this research will improve safety by reducing the number of Veterans who suffer CIED lead failure, thereby helping Veterans live longer with better quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will determine the contribution of the gut microbiome to mechanism of action of parathyroid hormone in bone. Our study will provide evidence that that primary hyperparathyroidism causes osteoporosis only in mice and patients harboring specific bacterial strains in their intestinal microbiome. This is important because sequencing of the stool microbiome may be used to predict which patients affected by primary hyperparathyroidism will develop bone loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Although it is widely known that people with psychosis have reduced cognitive ability compared to their psychiatrically healthy peers, the neurobiological mechanisms that give rise to this impairment remain poorly understood. In this project we will evaluate the role of a promising candadite biomarker of working memory dysfunction—a “core” cognitive deficit commonly observed in people with psychosis. Using EEG, we will (1) isolate a core psychophysiological process involved in working memory; (2) measure the impact of psychosis and illness chronicity on this biomarker; and (3) manipulate this biomarker using neurofeedback and measure the effects of this manipulation on working memory capacity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The proposal seeks to define the mechanism by which voltage changes activate ion conducting channels, a fundamental system in neurobiology, by determining atomic structures that enable therapeutic approaches to regulate ion channels in the lysosome, of impact in Ebola and viral infection. It also seeks to determine how regulatory complexes and their structural interfaces control uric acid transport in the endolysosome, to play a key factor in neurodegeneration, cancers, metabolic and cardiovascular diseases, that each depend on endolysosomal trafficking. A second set of aims concern determining the fundamental basis for the transmembrane transport of essential nutrients, particularly phosphate and glucose into, and removal of uric acid from cells, providing an atomic structural roadmap for therapeutic intervention in cancers, neurodegenerative diseases and malignant melanomas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Genomic analysis of plasma circulating tumor DNA has been adopted widely for genotyping of advanced cancer to select targeted therapies. This noninvasive biomarker also offers clear potential for evaluating treatment response, though no rigorous criteria have been established for determining when to assess response in plasma, and how much change is meaningful. In this grant we will identify a criterion for plasma response and evaluate its utility in clinical trial analysis and in guiding the care of lung cancer patients receiving first-line immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative At present, it is not known how the prostate cancer metabolome contributes to health disparities. The information gleaned from this proposal could rapidly revolutionize current diagnostic, prognostic, and therapeutic approaches by revealing the biological underpinnings of prostate cancer health disparity. This proposal investigates how altered metabolism in African-American Prostate Cancers promotes tumor progression and how the knowledge can be used in the future to develop diet based interventions and early detection markers for African American men.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ability to listen selectively in everyday environments like noisy restaurants, classrooms, and workplaces is essential to communication. Its disruption significantly diminishes quality of life in many communication, developmental, neurological, and psychiatric disorders. The project examines the mechanisms underlying human adult listeners' ability to direct attention to specific dimensions of sound.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Atrial fibrillation (AF) is an increasingly common heart rhythm disorder, affecting nearly 1 million Veterans engaged in VA health care. AF is associated with an increased risk of stroke, heart failure, and hospitalization, and results in substantial medical and societal costs. Although oral anticoagulant therapy reduces the risk of stroke from AF by 60%, it is often underutilized, particularly for racial and ethnic minorities who have an even higher risk of this adverse outcome. These inequities are particularly pronounced for a newer class of direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) – which have greater effectiveness, safety, and adherence compared to traditional warfarin anticoagulation. This project will use quantitative and qualitative research to understand the multilevel determinants of racial and ethnic disparities in anticoagulant therapy initiation for Veterans with AF and use the findings to empirically develop and test implementation strategies to reduce or eliminate these well-documented disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative: Alcoholic Cardiomyopathy (ACM) is the most prevalent form of ethanol-induced heart damage. There are currently no FDA-approved therapies for ACM. We propose to develop a pleiotropic natural compound emodin as a therapy for the prevention and treatment of ACM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Common and rare genetic diseases affect a large fraction of the world’s population, but the causal genetic variants affecting disease risk and the mechanisms by which they affect disease remain largely unknown. We will establish a Center of Biomedical Research Excellence (COBRE) in Human Genetics that constitutes a unique partnership between the Clemson University Center for Human Genetics and the Greenwood Genetic Center. Research in the COBRE in Human Genetics will focus on understanding the genetic, genomic, and epigenetic mechanisms by which molecular genetic variation affects rare and common diseases and will strengthen the biomedical research infrastructure of Clemson University and the state of South Carolina.
PI_NAMEs: ANHOLT, ROBERT R. H;MACKAY, TRUDY F. (contact)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Accumulating evidence over time to select between alternative options is a fundamental process in decision making, but canonical models suggest that neural signatures of this process should show persistent, ramping activity, unlike the choice-selective, sequential neural firing commonly observed throughout cortical and subcortical areas. This project will develop new computational circuit models that suggest different underlying mechanisms for accumulating evidence through sequences and analyze the correspondence between these novel models and neural recordings in different brain regions at the individual neuron and population levels during the same navigation-based, accumulation of evidence task. Successful completion of this work will lead to the development of novel models which propose yet unexplored mechanisms that may underlie decision making and advance our understanding of how decision making processes are distributed and coordinated across the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The profiling of genome variation from hundreds to thousands of cells now provides a powerful means to study the tempo and mode of molecular evolution at the finest resolution, but there is a need for new methods to analyze such datasets effectively. We will develop new mutation-ordering phylogenetic methods for evolutionary bioinformatics analysis of cell sequencing data. These methods and their software implementations will facilitate evolutionary research pursued by basic and applied biologists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative:  Understanding the fundamental principles governing social communication is of paramount importance as deficits in expressive and receptive vocal communication skills are hallmark characteristics of a wide range of neurological disorders. The proposed experiments aim to determine the direct impact of social communication on behavior and delineate how neural circuits encode social communication. Ultimately, knowledge gained from the proposed project has the potential to inform and hasten the discovery of novel therapeutic approaches that will help reduce the burdens of human disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Common mental disorders such as depression and anxiety are extremely prevalent among people living with HIV, interfere with lifelong adherence to treatment, and are associated with risky sexual behaviors. We hypothesize that screening and treatment of common mental health disorders is an important component of the HIV response in sub-Saharan Africa, especially in areas that are not on track to achieve HIV epidemic control. We will determine the best role for mental health care as part of the HIV response in highly endemic areas of sub-Saharan Africa, while also ensuring that the resources spent measuring the HIV prevention needs of specific locations are justified by the benefits of a customized HIV response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: Project Narrative  This program will investigate the enzymatic mechanisms of heme oxygenase enzymes using both spectroscopic characterization and computational modelling. Human heme oxygenases are drug targets due to their association with antioxidant and cytoprotective functions, along with neonatal jaundice, and improved fundamental understanding of the enzymatic reaction mechanism will aid these drug design efforts. Heme oxygenases are also part of iron acquisition pathways of pathogenic organisms, and fundamental understanding of these enzymes will aid antibiotic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE New and innovative strategies are urgently needed to increase the uptake of HIV prevention and sexual and reproductive health services among adolescent girls and young women (AGYW) in sub-Saharan Africa. In this study, we will rigorously evaluate an innovative intervention intended to create AGYW-friendly drug shops in Tanzania that includes the distribution of HIV self-test kits alongside contraception and linkages to care. The results from the study will provide guidance about whether community-based distribution of HIV testing at drug shops is an effective strategy for decreasing the incidence of HIV and unintended pregnancies among AGYW.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The aggressive form of kidney disease seen in blacks has been related to genetic risk variants prevalent in sub-Saharan Africa thought to be triggered by other genes and environmental factors. This application investigates diet (dietary nutrients and dietary factors) as risk factors and triggers for kidney disease in Africans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) in preterm infants is a common and often severe lung disease with long term sequelae. Currently, there are no biological markers available to predict which infants will develop BPD or to assess options for prevention and treatment. The goal of this project is to characterize infant physiology using metabolomics, and to investigate the role of race/ethnicity, genetics and medical interventions in order to increase our knowledge of the biological basis of BPD and improve the health and outcome of these infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) affects 1 in 4 adults, has no FDA-approved treatments, and increases the risk of developing end-stage liver disease and several cancers. Our proposed study examines the potential role of sphingosine kinase 2 (SphK2) in preventing hepatocyte mitochondrial dysfunction and inflammation, which coincide with NAFLD progression. These findings will significantly enhance our knowledge of fundamental hepatocyte biology and may inspire future research investigating sphingolipids as a potential drug target for NAFLD treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Community college (CC) students suffer high rates of depression and anxiety in the face of daunting life challenges (e.g. housing and food insecurity) without adequate mental health resources. This Center aims to optimize the effectiveness and implementation of a system for screening, tracking and treating anxiety and depression in a low-income, diverse community college student population, and explore pathways for sustainability and spread to other community colleges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Self-nonself recognition is an essential function that maintains and protects cooperative interactions among cells in a multicellular organism. As an example, our immune system interacts harmoniously with our own tissues, while eliminating foreign pathogens and non-cooperative cancer cells. This proposal investigates a new paradigm for cellular self-recognition and how cells assemble cooperative multicellular behaviors

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major challenge in treating birth defects and developing regenerative medicine is to better understand complex systems of cell fate specification in stochastic and dynamic environments. This application will exploit novel experimental tools and new computational methods to uncover new mechanisms that control fate specification in neural crest cells that form diverse tissues including body pigmentation, the peripheral nervous system and the skull. The expected new results are directly relevant to treating birth defects, regenerative therapy, and therapeutic strategies for the many diseases associated with these derivatives of the neural crest.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Endometrial cancer is becoming increasingly common, particularly in women with aggressive tumors who have poor outcomes. African American women have higher mortality than other racial/ethnic groups even after accounting for stage, histology, comorbid conditions, and treatment. Here, we will use the largest, most diverse population to date (including >1,000 African American and >2,000 non-African American endometrial cancer patients) to investigate endometrial tumor genomics, distinct risk factor profiles across tumor types, and the role of underlying tumor biology in driving this large survival disparity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Disease pathogenesis for non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) remains poorly understood and attempts to modulate a singular hepatic lipid homeostatic pathway have been plagued by unexpected compensation and feedback loops. We have shown that loss of hepatic folliculin (FLCN) robustly protects against NAFLD/NASH via an FLCN-mTORC1-TFE3 signaling axis that controls de novo lipogenesis and fatty acid oxidation. We have evidence that this non-canonical mTORC1 signaling also regulates VLDL-TG secretion and we propose that upregulated VLDL-TG secretion is a major mechanism by which loss of FLCN protects against NAFLD/NASH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent clinical need to develop non-addictive analgesic agents for abdominal pain in gastrointestinal disease patients, as current medications are not effective for all individuals. The enzyme glutamate carboxypeptidase II (GCPII) has well-defined functions in central and peripheral pain pathways and we have recently discovered that dysregulated GCPII in the enteric nervous system may also contribute to abdominal pain. This proposal will expand our knowledge regarding GCPII’s functions in abdominal pain and inform future drug development efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Food allergy has been associated with neuropsychiatric and neurodegenerative disorders, although how the immune disorder affects brain function is not clear. Our recent studies with a mouse model of cow’s milk allergy have indicated that allergic mice exhibit altered behavior, and brain pathologies are evident especially after repeated allergen consumption. Under the hypothesis that allergen-activated immune cells enter the brain to elicit damage-producing neuroinflammation, we aim to determine whether preventing the activation and migration of the immune cells will decrease these allergy-associated changes in the brain and behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Despite therapeutic advances in Hodgkin Lymphoma (HL), adverse effects of treatment can manifest as early as within one year after treatment and result in considerable morbidity, altered health-related quality of life, and excess mortality. Through an unprecedented, worldwide collaboration of adult oncology HL experts, epidemiologists, statisticians, imaging experts, and decision scientists, we have harmonized modern, multi- source HL data from seminal, international clinical trials and prominent HL registries that will be harnessed via simulation models for translation to clinical use. Our three-step approach (predictive modeling to multi-state modeling to simulation/decision modeling) will be designed to incorporate future prospective data as new/novel treatments and knowledge emerges over time and this project’s results will be significant as they will delineate acute & post-acute outcomes for individual HL patients and inform development of models & paradigms for other diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Integrase strand-transfer inhibitor (INSTIs) are the mainstay of antiretroviral treatment for people with HIV, but a major side effect is weight gain, which may potentiate the already increased risk for diabetes and cardiovascular disease in an aging HIV population. This proposal addresses key knowledge gaps of INSTI- associated weight gain, including sex-specific patterns and predictors, long-term cardiometabolic consequences, and underlying mechanisms by leveraging the MACS/WIHS Combined Cohort Study, the largest and longest longitudinal interval cohort of men and women living with and at-risk for HIV in the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The enteric nervous system is the largest collection of peripheral neurons that function independently of the central nervous system and are critical for controlling key intestinal functions, including motility, nutrient handling, and immune regulation, which have been shown to be dysregulated in the context of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), irritable bowel disorder (IBS), colon cancer, or during enteric infection. Therefore, a deeper understanding of the mechanisms by which the intestinal immune cells impact the function of enteric neurons is essential for elucidating the link between these two systems. This proposal will investigate the mechanism by which intestinal innate lymphoid promote ENS homeostasis during states of health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Urinary catheterization is one of the most common healthcare-related procedures; however, placement of a catheter is known to predispose patients to the development of catheter-associated urinary tract infections. Bladder inflammation is induced upon catheterization and changing the bladder environment allowing a diverse group of pathogens to infect. Fibrinogen, a proinflammatory protein, is released in the bladder and deposited onto the catheter surface, becoming a key platform for microbial colonization. This project focuses on understanding how modulation of protein deposition on the catheter by using a liquid surface coating may affect microbial colonization, biofilm formation, and systemic dissemination, as well as the inflammation response. This approach will offer new insights to inform the development of new clinical treatments that will continue to remain effective long-term.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative: Opioid use disorder is a public health crisis in the United States with roughly 80,000 overdoses taking place in 2021, therefore further studies are needed into the molecular and cellular changes underlying the habitual/compulsive use characteristic of this disorder. Previously, the Hurd Lab identified alterations in Fyn kinase within the dorsal striatum, a region implicated in habitual drug use and craving, as associated with heroin use in humans, which, when reversed, decreased heroin seeking in a translational model of relapse. My project will investigate the impact of Fyn modulation on goal-directed and compulsive heroin self- administration, activity of dorsal striatal neurons during heroin seeking, and gene expression to give me training in behavioral models of compulsive drug seeking, in-vivo fiber-photometry, and RNA-sequencing and bioinformatics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Current therapeutic approaches have generally proven ineffective in treating patients with advanced prostate cancer (CaP) that has metastasized to bone. Understanding the mechanisms contributing to CaP progression, involving the tumor cell and its microenvironment, and developing improved therapeutic strategies to eradicate bone metastases is crucial for diminishing disease morbidity and mortality. Using clinically effective immunotherapy in combination with molecular-targeted therapies may provide a safe and effective treatment to achieve this goal.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite unquestionable past successes in medicine, most complex terpene natural products have yet to realize their full potential as therapeutic agents. This program will greatly expand the chemical toolkit of small molecules for the treatment and understanding of human disease using natural product structures as inspiration. During the course of this work, new synthetic strategies, methods, chemical reactivity principles, and natural product mechanisms of action will be uncovered and developed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (revised)  This research is relevant to public health because chronic stress profoundly impacts brain circuit function and is a major risk factor for many neuropsychiatric disorders. In this project the causal role of neural circuits in chronic social stress-induced behavioral impairments in both male and female mice will be studied to provide a mechanistic understanding on social circuit maladaptive changes in response to chronic stress. Successful completion of this study will likely establish a lead neural circuit for targeted interventions to neuropsychiatric diseases featuring social impairments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative: There is widespread consensus that early detection of Alzheimer's using non-invasive biomarkers is critical, because cognitive and memory deficits occur past the point of no return. Full validity and relevance of these biomarkers requires detailed understanding of their underlying biological mechanisms, and how they relate to disease progression. Here we seek to understand the cellular and circuit mechanisms underlying two emerging biomarkers, gap detection and fMRI functional connectivity measures. This understanding will deepen and extend the validity of these biomarkers for early diagnosis of Alzheimer's, could also provide a basis for the development of new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Despite of a great deal of effort by public and private institutions, we don't have a prophylactic vaccine against HIV-1 or an eradication protocol to treat infected patients. Recently, laboratories all over the word have reported an increase in the transmission of HIV-1 strains that are resistant to one or more components of the antiretroviral (ART) cocktail. In order to find novel therapeutic targets, basic understanding of HIV-1 replication is urgently needed. This proposal will study the basic mechanisms of the early steps of HIV-1 infection, which may lead to the discovery of novel and more effective therapeutic targets for HIV-1/AIDS.!
