IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Loss of RB function is a dominant mechanism driving prostate cancer lethality. It is therefore critical to identify potential therapeutic strategies targeting this disease mechanism to reduce prostate cancer mortality rates and improve the well-being of patients and their families who are experiencing the impact of the disease. Our work will delineate downstream effectors of the RB/E2F pathway and provide novel insights into the contributions of RB to ferroptosis as well as the preclinical data regarding efficacy, safety, and biomarkers required for the rational design of future clinical trials targeting ferroptosis as a therapeutic approach to treating lethal RB1-deficient prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PI: Sinha, Rajita TITLE: Chronic Alcohol and Brain Stress Circuit Response (R01-AA013892-15) PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a current opioid crisis in the US driven by high levels of chronic pain and heavy alcohol intake that alters brain and peripheral pain and stress pathways in ways that promote increased alcohol craving and heavy drinking risk. This project will study men and women with and without alcohol use disorder (AUD) and those with and without chronic pain in an experiment of neural and biobehavioral responses to stress/pain and alcohol cues relative to neutral cues, and also assess if changing those responses with standard behavioral pain and AUD treatment improves clinical pain and craving symptoms and pain-related alcohol use outcomes in AUD. Findings will critically inform development of new interventions to reduce pain-related heavy drinking to improve alcohol use and pain outcomes.

PHR: Narrative. This proposal seeks to elucidate how the immune system regulates its mechanisms that detect, control and eliminate cancers and virally infected cells. This is an important issue because this process is essential to a patient's ability to prevent and/or fight these diseases naturally or in the setting of immunotherapy. The information gained from the proposed studies may lead to a better ability to predict and/or manipulate immune responses to tumors and ultimately aid in the immunotherapy of cancers.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research seeks to reduce inappropriate antibiotic use in pediatric acute lower respiratory tract infections, the most common serious infections in childhood. Antibiotic overuse is common in this population and is associated with substantial consequences. The major goals of this proposal are to design, implement, and evaluate the effectiveness of clinical decision support tools that promote judicious use of antibiotics in children and adolescents with lower respiratory tract infections in real-world emergency and inpatient settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This prospective study will examine the factors that account for variability in the trajectories of well-being and mental health in family caregivers of young adults with autism and other developmental disorders, linking them to biological measures of accelerated aging. Social connectedness, generative activities, cumulative caregiving burden, life events and transitions, family functioning and demographics and young adult characteristics will be evaluated as potential contributors to positive and negative outcomes in family caregivers. This study will inform our understanding of the types of supports needed for caregivers of aging individuals with autism and other developmental disorders.

PHR: Successful completion of the experiments listed in this proposal will characterize, in detail, the Clostridium difficile spore ‘germinosome’ complex – a complex consisting of the CspB, CspA, CspC and SleC proteins – and how this complex is formed. Moreover, this application will identify and characterize YabG protease substrates (other than CspBA and preproSleC). The knowledge gained from these experiments could lead to the design of novel therapeutics to combat C. difficile spore germination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: The manifestation of depressive symptoms is contributed by the disturbance of complex neural networks, including the dopaminergic neural circuit. Astrocytes have been shown to play an important role in the modulation of neuronal activity and synaptic plasticity, and may be crucial for dopamine release during the development and progression of depressive symptoms. The proposed research aims to understand the mechanisms and contribution of insulin signaling-dependent exocytosis of ATP by astrocytes on the regulation of dopamine signaling and reward deficits under chronic stress exposure, which will further expand our understanding of the etiology of depressive disorders and may reveal new therapeutic approaches for depressive disorders.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is relevant to public health, as it will foster a better understanding of the relative influences psychological, social, and epigenomic factors have on cLBP and will also give insight into the mechanism the drives racial disparities in cLBP. The proposed project is in response to NIAMS RFA-AR-20-001, Mechanistic Ancillary Studies to Ongoing Clinical Projects. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Retinitis pigmentosa is a group of blinding diseases and is the most common cause of inherited retinal diseases causing vision loss. Modern retinal imaging methods can non- invasively measure the progression of these disorders. The proposed project is important to public health because we will accurately quantify biomarkers of disease on retinal images to determine whether a novel treatment, N-acetyl cysteine, can significantly slow the progression of this devastating condition, which would thereby reduce personal, financial, social, and health burden costs.

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Tuberculosis kills nearly 2 million people annually. Tuberculosis therapy takes 6-9 months, a problem that leads to decreased compliance for taking antibiotics and increased chances of developing drug-resistance. The rise of extensively drug resistant (XDR) strains of M. tuberculosis is a public concern, thus the identification of specific pathways in Mycobacterium tuberculosis that could be targeted by new drugs is of great interest.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will test a novel intervention (intensive antihypertensive control) to determine if it will decrease osteonecrosis in children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), while also identifying biomarkers of osteonecrosis risk. This can reduce a side-effect of therapy causing lifelong disability, a crucial goal because more than 90% of children with ALL will become long-term survivors. Identification of both interventions and biomarkers for osteonecrosis will have broad significance as this side-effect complicates therapy not only of ALL but for other cancers and autoimmune diseases which use glucocorticoids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Narrative Alzheimer's disease is the most common neurodegenerative disease and its current lack of effective treatment makes determining factors that may modify the disease course of paramount importance. Sleep disruption is one such factor, and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), the most common clinical form of sleep disruption, is highly prevalent in the aged. The current proposal addresses the longitudinal impact of untreated OSA on both memory and brain tau accumulation as well as the impact of OSA treatment on tau in cerebrospinal fluid.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Invasive lobular breast cancer (ILC), which is characterized by the near universal loss of E-cadherin and unique growth pattern, accounts for 10-15% of all breast cancer (up to 40,000 new cases per year) and is understudied in part due to a lack of credentialed models in which to study the disease. Here we propose to comprehensively generate and characterize cell line, organoid, patient-derived xenograft, homograft and genetically engineered rodent models of ILC and compare them to the human disease. We will perform detailed genomic, epigenomic and transcriptomic analyses, phenotypic studies and therapeutic efficacy studies to test which models recapitulate the unique biology of human ILC, thereby credentialing them for future use in the study of ILC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE Congenital cardiac anomalies represent the most common birth defect, affecting nearly 1% of all live births. Despite significant advances in surgical and medical management, these conditions remain a leading cause of death and disability in the newborn period. One significant source of morbidity and mortality arises from complications associated with the use of currently available prosthetic vascular grafts, cardiovascular patches, and replacement heart valves that are frequently required to perform reconstructive procedures. Tissue engineering offers a potential strategy for creating improved biomaterials for use in congenital heart surgery. In this project, we will elucidate the mechanism underlying LYST-mediated TEVG stenosis, the most common graft-related complication and the critical barrier preventing its widespread clinical use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Cadmium is an environmentally prevalent toxic metal posing increasing risk to human health worldwide. The proposed studies will take a step to understand the impact of chronic cadmium exposure on membrane transport and consequently on drug disposition and response in the kidney. Findings from the proposed studies are expected to provide mechanistic insights into the regulation of renal transporter proteins and to fill knowledge void of cadmium exposure as a source of broad variation in drug response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our goal is to conduct a large multi-site randomized controlled trial (RCT) of a promising computer-facilitated Screening and clinician Brief Intervention (cSBI) system designed for delivery by pediatric primary care clinicians and aimed at reducing unhealthy alcohol use and related riding/driving safety risk among adolescent patients. Our setting will be the American Academy of Pediatrics' (AAP) Pediatric Research in Office Settings (PROS) national primary care research network, with >600 U.S. primary care practices having participated in recent studies. This trial addresses the evidence gap identified in the latest U.S. Preventive Services Task Force review of alcohol screening and brief counseling interventions among adolescents, and, if shown effective, the cSBI system could be widely disseminated via AAP's existing education, teaching, and advocacy platforms to its 67,000 pediatrician members, thereby greatly increasing the potential for population- level impact of alcohol screening and brief intervention for U.S. adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite high levels of stress, there are few empirically-supported stress management interventions for caregivers of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HCT) cancer patients, despite research showing that caregiver burden and distress can have an adverse impact on patient health outcomes, including decreased patient survival. Mindfulness-based approaches may be particularly beneficial, given active mechanisms of mindfulness and the unique stressors experienced by this caregiving population. This project will build on pilot data by randomizing participants to one of three treatment conditions: FOCUS, Healthy Living (HL), and Usual Care (UC) to determine whether FOCUS demonstrates efficacy above HL and UC on caregiver burden, patient distress, and patient healthcare utilization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol and methamphetamine use are associated with increased HIV risk among men who have sex with men (MSM) but the precise behaviors most responsible for this elevated risk are not well understood. This study will integrate data from several large cohort studies to parameterize network epidemic models and provide holistic estimate of the effect of these substances on HIV incidence among MSM. Subsequently, we will leverage these models as an experimental laboratory to evaluate the population level impact of substance use and HIV interventions among MSM, utilizing cutting-edge computational tools to identify robust and optimal interventions for HIV elimination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Congenital heart defects are present in 1-2 out of 100 births, and are the leading non-infectious cause of death in the first year of life, yet the initiating instructions for early heart formation are not well understood. We will use analysis of gene expression and chromatin states in single cells of mouse embryos, as well as live imaging of mouse embryos, to understand the mechanisms by which the first heart cells arise in the embryo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Increasing recognition and diagnosis of opioid use disorder adds additional complexity to management of other chronic medical conditions commonly seen in primary care, leading to high cost and inappropriate utilization of health services; intensive primary care interventions targeting high-risk patients with opioid use disorder may be a potential solution. The proposed project adapts an intensive primary care intervention of multi-disciplinary staff addressing social determinants of health to outreach complex patients with opioid use disorder seen in primary care, and assesses feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary efficacy to improve quality of care for these patients. The results of this project will help community health systems develop scalable interventions for medically complex patients with opioid use disorder to improve health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Atrial fibrillation is a major health concern and a primary cause of stroke and thromboembolism. Percutaneous cardiac catheter ablation is currently used to treat atrial fibrillation in order to eliminate a lifelong multidrug regimen but its main limitation is high recurrence rate due to poor intra-procedural ablation monitoring and the inability to visualize lesions directly. We propose to develop and commercialize a new generation of percutaneous ablation catheters that enable direct real-time identification of radiofrequency ablation lesions to achieve safer, faster, cheaper, and more reliable atrial fibrillation ablation therapy

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Targeting ubiquitin and ubiquitin-associated systems has emerged as a rational strategy in the treatment of human diseases ranging from cancer to neurological and neuromuscular disorders. These targeted approaches are fostered by advances in understanding the fundamental mechanisms of these ubiquitin and ubiquitin-associated systems. The proposed research is relevant to public health and NIH mission in that it aims to promote innovative research discoveries and strategies to advance knowledge of ubiquitin-like systems associated with human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This project aims to compare the epidemiology, treatment intensity, and outcomes for patients hospitalized with five acute “tracer” conditions in five OECD countries with vastly different health system organization. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This project will use computational methods to characterize molecular details of viral infection processes in enteroviruses, which include severe pathogens EV-A71 and EV-D68. Children are most susceptible to these viruses, which can cause severe respiratory symptoms, paralysis and can even be fatal, and at the current time there are no approved treatments for these viral infections. This project will provide fundamental knowledge about the enterovirus infection process, which can lead to new drug development strategies against these pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Zhu-Tokita-Takenouchi-Kim (ZTTK) syndrome, characterized by intellectual disability, delayed motor-psycho development and multi-organ anomalies, is a recently identified rare disease caused by de novo heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the SON gene (SON haploinsufficiency). This project is to examine the hematopoietic abnormalities associated with ZTTK syndrome using mouse models, and to dissect the underlying molecular mechanisms. The results generated from this study will advance our understanding of this rare disease and serve as a basis for our future efforts to develop therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Recent advances in applications of machine learning methods to animal behavior quantification at high spatial and temporal resolution have yielded novel insights into neural functions, however, democratization of this technology remains a challenge. To better disseminate the theoretical and technical knowledge of this field, and train researchers to apply machine learning methods to behavior quantitation and modeling, we propose The Short Course on the Application of Machine Learning for Automated Quantification of Behavior. Our goal is to build an educational program that fosters productive and interactive dialogue, teaches proper methodology, and provides support structure to nurture and lower the barrier of entry into this nascent and emergent field that has the potential to facilitate leaps in our understanding of behavior and complex diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

This knowledge will ultimately help clinicians more effectively treat glucocorticoid myopathy in the Alzheimer’s population. The proposed research is relevant to the NIH’s mission that pertains to seek fundamental knowledge about living systems and the application of that knowledge to enhance health, lengthen life, and reduce disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative This work aims to develop the underlying technology to move towards the development of portable, minimal-equipment protein diagnostics, with applications to nutritional deficiencies and other diseases. This approach could enable large-scale epidemiological studies across the globe that will inform policy-making on nutritional interventions to better treat millions of undernourished people as well as improve diagnostic capabilities for neonatal intensive care unit patients who cannot give large volumes of blood for testing. Additionally, this approach can be used as a basis for other minimal-equipment protein sensors, further broadening access to medical testing in resource-poor areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Holoprosencephaly (HPE), a common malformation of the forebrain and midface, has a complex etiology involving genetic and environmental risk factors. Fetal alcohol exposure is one such factor, but its interaction with predisposing genetic variants, the identity of its embryonic target cells, and the developmental pathways it affects are all poorly understood. Using mouse models of HPE, we aim to provide insight into these questions to enhance understanding of gene-environment interaction in causation of birth defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE DNA and RNA can be alkylated upon exposure to alkylating agents in the environment or produced from endogenous metabolism. The proposed research will provide important insights into the molecular mechanisms about how alkylated DNA lesions perturb genomic stability, how cells sense and repair these DNA lesions, and how post-transcriptional modifications of RNA contribute to neurological diseases. The outcome of the proposed study will provide important new knowledge for the prevention and treatment of human diseases arising from DNA alkylation damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is one of the most deadly human cancers. We have recently identified a transcriptional network involving Yap, Myc and Sox2 that is important for PDAC tumor maintenance. In the current proposal, we outline a plan to fully elucidate the epigenetic mechanisms that enables PDAC cells to bypass Yap addition and investigate the therapeutic potential of using epigenetic inhibitors to prevent or overcome PDAC resistance to Yap blockade. The proposed study, once completed, will provide critical insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying PDAC plasticity and facilitate the development of more effective treatment strategies to improve the dismal outcome of this disease.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Knowing that connection is the key to recovery, we developed Peer PLUS (People Leveraging Urgent Support) in partnership with certified peer recovery coaches and individuals with lived experience of recovery from substance use disorder. The Peer PLUS mobile app provides a secure channel for just-in-time, two-way communication between peer recovery coaches and their clients – facilitating confidential messaging, transfer of information, and tracking of appointments and referrals to resources – and the companion website makes it possible for a team of peer recovery coaches to offer more comprehensive coverage for a pool of clients. Importantly, both the app and website are not tied to any specific care provider, and the modular software design and implementation toolkit will allow it to be readily taken up by any peer recovery support service organization.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Peer PLUS: A Client-Centered Digital Intervention for Addressing the Needs of Individuals with Substance Use Disorder

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: HENRY M. JACKSON FDN FOR THE ADV MIL/MED
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study addresses the mechanisms that control initiation of homologous recombination in mammals. Recombination defects, including reduced recombination efficiency and improper placement of recombination events, are invariably associated with infertility, miscarriage and aneuploidy-related birth defects. Progress in the recombination field will lead to a better understanding of the causes of faulty chromosome segregation and eventually to developing measures for their early diagnosis and prevention of resulting health conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Cellular senescence has been shown to contribute to age-related bone loss. In this project, we propose to define the interactions between senescent immune cells and skeletal cells, testing our central hypothesis that senescence of immune cells contributes to skeletal deterioration and conversely, senescent skeletal cells attract and contribute to an inflammatory and/or senescent phenotype of immune cells. In addition to defining underlying mechanisms, these studies may identify novel therapeutic targets to prevent, or reverse, age- related osteoporosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peripheral nerve injury induces pain that lasts more than three months (chronic neuropathic pain) in patients, which affects their quality of life and has a substantial economic and social impact due to limited treatment options. Thus, the medical community needs novel and more effective therapies to prevent the development of chronic neuropathic pain. The proposed studies will provide the foundation for a new non-narcotic therapeutic strategy that has the potential to reduce the incidence of chronic pain following nerve injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The small intestine is separated into two main parts, the lumen where food passes through, and the lamina propria, where immune cells reside. A single layer of cells separates these two parts and provides a selective barrier that prevents bacteria and food particles from passing though, while allowing nutrients to leave the lumen. This proposal investigates how a breakdown of that barrier may lead to severe reactions in food allergy, whereby food proteins inappropriately move from the lumen and activate immune cells in the lamina propria, leading to anaphylaxis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Persons who withdraw from opioids have different experiences, but little is known about the magnitude of these differences or what might predict different responses across individuals. This study will combine a laboratory session with a clinical treatment trial to learn more about these differences. We will also examine differences between men and women, with a goal of helping providers better match patients to different opioid use disorder treatment medications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposal seeks to determine the role of the purinergic system in the development of Chagas cardiomyopathy and how targeting these pathways impacts disease progression. Through the study of cardiac explants from transplanted patients and murine experimental models the project will provide detailed insight into the biology of the cardiac response to infection. The investigations will provide a comprehensive understanding of regulatory mechanisms through which Trypanosoma cruzi infection subverts immune response to sustain parasite persistence within host tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Tuberculous meningitis (TBM) is the most lethal and disabling form of tuberculosis arising when Mycobacterium tuberculosis crosses the blood-brain barrier. To better understand TBM disease mechanisms and response to drug treatment, we have access to unique clinical samples from TBM patients prior and during therapy. We propose to analyze these samples to measure the penetration of TB drugs in brain lesions, and refine a rabbit model of TBM, which will be used to discover new and better drugs that hit critical and vulnerable pathways to ameliorate TBM disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Scripps hub brings together Scripps Research and its partners Scripps Health, Rady Children’s Genomic Medicine Institute, and newly added San Diego State University, along with many collaborating entities, to innovate and transform translational and clinical science. The three principal focus areas of SRTI—genomics, digital medicine, and informatics/analytics—are interdependent, and foster a multi-dimensional understanding of human beings, which is the true foundation of individualized medicine. The Scripps hub will relentlessly pursue innovations in translational and clinical science to promote accuracy, individualism, and democratization, with deep academic and industry collaborations, fully integrating the voice of the community and patients, with a paramount goal of reducing health inequities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Urethral stricture disease and hypospadias are conditions that affect children and adults. When urethral replacement or repair is required, alternative tissue options are limited and are associated with high risk of short and long-term complications. This proposal will create and evaluate a novel bioinspired, biomimetic, cell-seeded urethral tissue construct with optimized biomechanical properties to support urethral tissue regeneration in these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
ORG_NAME: NEBRASKA ST DEPT OF HEALTH & HUMAN SERVS
PHR: Project Narrative Nebraska Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (NE PRAMS) data is utilized by the Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services (NDHHS) Maternal and Child Health (MCH) programs and other state public health programs as a source of accurate information on state-specific, population-based data on maternal attitudes and experiences before, during, and shortly after pregnancy. NE PRAMS is currently the only readily-accessible source for population-level data on important issues such as pregnancy intendedness, reasons for patterns of prenatal care use, nutritional status of the mother, preconception health, and for postnatal behaviors such as depression, infant sleep position, and breastfeeding. State progra ms, local health departments, and community health organizations across the state that focus on maternal and child health issues have come to rely on PRAMS data to help identify, address, monitor, and evaluate both emerging and previously identified problems.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DP21-001 Nebraska Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System

ORG_NAME: ALASKA STATE DEPARTMENT OF HLTH-SOC SVCS
PHR: Project Narrative PRAMS is relevant to public health through its standardized collection of population-based data on maternal and infant health issues specific to Alaska. PRAMS provides self-reported maternal and infant health behavioral data that adds to outcome information gleaned from birth or hospital records that is helpful to program planning and evaluation. The standardized PRAMS protocol and methodology across states adds to the nationwide picture of maternal and child health status.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: Washington State PRAMS Component A [Core Surveillance] Grant 2021 Project Narrative The overall goal of Washington Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PRAMS) is to provide data that will influence program strategies, and policies that impact the health of women, infants and families in Washington State. The PRAMS survey provides a unique source of data on the behaviors and experiences of women before, during and just after delivery that is not available from any other source at the state level. This purpose of this proposal is to continue the PRAMs survey in Washington State. Approximately 2,000 Washington resident mothers per year are drawn from birth certificate data using a stratified random selection based on race/ethnicity. With a response rate of 55%, we are expecting that 1,100 women will participate in the survey. The data collection method for Washington PRAMS will involves a statewide mailing of the questionnaire with either a telephone or web-based survey as follow-up for non-responders. Completed surveys are cleaned by CDC, linked to the annual birth certificate file and weighted for non-response, an analytic file is sent to Washington PRAMS. Once Washington State receives the final analytic file from CDC we will analyze, interpret, and disseminate PRAMS data. The Washington State PRAMS project will utilize PRAMS data to plan and monitor programs and policies aimed at reducing health problems among mothers and infants.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-DP-22-001 DP006601 Component A - Core Surveillance - Washington Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PRAMS) RFA-DP-16-001

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  While several studies have noted substantial variations in the generosity of benefit coverage required by state autism insurance mandates, there is little evidence on how the effects of insurance mandates vary by the generosity. This proposed study aims to fill the evidence gap by identifying which specific mandate policy features matter most for improving health care for children with autism. The study findings have the potential to inform policymaking on expanding insurance benefits and closing coverage gaps for children with ASD, and the findings will also be relevant to broader debates around optimal design of essential health benefits, a topic of great interest to policymakers and researchers, especially in the past decade.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE A major roadblock to rational HIV-1 vaccine design is the lack of a suitable primate model where the induction of broadly neutralizing antibodies (bNAbs) can be achieved in a consistent and reproducible manner and the molecular events responsible for bNAb elicitation deciphered. This HIVRAD application proposes a novel means to overcome this roadblock by using SHIVs as immunogens and new B cell analytics to elucidate Env-Ab co- evolutionary pathways, leading to new strategies for germline-targeted, B cell lineage-based vaccine design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is one of the most lethal forms of cancer with 5-year survival rates of 7%. Our preliminary data suggest a key factor driving pancreatic tumor progression is the profound immune suppression in tumors driven by gut micro biome-produced metabolites. In this application we predict interfering with this gut-tumor axis will cause the tumors to become inflamed reducing growth and spread rendering pancreatic cancer sensitive to therapy. This project has the potential to completely change our understanding of the microbiome and how it influences immunity. Likewise, lessons learned from this project will enhance our understanding of tumor- gut interactions that will provide new prognostic tools and therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIS CENTER
PHR: Project narrative Because K+ selective ion channels are essential regulators of cell excitability, their dysfunction underlies a myriad of human pathological conditions that make them excellent targets for drugs to treat very diverse diseases, such as: LQT syndrome, arrhythmia, epilepsy, autoimmune diseases and diabetes. It follows that understanding the function-structure correlations of K+ channels at atomic resolution will pave the road to develop highly-specific therapeutic drugs to correct channelopathies. The central tenet of this grant application is how the structure determine the function of ion channel and how this relationship is influenced by the cell membrane lipid composition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The increase in overdose-related deaths associated with the misuse of clinical opioids has prompted synthesis efforts geared towards designing safer opioids. Novel atypical opioid agonists have been developed that appear to have a favorable profile of behavioral effects, producing full analgesia with fewer unwanted side effects (e.g., respiratory depression, abuse liability); however, the mechanisms underlying the improved profile are not known. Our studies will determine the extent to which the desirable profiles of these agonists are due to low intrinsic efficacy at mu-opioid receptors or to preferential activation of one of the mu-opioid receptor’s signaling pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative The project will yield a highly flexible and effective analytical method for reducing confounding bias in studies that utilize routine-care data to compare effects of medical or surgical treatments. This method will enable researchers to leverage a large amount of patient information recorded in the clinical notes and reports that are contained within electronic health records to adjust for differences in background risks of different comparison groups. Our proposal can improve the quality of evidence based on electronic healthcare data generated in the routine-care settings to better inform patient care and optimal prescribing.

PHR: Project Narrative Arthropod-transmitted viruses belonging to the large Bunyavirales order (such as Oropouche virus (OROV), La Crosse virus (LACV), and Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV)) can cause significant disease outbreaks in humans throughout the world. Our proposed work will define critical host factors for virus entry and identify novel targets that will facilitate pan-bunyavirus therapeutic development. Recent outbreaks and the emerging nature of bunyaviruses due to climate change, coupled with a rising potential of misuse in the form of bioterrorism, underscore the importance of the proposed studies to global health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The DNA mismatch repair system (MMR) is essential for maintaining the integrity of mammalian genomes and defects in MMR are the cause of the most prevalent cancer syndrome, Lynch syndrome (LS) that is characterized by the development of cancers in the colon, endometrium ovary and other tissues as well as in significant number of sporadic colorectal cancers in humans. We are studying genetically modified mouse lines and human LS patient derived xenograft tumors with mutations in MMR genes to determine the ability of MMR in intestinal stem cells to suppress tumor formation. The goal of our studies is to provide a better understanding of the cellular and molecular mechanisms that underlie MMR-deficient colorectal tumorigenesis and to investigate novel strategies for the prevention and treatment of colorectal cancers with MMR defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human T cell leukemia virus type-1 (HTLV-1) is a human retrovirus that is the causative agent of a malignant T CD4+ cell lymphoproliferation referred to as Adult T cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATLL), as well as several inflammatory disorders with the most problematic being human myelopathy/tropical spastic paraparesis (HAM/TSP). Remarkable, while millions are affected worldwide, there is no effective vaccine or treatment options to prevent ATL or HAM/TSP afflicted individuals. We thus aim here, to develop a candidate vaccine to prevent and plausibly treat HTLV1-associated disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HEV is a leading cause of acute hepatitis worldwide and is able to persist in immunocompromised patients re- sulting in increased risk of severe liver diseases. The project will investigate the role of the viral ORF3 protein in the virus envelopment and exit in polarized hepatocyte culture and in a rat model. The study will provide novel insight into the mechanism of HEV infection and pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Eastern Nigeria Research Ethics Training (ENRICH) Program Project Narrative  The Eastern Nigeria Research Ethics Training (ENRICH) Program is a collaborative research ethics training program to be implemented jointly by the University of Nigeria, Nsukka (UNN), NIH/FIC-funded Center for Bioethics and Research (CBR) and University of Maryland School of Medicine (UMSOM). The program will provide 40 master's degrees, two hundred short- and twenty-five medium-term trainings in research ethics training to faculty members, members of ethics committees and individuals who are identified as potential leaders in bioethics by their institutions in eastern Nigeria.

PHR: Little is known how HIV affects the brain in the era of combination antiretroviral therapy, and how drug abuse, including cocaine and opiates, could be detrimental to the HIV infected brain. Our project, using human tissues from the Manhattan HIV Brain Bank, will explore gene expression programs in single brain cells and neural circuits of the HIV infected brain in the context of opiate or cocaine abuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Enhancer-promoter interactions are fundamental regulatory elements warranting time and space-specific transcription regulation. This research proposal will (1) establish an experimental platform to study the dynamics of enhancer-promoter interactions and to perform mechanistic and functional studies in a prototype gene during neuronal differentiation. Then, (2) generalize genome-wide the mechanistic results.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Abnormal lipid metabolisms are often associated with inappropriate activation of immune cells such as macrophages, leading to a disease called atherosclerosis. Atherosclerosis is the most common cause of death and this project seeks to identify and characterize the mechanisms that link aberrant lipid metabolisms to atherosclerosis. Identification of the novel molecular mechanisms offers new sites of therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project narrative: The goal of this project is to develop a chemical strategy to measure the labile iron pool in vivo with PET. Building on our preliminary data with 18F-TRX, a first in class, Fe(II) activated radiotracer, we will synthesize and evaluate in vitro and in vivo a series of Fe(II) activated transcyclooctene and 18F-tetrazine click partners that we expect to improve measurements of LIP by reducing the background signal from unreacted TRX and/or more completely reacting with high LIP levels in diseased tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative African American women living in the United States experience an undue higher burden of cervical cancer and a >2 times higher mortality rate than European American women. The resident microbiome has been implicated as important in the progression of many cancers but its role in cervical cancer is unclear. In this project we will study how the microbiome in African American women affects host immunity and the progression of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Human papillomavirus (HPV) causes enormous morbidity, yet despite a safe and effective HPV vaccine, adolescent HPV vaccination rates are low due to parental vaccine hesitancy, suboptimal clinician communication, and ineffective procedures within primary care practices. We have developed two potentially scalable implementation strategies to raise vaccination rates: one trains clinicians on optimal HPV vaccine communication while the other adds practice-based changes in HPV vaccine workflow processes; both have been found to be effective on a limited scale. We are partnering with 8 health systems and 72 practices to compare the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of the two implementation strategies and to assess provider, practice, and health system factors relevant to their implementation; the ultimate goal is to develop two nationally scalable implementation strategies to raise HPV vaccination rates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality globally, and up to 50% of vascular procedures such as balloon angioplasty, stenting, and surgical bypass to treat cardiovascular disease fail due to restenosis from neointimal hyperplasia in the treated artery. There is a critical unmet need to develop novel therapies which reduce restenosis susceptibility and to understand their underlying mechanisms. This proposal seeks to establish a novel pathway linking prebiotic fiber, butyrate from microbial fermentation of fiber, activation of free fatty acid receptor 3 in peripheral arteries, and the arterial remodeling response that could be used to develop new diagnostic and therapeutic approaches for patients undergoing vascular surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Binge drinking accounts for the majority of alcohol consumed by adolescents in the US and occurs during a critical period of brain development. It is also associated with lasting cognitive impairment and increased likelihood of developing an alcohol use disorder later in life. This research is relevant to the NIH/NIAAA mission because it represents an innovative strategy centered on astrocyte-neuron interactions that will expand our understanding of the long-term effects of adolescent binge drinking and the contribution of non-neuronal cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: Photodynamic therapy (PDT), in combination with surgery, offers a potential locally curative treatment and has been demonstrated in clinical trials, including in malignant mesothelioma, to substantially prolong patient survival. In this translational project we will optimize singlet oxygen dosimetry instruments for direct quantitative measurements of the major cytotoxic agent (excited-state singlet oxygen) generated in PDT, which could significantly improve the accuracy and hence efficacy of this modality, both for this particular clinical application and more generally in other tumor sites. Being fiberoptic based, the technology will be suitable for implementation in any tumor site that is accessible to PDT (interstitial, endoscopic, intraoperative).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Green space or trees and natural vegetation can provide mental health benefits and possibly lower risk of neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD); however, green space is often measured poorly in epidemiologic research. I propose to integrate high-resolution images from Google Street Views to derive ground-level objective measurements of green space into a diverse prospective cohort study using deep learning algorithms, mediation analysis and geographic mixtures. This research will enable unprecedented perspectives on exposures that drive ADRD and related cognitive decline risk, and will provide translational insights into potential interventions to optimize opportunities for ADRD prevention and reduce racial disparities in ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Broadly neutralizing antibodies delivered in ‘IgG form’ with recombinant adeno-associated virus (AAV) can mediate protection against HIV/SHIV acquisition in animal models. However, little is known about alternative immunoglobulin types such as IgA and IgM, and/or the amounts of AAV-delivered antibodies that are able to reach the main viral entry points: the rectal and vaginal mucosa. In this project we will tackle these key matters and assess 1) mucosal levels, and 2) protection that can be afforded by different immunoglobulin types, when delivered with AAV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The oxysterol 25-Hydroxycholesterol (25HC) controls a major branch of immune cell function and drives essential biological processes including B-cell migration, inflammasome activation, viral suppression, and inhibition of bacterial pathogens. This proposal examines the anti-bacterial mechanism of 25HC, with a specific focus on determining how oxysterols prevent bacterial interactions with host membranes through alterations in the levels of a specific pool of cell surface cholesterol, termed “accessible cholesterol”. A deeper understanding of the biochemical and cellular mechanisms of 25HC revealed by this work will lead to a greater understanding of the innate and adaptive immune responses that controls human infectious disease and will reveal new therapeutic opportunities promoting resolution of acute bacterial infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite the well-known risk of noise exposure and the rich literature concerning the benefits of musical training, the risk-benefit interplay has gone largely uninvestigated. The objective of the current work is to investigate how musical training and noise exposure interact to influence age-related declines to auditory brain function. The outcomes of this work may suggest new approaches to promote healthy aging and clinical recommendations about harnessing the therapeutic properties of music training to maximize benefits and minimize hazards.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative There is an urgent need to develop prevention options to halt the progression of oral premalignant lesions (OPL) into head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC). We recently conducted a Phase IIa trial in individuals with OPL to explore the potential of metformin to prevent oral cancer (M4OC-Prevent trial; NCT02581137), which represented the first study evaluating the chemopreventive potential of metformin in OPL, and achieved a histologic response rate of 60%. By leveraging the wealth of clinical and genetic information and tissue and body fluid resources from this trial with our expertise in decoding cancer promoting pathways, the long-term goal of our project is to define mechanism-based biomarkers predicting a response to metformin and suitable therapeutic options to overcome drug resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Circadian pathway controls several of the body functions including how organs response and recover from injury. Chronic alcohol ingestion is associated with circadian pathway dysfunction while also dramatically increases the risk of severe lung injury and disrepair, leading to scar formation following an injury. Understanding the mechanisms by which alcohol disrupts circadian pathway and provokes disrepair could identify preventative or therapeutic interventions that promote healthy lung repair following injury.

PHR: Project Narrative: In this proposal, we will investigate how the old bone marrow environment influences the heterogeneous expansion of stem and progenitor cells. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although progress has been made in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC), the mainstays of treatment continue to be surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy -- unfortunately, most patients have poor prognoses, with spread to lymph nodes and poor responses to treatment representing two of the most common reasons patients die from this disease. We recently found that some tumors cells are in an unusual transcriptional state called the “hybrid epithelial-mesenchymal” (hybrid-EM) state, and these hybrid-EM cells are primarily responsible for invasion and metastasis in HNSCC. Our initial forays investigating how this state is regulated revealed that the genes involved in producing cholesterol also play a role in HNSCC invasion, and we therefore propose to 1) test drugs targeting cholesterol pathways in sophisticated models, 2) find other cholesterol genes that could be targeted to treat HNSCC, and 3) apply the same strategy that we used to identify the cholesterol pathway to find other pathways important in invasion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Dietary restriction (DR) represents one of the most effective means to extend lifespan in all tested organisms, including mammals. DR also improves health-span and reduces the risk of various age-dependent diseases including neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Our work will lead to a better understanding of how DR promotes longevity and its regulation by the chemosensory system, and how it reduces the risk of age-dependent neurodegenerative diseases such as AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Immune responses are drastically impacted by the environmental context in which they occur. Here we aim to elucidate the impact of lung tumor-specific dysfunction of tumor-reactive CD8+ T cell populations and elucidate which immunological mechanisms contribute to their induction. Determining factors of differential T cell activation will enable the generation of rational and novel immune-modulatory agents for cancer immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Public Health Relevance / Project Narrative G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are some of the most important and scrutinized drug targets, largely because of their direct and broad involvement in human physiological processes, and their pharmacological malleability. The primary goal of this project is to analyze GPCRs and their complexes with several G-proteins in order to uncover the spatiotemporal determinants of G protein coupling by developing an innovative toolkit combining Molecular Dynamics simulations with system biology approaches such as Bayesian Network modeling. Using this system agonistic toolkit we will identify (i) the time correlated concerted motions in residue clusters that are critical to GPCR activation, (ii) residue pairs involved in allosteric communication from the ligand binding site to the G protein coupling site, and (iii) residue pairs in the GPCR:G protein interfaces that contribute to the G protein coupling strength and selectivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Heart attacks occur when either a coronary blockage grows to large or when a small blockage “breaks” causing a blot clot to form, and since these potentially deadly plaques are small, often the heart attack or stroke occurs without any warning or prior symptoms. Currently, we have very few tools try to make a weak plaque stronger, so we want to identify the role of a particular set of proteins that play a major role in determining both the size and strength of a coronary plaque. Our evidence suggests that a currently available, FDA approved drug may meet this goal; therefore the goal of this study will be to clearly identify how this target changes disease progression and test the drug in a large animal model of coronary disease to pave the way for use in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) is a non-invasive method for clinical brain stimulation that can treat psychiatric disorders. However, the mechanism by which rTMS modulates activity in cortical circuits is poorly understood. This project will determine how rTMS modulates the activity of excitatory and inhibitory cell types in the brain, paving the way for more effective treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Although clinical and experimental studies demonstrate olfactory dysfunction (OD) after traumatic brain injury (TBI), the underlying mechanisms and treatment remain elusive. The aim of our research is to investigate the inflammatory mechanisms underlying OD in a well-established controlled cortical impact mouse TBI model in order to allow future development of early and accurate diagnosis of TBI predisposing to dementia. Elucidating the underlying mechanisms of OD after TBI might be necessary not only to understanding the nature of neurodegeneration but also to developing disease management strategies for treatment and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Directed evolution exploits the seemingly boundless sequence space available to Nature’s catalytic machinery to repurpose enzymes for new-to-nature chemical transformations. The proposed research will harness the evolvability of cytochrome P450 enzymes to expand the activity domain of biocatalysis to include chemo- and enantioselective functionalizations of N-heterocycles. This research will contribute to our fundamental understanding of enzyme catalysis and evolution and will expedite drug discovery by providing an enzyme-controlled chemodivergent platform for the sustainable synthesis of pharmaceutically privileged motifs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ε4 variant of apolipoprotein E (APOE4) is the strongest and most common genetic risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease, but the underlying reason for this risk remains unclear. APOE4 is also a risk factor for heart disease, and is known to cause fatty plaque build-up in blood vessels, as well as impair blood flow. We propose that impaired blood flow and blood vessel movement caused by APOE4 can affect sleep and interfere with the clearance of waste products from the brain, promoting the brain cell death that causes Alzheimer’s disease. To test this idea, we will measure changes in brain blood vessel size, monitor sleep stages and quality, and assess levels of brain inflammation and cellular waste in a mouse carrying the human APOE4 gene. This study will also test the effects of exercise on these processes, and determine whether exercise can correct the overall changes caused by APOE4.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE  Fibromyalgia affects millions of Americans every day, reducing their quality of life, capacity to work and ability to care for themselves, making it a significant public health problem. The goal of this project is to determine the effectiveness and safety of metformin in treating pain, mood and cognitive symptoms of fibromyalgia, and identify the underlying mechanism for its actions. Understanding these pathways is a critical step in developing non-addictive pain treatments and has enormous potential to reduce the harm from chronic opioid use.

PHR: Narrative Although direct acting antivirals can cure Hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection, a vaccine is necessary to stop new infections, and re-infections in cured individuals. PHR: The purpose of this study is to test the novel hypothesis that glia-specific purinergic receptor P2RX7 mediate the secretion of small extracellular vesicles for mediating the spread of tau pathology from cells to cells. Here we propose to validate our exciting preliminary study with genetically targeted mouse model of P2RX7 by neuropathology, behavioral testing, and in vitro cell models. We will also determine which cell types are responsible for the P2RX7-mediated disease spread in this study, which would have direct translational implication for the prevention or treatment of Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Blockade of CD154 is a highly effective method of inducing transplantation tolerance (a state in which transplant recipients would no longer require toxic immunosuppression), however clinical translation of CD154 blockers has met with many challenges, and as an alternative reagents that block CD40 (the receptor for CD154) are now in the clinical pipeline. However, CD40 blockers are not as effective as CD154 blockers, and here we have identified a novel molecular interaction that explains this discrepancy. Mechanistic understanding of this new molecular interaction is of the utmost importance in order to devise innovative strategies to block these residual interactions and thus optimize the use of CD40 blockers in the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Findings from this study may ultimately enable providers in pediatric oncology to discern, via simple pen-and- paper screening, information about a child's immune response to stress and related risk for psychosocial or neurocognitive deficits linked to impairment in emotion regulation. In this way, both psychosocial interventions targeted at improving emotion regulation or neurocognition could be combined with immune-targeted pharmacological interventions in a true model of child-centered precision medicine. Given that eventual long- term survivorship is anticipated for more than 85% of pediatric oncology patients, understanding the nature and long-term psychological and biological impact of stress in pediatric cancer is critical for enabling maximal quality of life into young adulthood and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) is a chronic condition involving aberrant immune responses and recurring inflammation in the intestine and throughout the body. Patients with IBD are at risk for cardiovascular diseases, and, for unknown reasons, their mesenteric arteries do not properly regulate blood flow to the gut. The purpose of our project is to study how the perivascular nerves, immune cells, and adipose tissue around these arteries interact to regulate blood vessel function in health vs. IBD to identify new targets for the treatment of this debilitating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Anorexia nervosa is a deadly psychiatric illness defined by low body weight and associated with changes to many physiological systems in the body. This project will compare immune function and gut microbiome composition in a sample of female outpatients with anorexia nervosa and healthy comparison participants, and establish whether any differences are related to eating disorder symptoms. This basic knowledge will provide the required foundation to evaluate and interpret immune and gastrointestinal physiology in this clinical cohort, a required first step towards development of innovative, personalized treatments targeting these systems in anorexia nervosa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Poor metabolic health and reduced activity is prevalent in older humans, especially with expanded longevity. Using mouse models, we discovered a small cluster of neurons in the brain that control a sex- dependent ancillary activity circuit in females. We aim to leverage our findings to understand age-related metabolic decline commonly experienced by postmenopausal women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: AG BELL ASSN FOR DEAF & HARD OF HEARING
PHR: The effects of hearing loss and deafness is a global health issue that knows no borders – over 466 million people are affected by hearing loss and 34 million of them are children. Lack of information and resources prove to be the main obstacles toward their success in developing language, and among those who most need the information on advances in hearing health research and therapy are professionals in Listening and Spoken Language. The AG Bell Global Symposium ensures that these professionals have the latest information on research that is changing deafness across the globe.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Despite improvements in early diagnosis and treatment, ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) remains a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in the US, and patients with STEMI are at significantly increased risk for developing heart failure. Numerous studies have identified inflammation as a risk factor for heart failure, and in phase II clinical trials, Interleukin-1 (IL-1) blockade has shown to blunt the acute inflammatory response and prevent heart failure in patients with STEMI. This application will evaluate the mechanism by which targeted IL-1 blockade may preserve cardiorespiratory fitness and cardiac reserve, and prevent the incidence of new-onset heart failure in patients with STEMI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative – Public Health Relevance Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) is caused by atherosclerosis in the legs where blood flow is restricted. The central focus of PAD research for decades has been to understand and alter endothelial cell biology, yet no progress has been made towards effective therapeutic design. We will combine our use of innovative mouse genetic models, established PAD relevant laboratory models, innovative tools (gene therapy designed expression viruses), and a heterogeneous PAD patient population to fully interrogate the role of BAG3 as both a potential cause of pathology (in the case of the variants pre-disposing African Americans to severe disease outcomes) and as a potential target for therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The Syracuse University-Summer Training in Alcohol Research (SU-STAR) program aims to address the persistent imbalanced engagement of racial/ethnic minorities and individuals with socioeconomic disadvantages and disabilities in science, especially in health-related sciences. The proposed program will help meet the nation's need for a diverse pool of talented scientists by enhancing underrepresented undergraduate students' participation in alcohol and health research and facilitating their admission into graduate school. Ultimately, the SU-STAR program will expand a pipeline of diverse graduate students in health research, strengthening alcohol science incorporating diverse perspectives and life experiences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The U.S. is one of just three industrialized countries that does not have a federal paid sick leave (PSL) mandate and many employees do not have access to PSL, states and localities have adopted PSL mandates given the federal void. Work commitments and the prospect of lost wages are factors contributing to delays in seeking medical care, including mental healthcare treatment, both for employees and for their dependents (e.g., children and partners). This project will provide the first causal estimates of the effect of state and local PSL mandates on access to PSL among those with mental health disorder, use of mental healthcare, and indicators of potential quality of mental healthcare received, and will examine how community-level factors (e.g., mental healthcare workforce and socioeconomic status) mediate PSL mandate impacts.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 800,000 Americans experience a stroke each year, with a resultant cost of care estimated in the hundreds of millions of dollars. Restoring fully independent gait function is a common goal following a stroke, but gait instability and a high risk of falls often limit functional mobility, causing a decrease in quality of life. This project will investigate the use of novel methods of perturbation training to improve post-stroke gait instability, with the potential to serve as the basis for the development of novel gait rehabilitation techniques able to increase the quality of life for thousands of stroke survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

Potential biological and genetic factors that may modify and/or mediate these associations will also be examined.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study is focused on the topic of postmenopausal shifts in follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) and how FSH relates to obesity development and breast cancer risk. The results will provide insight into obesity-breast cancer mechanisms and will enhance our ability to target preventive therapies. Based on study results, hormone-related medications on the market or in development can be tested specifically for breast cancer prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE  Delayed identification of infant head malformation is causing unnecessary medical complications and societal costs, partly because of the absence of tools available to pediatric offices. For this Fast-track SBIR proposal, PediaMetrix Inc. has joined forces with clinical institutions to develop and evaluate a 3D mobile scanning tool that provides cranial volume and malformation measurements. Our tool, called SoftSpotTM, will improve the early detection and management of infant cranial malformations at the point-of-care and avoid delayed, costly and intensive treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative: We will study the role of glycinergic inhibition from the medial nucleus of the trapezoid body in sound localization processing performed by the medial and lateral superior olive. The proposed aims will optogenetically manipulate this inhibitory projection while assessing the effects on sound localization, allowing us to discriminate between several models that have been proposed. A better understanding of these mechanisms in normal hearing may lead to a better understanding of common hearing disorders that affect spatial hearing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The burden of HIV/AIDS falls hardest on people who inject or use drugs, who are often among a nation’s poorest, most disempowered and stigmatized populations. To date, there is a paucity of well-qualified scientists with the unique investigative skills required to inform research ethics decision-making to adequately protect the rights and welfare of these vulnerable populations. Through its intensive summer training program, funded mentored research experience, and public online resources, the Fordham University HIV and Drug Abuse Prevention Research Ethics Training Institute will provide early-stage clinical scientists with the competencies to address the global need for empirical and educational resources to inform research ethics practices and policies involving persons with or at-risk for HIV and drug addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is to continue the ongoing Monitoring the Future (MTF) Panel study, which has surveyed new nationally representative samples of high school seniors every year since 1976 to track patterns and consequences of substance use and HIV/AIDS risk and protective behaviors. This application covers five new longitudinal data collections in 2023 through 2027 from national samples of adults ages 19 through 65 (approximately 120,000 people total). This application – the MTF Panel – is part of the integrated MTF study; a companion R01 application (the MTF Main) requests funding to continue (a) to collect annual nationally representative cross-sectional data from secondary school students, and (b) to analyze all cross-sectional and longitudinal data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Glioblastoma and tumor-related epilepsy are a pair of intimately connected neurological diseases with no curative or effective treatments available despite decades worth of preclinical and clinical research. Unlike previous studies that relied on tumor xenografts, we use a novel genetically induced, native mouse tumor model that recapitulates many hallmarks of the human disease progression, and that allows us to study the disease in vivo in an immunocompetent model organism. Here we propose to study the feedback loop of tumor invasion and neural hyperexcitability and explore potential interventions by mitigating the effects of excess glutamate or silencing focal groups of neurons to slow down tumor growth and reduce risk of epilepsy and other neurological comorbidities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project will contribute to knowledge about the relationships between staffing levels of registered nurses (RNs), licensed practical nurses (LPNs), certified nurse assistants (CNAs), physical therapists, occupational therapists, speech-language pathologists (i.e. speech therapists), and social workers, and several outcomes for residents in nursing homes, including deficiencies. It will provide information for both nursing homes that treat large populations of residents with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) and nursing homes with few residents with ADRD. This information will enhance the ability of policy makers at all levels to plan and develop policies that will improve workforce planning and allocation and ultimately will improve outcomes for residents with ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This study aims to use Deep Learning to simultaneously accelerate knee MRI acquisition and automate post processing pipelines including multi tissue segmentation, detection and severity staging of osteoarthritis degenerative changes. The proposed study builds a novel translational platform to revolutionize knee MR images in research studies, but also is paradigm-shifting in that it may provide a first step towards on real time automatic image inspection and personalized imaging protocolling.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Infants born to opioid-dependent mothers living in poverty are at risk for a host of developmental problems, but effects can be buffered if mothers interact with their children in sensitive ways. This project assesses the efficacy of an intervention that targets parental sensitivity and is tailored to the needs of opioid-dependent infants. Effects are expected to be seen on maternal sensitivity and neural activity and on infant behavioral and biological outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will explore barriers and facilitators to participation in the Parent Infant Interac(X)tion Intervention (PIXI), a virtual parent-mediated intervention for caregivers of infants with neurogenetic conditions, among traditionally marginalized communities (e.g., Black/African American; Hispanic). Through frequent engagement with a targeted community advisory board and strategic interviewing strategies, this study will first gather formative, detailed information about challenges in virtual intervention implementation in these populations, leading to critical procedural changes to be implemented in a pilot of PIXI specifically with these groups. This work will gather important formative information to ensure that the PIXI protocol is developed in a way that maximizes access for diverse populations of individuals with infants identified to have rare neurogenetic conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tobacco use is the leading cause of preventable and premature disease, disability, and death among Americans; its effects unequally burden the health of minoritized and marginalized groups who have more difficulty quitting. The STRONGER Scholar Program at MD Anderson will prepare the next generation of clinicians to understand, conduct, and evaluate innovative tobacco addictions research to meet the critical need for improved tobacco cessation care provision, particularly with groups adversely affected by tobacco disparities. The STRONGER Scholar Program will educate 16 doctoral students in clinically-focused training programs (psychology and social work) and 35 medical students to conduct tobacco addictions research and apply findings within clinical care provision; contributing to NIDA’s Racial Equity Initiative to increase racial/ethnic diversity in addictions research to better address associated health inequities, and aligning with its strategic plan and cross-cutting scientific priorities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Mayo Clinic Stimulating Access to Research in Residency (StARR) program achieved substantial success in its inaugural round with eight resident-investigators completing or currently active in research training. The program—both in model design, operation, and outcomes—has made important strides in supporting heart (and vascular), lung, hematologic (blood), and sleep (HLBS) disorders/diseases research training and career development, building a solid and sustainable research career pipeline. In our next cycle, we will continue to enhance the Mayo Clinic StARR program by extending opportunities to residents in Laboratory Medicine and Pathology and adding experienced preceptors from the same department, and by invigorating recruitment and training to residents from diverse backgrounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Colorectal cancer (CRC) mortality is markedly higher in African-American patients than any other racial or ethnic group. This proposal aims to understand how tumor metabolites and microbiome differ between racial/ethnic populations, how socioeconomic status effects this association, and potentially impacts patient outcomes. The long-term goals of this research are to determine microbiome and metabolic differences between patients with CRC that can be exploited to improve treatment and reduce mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic infection with hepatitis B virus (HBV) presents a global public health burden affecting 296 million individuals worldwide, who are at high risk of developing severe liver diseases, including cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma. Our proposed research seeks to explore the distinct functions of the HBV PreCore- derived proteins in modulating the outcome of HBV infection, as well as to identify their associated host factors and dynamic changes related to infection outcome and antiviral treatment. Our project will characterize new virus-host interactions linked to viral persistence and their use as a potential biomarker predicting HBV infection and treatment outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Psychiatric disorders comprise a spectrum of mental health problems with multiple factors contributing to risk including nutrition and environmental exposures. This would be the first US epidemiological study to examine the joint associations between prenatal exposure to maternal nutrition and metals in the expression of early childhood psychiatric outcomes, specifically internalizing problems (anxiety and depressive symptoms, behavioral inhibition). As nutrition is a highly mendable factor in human health, understanding the independent and modifying effects of nutrients in the relationship between heavy metal exposures and psychiatric outcomes is arguably critical to informing early intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative A challenge in targeting the neurologic drugs to the brain is the presence of the blood-brain barrier (BBB), a dynamic structure that prevents neurotoxic blood particles and pathogens from entering the brain while simultaneously regulating bidirectional transport of nutrients and waste products. Here we seek to understanding the biological rhythms of the blood-brain barrier by establishing a human blood-brain barrier culture containing a circadian rhythm reporter. We then intend to use this model to understand the influence of inflammation on BBB rhythms and determine the timing of endogenous blood serum particles under normal and inflammatory conditions.
