IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infectious diseases continue to have a major impact on global health and clinician-investigators play an important role in addressing infectious diseases through research whose findings can advance the development of new diagnostic, treatment, and prevention strategies. The goal of the University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB) StARR Program is to recruit, train, and accelerate the research independence of UAB resident-investigators through mentored research, training in research methodology, and career development activities. The impact of the program will be generation of a pool of diverse resident- investigators with the knowledge, skills, experience, unique perspectives, and motivation that are all necessary to facilitate transition towards becoming the next generation of highly successful clinician- investigators who combat the burden and challenges of infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to understand in unprecedented detail how medically-important neuromodulators, including serotonin, help generate the dynamic pattern of activity in a neural circuit. Defects in neuromodulator function appear to underlie many human brain diseases, such as mood disorders and Parkinson’s disease, yet it is difficult to understand these diseases because we as yet have little understanding of how neural circuits work. By deeply studying one neural circuit in the simple model organism C. elegans that uses the same types of neuromodulators found in the human brain, we hope to spearhead a new level of understanding of neural circuit activity that will advance our understanding of neuromodulators and their roles in brain disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Effective programs for swimming and water-safety instruction for autistic children are not currently available and tremendous variability among types and techniques of swim instruction exists. This project will compare the effects of a specialized swimming and water-safety program for autistic children (Sensory Enhanced Aquatics-SEA) to standard swimming lessons, examine characteristics of instruction associated with skill attainment, and explore child, parent, and instructor perspectives about instructional methods most effective for developing swimming and water-safety among autistic children. If the project is successful, it will increase knowledge of best practice swim instruction for autistic children to potentially reduce the high risk of drowning in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE There are two primary objectives in the current proposal that remain key to understanding peripheral fatty acid signaling in the taste system and, in general, the roles of various taste cell types. The first deals with the mechanistic underpinnings of Type II and Type III cells in the transduction of two classes of fatty acids – the long chain polyunsaturated fatty acids and the medium chain saturated fatty acids. The second expands from earlier research showing pronounced sex differences in fatty acid signaling and fat taste and attempts to use cell-based assays to explore the details of these differences within these cell types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  On average 20-30 babies born each day in the United States are born deaf or hard of hearing, where genetic causes are not always fully understood. In order to target treatments and provide better therapies, we need to understand how the auditory system functions and how these genetic mutations cause dysfunction in the system. I will apply state-of-the-art technology to investigate mechanisms related to mechanotransduction, a key step in converting sound vibrations into electrical signals sent to the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Somatic hypermutation (SHM) is essential for B cells to evolve high-affinity antibodies against pathogens and vaccine immunogens and deficit SHM is associated with human immunodeficiencies. We find that Uracil-DNA glycosylase (UNG) mutants unable to interact with replication protein A (RPA) impair mutation events in vitro. The goal of this application is to develop a mouse model to understand the mechanistic contribution of RPA- UNG interaction to SHM in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative As growing millions of older adults with frailty, Alzheimer’s Disease and related dementias, multimorbidity and serious illness undergo surgery, significant knowledge gaps remain as how to best care for them and achieve optimal outcomes. Rigorous research training is required to prepare the next generation of surgeon-scientists to take on the clinical, research, and policy challenges ahead, however there are no training programs specifically designed to give surgical residents, including those from under-represented minority groups, necessary skills to conduct high-quality research related to fundamental questions in surgery and aging. We propose the Mentored Research Training in Aging and Surgery (MERITAS) Program based at the Center for Surgery and Public Health (CSPH) at Brigham and Women’s Hospital (BWH) to provide two dedicated years of mentorship and skill development conducting health services research at the intersection of surgery and launch a community of 8 diverse surgeons for productive research careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a dire need to systematically develop, refine, and examine for efficacy promising behavioral interventions that can be easily disseminated to aging adults at-risk for AD and related dementias. The research proposed in the current application will systematically develop and test the feasibility of an internet-based, asynchronous, mindfulness program (iMBSR) with a matched control group for adults with subjective cognitive decline. This Stage I study, yielding estimates on successful recruitment, adherence, adverse events, overall acceptability, and effect sizes for mind-wandering, and plasma-based AD biomarkers of Aβ and tau will provide important foundational data for future efficacy trials of the iMBSR program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The “Purposeful Outreach for Diversity and Inclusion of Underrepresented in Medicine (PODIUM) Physician- Scientists” T32 training program will provide advanced research training in heart, lung, blood and sleep (HLBS) disorders to underrepresented in medicine (URM) postdoctoral trainees from established, senior investigators at Einstein-Montefiore. The PODIUM leadership team will implement an individualized curriculum for each trainee with structured classwork, seminars and workshops to supplement the hands-on research with mentors and transition to academic careers. The ultimate goal of the PODIUM T32 program is to provide the next generation of URM investigators with the state-of-the art experiences and skills required to initiate and sustain successful independent careers in HLBS research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bone disorders resulting from bacterial infection are associated with severe inflammation and bone loss, but the mechanisms regulating such damage are poorly understood. While type I interferons are increasingly recognized to impact host susceptibility to bacterial pathogens and have been shown to affect bone homeostasis, their role in staphylococcal bone infections has not been examined. In this pilot study, we will begin to determine whether type I interferons serve a protective role in bone infections by limiting the ability of bacteria to survive in local cells and/or by reducing the number and activity of bone resorbing cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative After an initial minor stroke, the risk of another stroke occurring is high, particularly in the first days and weeks, and then falls to a lower rate that is steady over time. This change over time in rates of recurrence of stroke can be understood as a transition after stroke from a vulnerable state to a stabilized state, with the different mechanisms of stroke in the two states potentially targeted by different preventative medicines. Combining large data sets from clinical trials that have included patients starting immediately after the initial stroke will provide the opportunity to detect which risk factors or medications affect each of the distinct rates that determine stroke recurrences over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: Component A: Core Surveillance Project Narrative The New York City Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System will provide population-based surveillance data of high scientific quality on maternal attitudes, experiences, and behaviors before and during pregnancy as well as early infancy. These data are not available from any other source and thus are important for developing and evaluating programs and policies aimed at improving maternal and infant health in New York City. The data will also serve to monitor progress towards select national Healthy People 2030 indicators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Tuberculosis (TB), caused by the human pathogen Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb), is the second leading infectious disease killer in the world. Despite this global importance and an increasingly drug-resistant Mtb, new approaches to diagnosis and treatment are limited by a lack of human experimental systems to identify key determinants of the outcome of infection. Here, we introduce and necessarily employ a tissue engineered biomimetic model of human TB granuloma for the identification and testing of new therapeutics for the control of human TB.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: RELEVANCE DDX RNA helicases or ATPases are involved in virtually every RNA metabolism step, from ribosome biogenesis to transcription, RNA maturation, microRNA processing, translation, and RNA degradation. This project will unravel the underlying mechanisms of the nucleolar specific RNA helicase DDX18 in controlling nucleolar integrity for pluripotency of human embryonic stem cells, establishing a novel paradigm for cell fate control and providing insights into developing therapeutics targeting the nucleolar dysfunction in human diseases such as ribosomopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will profile and define the antiviral potential of transfer RNA fragments made during gammaherpesvirus infection. This work will establish transfer RNA fragment functionality during gammaherpesvirus infection and the antiviral response, while also contributing a widely-applicable and innovative sequencing strategy to accurately profile transfer RNA fragment expression. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to part of NIAID’s mission that pertains to enhancing our understanding and treating infectious disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Co-occurring small vessel disease (SVD) in the brain accelerates the progression of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Older women have a greater SVD-related AD risk. In this study, using state-of-the-art MR imaging, we will test whether women have faster progression of SVD than men. We also evaluate the treatment effects of Equol, an oral supplement, on brain SVD. Targeting SVD with an intervention is particularly promising for reducing AD risk in women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative We seek to reveal sex differences in an engineered microfluidic cardiac hypertrophy-on-a-chip platform populated with sex-specific cardiac cells. It is hypothesized that there exist critical differences between sexes in the development of biomechanically induced and/or biochemically induced cardiac hypertrophy in the biomimetic on-chip platform. Sex as an important biological variable in heart-on-a-chip systems has not been investigated so far and we envision our high-risk, high-reward bold new method project to lay down the basis for future in-depth studies on this indispensable but highly underrepresented parameter.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Fuchs’ dystrophy is characterized by the destruction of the corneal endothelium due to genetic defects and is currently treatable only by corneal transplantation. As there are currently no models to study this disease, we will develop animal models of late-onset Fuchs’ dystrophy (the most common form). These animal models will enable research into the causes and treatments for late-onset Fuchs’ dystrophy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative After mating, when sperm enter the uterus, they are attacked by the female’s immune system but a few move quickly into the oviduct where they survive for a longer period and form a storage reservoir. Their enhanced survival in the oviduct is partly because they do not trigger a phagocytic response. We have discovered that sperm have sugars on their surface that bind to receptors in the oviduct and we will determine if this system helps retain sperm in the reservoir and dampen the phagocytic response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Public Health Relevance) Oxidative stress (OxS) is a biochemical process that leads to damage of cellular lipids and is associated with the pathophysiology of aging and numerous human diseases, including cardiovascular disease, neurodegeneration, frailty, and SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19). We propose to study how certain oxidized lipids are broken down in the body. Establishing precise methods to ensure the complete quantification of these compounds and their metabolites will help to clarify the role OxS – and potential therapies – in health and human disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Preeclampsia (PE) remains a poorly understood, multiorgan vascular disease that is responsible for the death of up to 50,000 women and 1 million infants per year. Our goal is to determine whether a novel NF-κB variant increases PE risk by enhancing inflammatory cytokine responses of the vascular endothelium that, in turn, impair uteroplacental blood flow. Our study will accelerate the understanding of maternal-fetal genetics and its role in the development of PE and may also identify candidate pathways to direct future functional experiments and potential avenues for therapeutic intervention.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is relevant to public health because it elucidates a fundamental and general property of bacterial spore formation that plays a critical role in causing human disease. These studies are relevant to NIH’s mission to acquire knowledge that is important in the development of new strategies to treat and prevent infections disease. These studies are also important for NIH's national defense mission because they define a critical feature of Bacillus anthracis spores, the causative agent of anthrax and a serious threat as an agent of bioterrorism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emerging evidence indicates that vulnerable groups, such as Native Hawaiian, Pacific Islander, and Filipino (NHPIF) young adults, use e-cigarettes and cannabis at higher rates than other racial/ethnic groups, but past research has not examined co-use. The current phased study will utilize epidemiological data from two sources to guide the development of a Just-in-Time Adaptive Intervention (JITAI) for NHPIF young adults ages 18-30 who co-use e-cigarettes and cannabis. Following pilot work, a randomized controlled trial of the JITAI will examine the impact of the new intervention on frequency of e-cigarette, cannabis, and co-use and related problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative  This proposal will perform RNAseq on blood of a derivation cohort of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) patients to determine those genes that best predict Delayed Cerebral Ischemia (DCI) between 4 and 14 days and that predict median Rankin Scores (mRS) outcomes at 90 days using cross-correlation. These genes are then measured in an independent validation cohort of SAH patients to predict who develops DCI by 14d, and to predict their mRS at 90 days after SAH. The studies will direct early treatment for DCI, identify treatment targets for DCI, and help stratify patients for future DCI treatment trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The airways are lined by dense fields of motile cilia that generate a directional fluid flow that is critical for clearing mucus, pathogens, and debris from the airways. Disruptions in the ciliary apparatus, whether due to a genetic disorder or infective and acquired causes, are directly linked to infection and disease progression. The goal of this study is to better understand how the spatial organization of the airway epithelium regulates airway clearance in diseases characterized by genetic changes in motile cilia. 1

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) frequently have insomnia (trouble falling or staying asleep). Untreated insomnia carries grave health consequences. Early evidence suggests that pimavanserin (Nuplazid), a medication approved by the Food and Drug Administration for the treatment of psychosis (hallucinations and delusions) in Parkinson’s Disease, may treat insomnia. In this preliminary study, Veterans with insomnia and PTSD will receive either pimavanserin 34mg or placebo at bedtime for 8 weeks, and sleep quality will be compared pre- and post-treatment. Veterans will also complete sleep studies and wear actigraphy watches so we may better appreciate how pimavanserin impacts sleep. Overall, this study will help us understand pimavanserin’s potential benefit for treating PTSD-related insomnia and prepare for a larger, future trial.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This VA Merit Review Application is highly relevant to the health of Veterans, as it seeks to develop novel biomarkers to improve risk stratification of Veterans with significant liver disease who have achieved HCV cure. The Department of Veterans Affairs is the single largest hepatitis C virus infection health care provider in the United States. Since the introduction of direct acting antivirals for the treatment of HCV infection in 2014, VA has cured over 100,000 Veterans. Due to the high rate of comorbidities in the veteran population, including HIV co- infection, alcohol use, and obesity and metabolic syndrome, rates of severe liver fibrosis prior to DAA therapy are high and likely to persist despite cure. To date there are no reliable laboratory tests or biomarkers to differentiate patients with the greatest risk of post-SVR decompensation events, HCC, and liver-related death. This is a critical unmet clinical need that is highly relevant to clinicians who care for Veterans cured of their HCV infection, but with significant residual liver disease and/or ongoing liver injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Brain function depends on the integration of multiple neural structures and processes that currently cannot be studied at a whole-brain level in living organisms. To address this problem, we introduce a novel technology called hemogenetic imaging, which will enable the biology of genetically-targeted cells to be comprehensively studied by functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) or related techniques. Here we propose to apply hemo- genetic fMRI to study brain-wide aspects of sensory processing, resting state dynamics, and neurovascular cou- pling. We will also improve the technology itself, setting the stage for many future applications.

PHR: Project narrative: The goal of this project is to understand how MIS protects fertility in mice receiving chemotherapy to inform the development of new therapeutic options for female cancer survivors. These therapies would address a significant unmet medical need, which is rapidly growing as cancer outcomes improve. At the end of these studies we will understand the cell types and cell responses regulated by MIS in the ovary and uterus, and have provided a path to scalability and sustainability for the clinical development of a novel class of fertoprotective drug candidates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Current treatment options for refractory pain are associated with dangerous side effects that stem from their off- target activity. The proposed study leverages recent advances in single-cell genomics to build viral tools that selectively express in the peripheral sensory neurons that detect and transmit pain signals. These new viral tools will facilitate pain research in animal models in multiple species and have the potential to provide analgesia to patients with unprecedented precision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sexual and gender minority (SGM) youth and emerging adults are at high risk of suicide attempts and death by suicide, and no known suicide prevention programs exist for this vulnerable population. The proposed study will adapt and test an intervention that integrates patient navigation with safety planning to prevent suicide. This intervention program for SGM youth and emerging adults is designed to target mechanisms that theoretically underlie suicide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Understanding how the metabolic activity of the gut microbiome contributes to host cardiovascular disease risk through modulation of cholesterol levels has important translational implications. Working with the Framingham Heart Study (FHS) we profiled participant microbiomes, identifying a novel group of cholesterol dehydrogenases that metabolize cholesterol and result in lower serum cholesterol in subjects whose microbiomes encode these enzymes. In this proposal, we will utilize multi-’omics data generation (metagenomics, metabolomics, transcriptomics), cell-based assays, and a state-of-the art gnotobiotic mouse pipeline to functionally identify the gut microbes and enzymes that metabolize cholesterol, corticosteroids, or phytosterols and determine the mechanisms through which cholesterol metabolism impacts cardiovascular health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will interrogate a novel cell population identified in the developing human lung, referred to as Fetal Airway Secretory (FAS) cells, that are marked by SCGB3A2/SFTPB/CFTR. Since nothing is known about FAS cells, and there is no analogous population in the murine lung, the overarching goal of this proposal is to use an in vitro model of FAS differentiation to describe these cells in detail, to interrogate their differentiation potential, and to determine how they are regulated, thereby providing foundational descriptive and mechanistic insights into a new cell type in the human lung.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  South Dakota has one of the highest infant and postneonatal mortality rates in the United States, with large racial disparities. The information obtained from participation in the CDC PRAMS as a Core Surveillance state will provide important information on maternal attitudes and behaviors around the time of pregnancy and help guide maternal and child health programs in the state. Previous participation in the CDC PRAMS has led to significant work and outreach with maternal child health stakeholders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: R&R Other Project Information  Pennsylvania PRAMS Project Component A: Core Surveillance Project Narrative: The Pennsylvania Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PA PRAMS) project collects information on selected maternal behaviors and experiences occurring before, during, and after pregnancy from a monthly random sample of residents with a live birth. The project’s mission is to promote the collection, analysis, and dissemination of population-based data of high scientific quality and to support the use of data to develop policies and programs in order to reduce maternal and infant morbidity and mortality. It is anticipated implementation of the PA PRAMS project over the next five-year period will continue to result in timely, high quality data to monitor prevalence of, and inequities in, maternal health behaviors and experiences.

PROJECT_TITLE: DP21-001 The Pennsylvania Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PA PRAMS) Project

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: PRAMS Project Narrative New Jersey PRAMS is a surveillance system designed to collect data that contributes to the improved health of New Jersey mothers and infants. Information from PRAMS is used to help plan and evaluate health programs such as those focusing on improving access and early prenatal care, reducing smoking during pregnancy and encouraging safe sleep practices. PRAMS provides data that can be used to inform decision making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Implementation science has the potential to transform the delivery of care and improve health equity for heart and lung diseases in real-world settings. This T32 program will provide a diverse group of trainees with the structured mentorship, education, and hands-on training needed to translate the strong evidence base in the prevention and management of heart and lung diseases into effective practice in diverse populations. Unique strengths of the program include 1) a focus on the intersection of implementation science and health equity; 2) exceptional opportunities in didactic and experiential learning; and 3) team-based research mentorship.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project narrative: Cancer-induced cachexia, or cancer cachexia, is a complex metabolic syndrome that significantly increases the morbidity and mortality of cancer patients. However, understanding of the underlying mechanism of cancer cachexia is limited and hence there is no standardized assessment or established treatment. The current project is designed to evaluate whether cancer-released circulating Hsp70 and Hsp90 are biomarkers and therapeutic targets of human cancer cachexia based on previous findings in mouse models of cancer cachexia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Methane gas is a major contributor to climate change, which represents a significant threat to human health. This research program focuses on the chemistry and biology of methanotrophs, methane-consuming bacteria that have the potential to mitigate methane emissions in an environmentally-friendly and productive fashion. In addition, methanotrophs produce copper-binding natural products with promising applications as metal-chelating therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Navigation is an important aspect of our everyday lives, and one of the key brain structures involved in navigation is the retrosplenial cortex, yet we know very little about its function. The proposed research will challenge classical models of retrosplenial cortex computations that support the flexible use of both viewer- centered and world-centered (map-like) representations in remembering and navigating learned spaces. Advancing theories in the cognitive and neural bases of retrosplenial cortex contributions to learning, memory and navigation will provide insight into disease pathologies associated with insult to this brain region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is currently no therapy that can prevent the development of epilepsy after brain trauma. Here we propose to test the efficacy of a novel compound, and determine its efficacy and tolerability in an animal model of posttraumatic epilepsy, in a setting that resembles the clinical practice of care of people with severe traumatic brain injury. We also aim to identify and validate novel biomarkers that can predict who will develop epilepsy and who may respond to a treatment that can prevent epilepsy, in hope that this may accelerate and optimize future efforts to develop new antiepileptogenic therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative The progression of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and related dementias (ADRD) leads to abnormal sleep/activity patterns, associated wandering, and disruptive behaviors in AD/ADRD patients, causing tremendous stress and fatigue to family caregivers that can lead to the patients' institutional placement. Our current R01 shows that both short- and long-term light exposures result in significant improvement in sleep, behavior, and mood, but it remains unknown how the light dose (amount and duration) affects circadian response in AD/ADRD patients. Addressing this dose–response issue will further contribute to the scientific understanding of AD/ADRD while providing a translational component for the development of new lighting products designed to promote sleep and reduce behavioral disturbances in AD/ADRD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Following consumption of a meal, pancreatic beta-cells secrete insulin, a hormone that promotes the uptake and storage of carbohydrates and other nutrients in skeletal muscle while simultaneously repressing glucose efflux from the liver. Diabetes mellitus results from insulin availability that is insufficient to meet tissue needs, and both the type 1 and type 2 forms of the disease are associated with decreased beta-cell mass and insulin production. Herein we propose to test the hypothesis that a family of nutritional byproducts termed ceramides contribute to this decline in beta cell function that drives both forms of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will encourage individuals from diverse backgrounds, especially those that are underrepresented in biomedical science, to pursue careers in biomedical research. Since its inception in 2009, the Michigan Postbaccalaureate Research Education Program (UM PREP) has prepared over 100 scholars to successfully compete for admission to graduate programs across a wide range of disciplines, including, but not limited to Biochemistry, Bioinformatics, Biomedical Engineering, Biophysics, Cancer Biology, Cell Biology, Developmental Biology, Genetics, Immunology, Microbiology, Neuroscience, Pathology, Pharmacology, Physiology, and Neuroscience. In this renewal application, we will continue to enhance our efforts to prepare UM PREP trainees for success in graduate programs so that they can continue to make outstanding contributions as part of a diverse scientific workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a growing global health problem affecting approximately 1.5 million people in the US alone, and is a growing and significant unmet medical concern. Oral agents that are safe and effective for the induction and maintenance of UC remission are in dire need as additional treatment options, and to limit the use of drugs with potentially severe side effects. Thetis plans to investigate TP-317, an innovative and potential first in-class therapeutic agent, as an oral therapy for the induction and maintenance of remission of intestinal inflammation and symptoms in UC patients. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetes accounts for approximately 45% of prevalent ESRD cases in the United States, therefore new interventions to prevent or decelerate development of kidney failure are critical in order to improve the health of patients with diabetes who comprise a large sector of the US population. This study will advance our knowledge regarding the etiology of diabetic kidney complications evaluating specific components of systemic (KRIS) and local, kidney inflammation (Complement). These advances offer long-term potential for the development of new therapies that will ultimately improve clinical outcomes of patients with diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The hippocampus can represent memories, present experiences, and imagined futures, but it remains unclear if subregions of the hippocampus are separately engaged in these representations. The proposed research will specifically test if two subregions are better understood as distinct or coupled networks based on the patterning of spatial representations in each and the correlation structure of the combined network. By uncovering the functional heterogeneity across hippocampal subregions, we will advance our fundamental knowledge of how memories and prospective futures are coordinated with our present experiences.

PHR: Project Narrative The primary objective of this multicenter prospective cohort trial is to effectively evaluate the test performance of novel molecular techniques for the diagnose of congenital syphilis (CS). It is hypothesized that contemporary molecular platforms will result in more sensitive, specific and timely diagnosis of congenital infection with Treponema pallidum compared to the current CDC diagnostic standards. In addition, we plan to leverage the resulting clinical cohort to more accurately define adverse neurodevelopmental outcomes associated with CS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) The availability of new blood-based biomarkers provides an opportunity to investigate the application of “A/T/N biomarker profile” in community-based, observational study, and provide endophenotypes that can be used to identify genetic research. The Washington Heights, Inwood Columbia Aging Project study is one of the few cohorts where these newly-established blood-based biomarkers (Aβ40, Aβ42, total tau, phosporylated-tau217, neurofilament light chain or NFL) and well-established neuroimaging biomarkers for AD can be used to investigate the application of “A/T/N biomarker profile” across race/ethnic groups and by age and sex.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC) is a devastating disease that has increased seven-fold in the past four decades, yet the survival rate remains poor at less than 20%. The established risk factors for EAC and its precursor lesion, Barrett’s esophagus, are highly prevalent in the VA population. Therefore, there is an urgent need to improve current strategies to prevent or treat EAC. Efforts to improve outcomes are limited by inadequate understanding of the mechanisms underlying EAC progression. This proposal aims to improve the lives of Veterans and their families through mechanistic discoveries related to EAC development, which can be leveraged to improve treatment standards for this lethal cancer.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: For suicidal individuals, minimizing future risk and fostering recovery are critical public health concerns, especially among veterans, as very few effective interventions exist. Despite extensive VA resources targeting suicidal Veterans, suicide deaths number twenty daily. This project will conduct a randomized clinical trial in suicidal Veterans of a novel 10-session group psychotherapy treatment that combines emotion regulation skill based, and psychoeducational approaches, with suicide safety planning. The comparison condition is weekly individual safety planning. Assessments will occur at baseline, post treatment, six and twelve months. The primary outcome is suicidal behavior with secondary outcomes of hopelessness, depression and treatment utilization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blood-based biomarkers are urgently needed as alternative outcome measures in DMD. In this study, we seek to define monitoring biomarker signatures for DMD to assess disease course and changes in disease. We will use longitudinal serum samples including clinical data collected from well defined and well annotated cohorts and apply our internally developed and validated quantitative proteomics assays to develop such biomarker signatures. Finally, the signatures developed will be validated in external samples.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women who initiate antiretroviral therapy (ART) during pregnancy in South Africa are at high risk of dropping out of care – particularly after delivery – but efforts to evaluate continuity of HIV care among pregnant and postpartum women have been hampered by lack of a national longitudinal HIV care database. Through this five-year award, we propose to use routinely-collected laboratory data to develop a national cohort of pregnant women living with HIV in South Africa that is uniquely robust to patient transfer. This novel cohort of pregnant women will be a powerful tool available to policymakers, clinicians and researchers for improving our understanding of engagement in care among pregnant women in South Africa and assessing the performance of the South African national ART program in caring for pregnant women living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of this project is to measure articulatory and prosodic sensorimotor adaptation in interactions between a speaker and listener. Our understanding of speech motor control is based on strong evidence of sensorimotor adaptation in articulation and prosody, but thus far only in speech without communicative intent. This project will therefore provide the empirical evidence needed to extend current models of speech motor control to ecologically valid interactions between a speaker and a listener and to inform interventions that use external feedback to bolster impaired articulatory and prosodic control in clinical populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is well known that physical inactivity is linked to poor health and lower quality of life; recent work has shown that how active an individual is during childhood can alter the structure of bones, joints, and muscles in such a way that the capacity for exercise as an adult would be affected. This project explores how growth-period exercise prescription can reverse the effects of inactivity by documenting altered anatomy, function, and ultimately the effects on adult exercise behavior. Fundamental knowledge arising from this work will allow us to optimize musculoskeletal structure and function through targeted physical activity in childhood to enhance lifelong health and mobility.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Aerobic exercise has emerged as an effective treatment to reduce sport-related concussion symptom severity, yet existing work lacks rigor regarding the precise exercise volume and intensity required to elicit therapeutic effects, how exercise can alter concussion-related pathophysiology, and whether exercise can prevent the development of secondary sequelae. Our objective is to examine if a high dose exercise program (higher volume than currently prescribed at an individualized, safe intensity level) initiated within 10 days of concussion results in faster symptom resolution, altered physiological function, or reduced secondary sequalae. Findings from this research will lead to more rigorous and precise rehabilitation guidelines and improved understanding about how exercise affects neurophysiological function among adolescents with concussion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative There is a significant need for large-scale African studies that examine the size and make-up of the latent viral reservoir that exists in HIV-infected individuals on antiretroviral treatment. This project proposes to transfer a newly reported highly accurate reservoir sizing method developed using American populations to measure reservoir size in South African women, and to investigate the role of multiple viral factors in reservoir size and composition. The contribution of viral variants from the blood and cervix to the reservoir will also be explored.

PHR: Relevance of the proposed research to Veterans’ health issues: Many military personnel and Veterans incur joint injuries that can result in development of post-traumatic osteoarthritis (PTOA), and many others develop OA from other etiologies. Success would transform our mechanistic understanding of OA, and identify targets for therapeutics to treat pain and prevent progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of the dopamine system is a tightly regulated process that has great implications on social and reward associated behaviors. Microglia, the resident immune cells of the brain, selectively engulf (phagocytose) dopamine receptors during adolescent development, however, what regulates this microglia function remains unknown. I will investigate the role of dopaminergic signaling in regulating microglial chromatin remodeling and phagocytic function through adolescence impacting social behavior—providing necessary foundational knowledge on microglial development in a key reward associated brain region.

PHR: Obesity and diabetes rates continue to rise, and racial and gender disparities persist. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Osteoarthritis (OA) is an exceptionally common problem among veterans, is associated with a number of other medical conditions, and is a leading cause of disability among veterans. Recent research has demonstrated that the gut and cartilage microbiomes are altered in association with OA. A better understanding of how aging, obesity, and trauma influence these microbiomes may lead to new insights into the causes of OA and give rise to new treatments for OA patients. We will study these microbiome patterns in the context of veterans with OA and in OA animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The α1A-adrenergic receptor subtype has been shown in vivo and in vitro to be expressed in the cognitive centers of the brain, is both cardiac and neuroprotective, and can increase cognitive functions, synaptic plasticity, and long term potentiation. This grant will determine if highly-selective and novel α1A- adrenergic receptor positive allosteric modulators we developed may be improved upon in its in vitro and in vivo pharmacology to ultimately demonstrate its usefulness in ameliorating the cognitive decline and brain function in Alzheimer's Disease without affecting blood pressure. In light of current disappointing clinical trials using anti-amyloid β antibodies, a pharmaceutical approach that can regenerate the brain and/or reverse cognitive decline is urgently needed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Given the increasing health and economic burdens associated with the burgeoning number of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) cases throughout the world, there is an urgent need to develop therapeutic agents that can treat, delay, or prevent the disease. However, development of effective new therapies has been hindered by a lack of the skills and knowledge required to perform scientifically rigorous preclinical drug-screening studies, which are typically carried out using laboratory mice. This proposal aims to address these gaps by developing and delivering a workshop at The Jackson Laboratory, a world-renowned center of expertise in the analysis of mouse models, that will provide participants with hands-on training and lecture instruction that will enable the rigorous design, execution, analysis, and reporting of preclinical experiments that will have potential to bring new AD therapies to the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE The noteworthy similarities and the differences between sound location processing in birds and mammals show there are many ways of localizing sounds and separating sources from background noise; these different strategies can inspire the development of new technologies such as cochlear implants. Current binaural implants work independently, so that the timing of pulses is not synchronized or coordinated between the ears, and much of the fine temporal structure required for effective ITD processing is not preserved. In the broader context, understanding the development of temporal fine structure should reveal common constraints on the development of binaural hearing to guide technological advances.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Indiana Clinical Translational Science Institute is a partnership among Indiana's three research-intensive universities, Indiana University, Purdue University, and the University of Notre Dame, and the Regenstrief Institute, and has a distinguished history of documented success and a robust statewide research, educational, and community infrastructure on which to build its expansion in this new CTSA funding period. We will transform our statewide research ecosystem with deliberate attention to diversity and inclusion and the principles of trustworthiness and community engagement in our partnerships, workforce development and research engagement. We will accelerate innovation and rapidly implement evidence into practice in order to advance health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Although tremendous progress has been made in treatment modalities of acule myelogenous leukemias (AMLs) and myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs), there is the necessity to improve and develop novel therapeutic approaches. We propose to develop a strategy based on gene mutation profiling to identify patients with AMLs and MPNs displaying specific defects in DNA damage repair pathways. These pathways will be then attacked by DNA repair inhibitors combined with already approved drugs in the conditions mimicking peripheral blood and bone marrow niche to eliminate quiescent and proliferating AML and MPN stem and progenitor cells without affecting normal cells and tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anemia, sickle cell disease, and beta-thalassemia are blood disorders that affect millions of people in the United States and worldwide. There is no Food and Drug Administration-approved point-of-care diagnostic device for sickle cell or beta-thalassemia in the United States. In this project, we plan to complete US-centric analytical and clinical validation studies for FDA 510(k) applications and commercialize Gazelle in the US as the first and only integrated point-of-care diagnostic platform for sickle cell disease, beta-thalassemia, and anemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL NARRATIVE The Cyclin D-Cdk4/6-Rb-E2F pathway normally integrates external and internal signals to control cell cycle progression at the G1/S transition of the cell cycle. Alterations in the Cyclin D-Cdk4/6-Rb-E2F pathway are found in the vast majority of human cancers. These alterations are thought to increase the proliferative potential of cancer cells. Here we propose an in-depth mechanistic investigation of all levels of the Cyclin D-Cdk4/6-Rb-E2F pathway to gain novel insights into fundamental aspects of the mechanisms of action of this pathway in cells, with the hope that these studies will reveal novel ways to block the proliferation of cancer cells in patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Suicide prevention is VA’s highest clinical priority, and the greatest number of lives lost to suicide are in older Veterans. However, most national suicide prevention programs target younger military personnel and Veterans returning from combat. Thus, the on-going work by Dr. Amy Byers on suicide-risk detection and prevention in older Veterans is imperative. She is a leader in investigating salient risk factors related to late-life suicide using nationally based, large-scale data. Her work uses substantial creativity and originality to identify new and timely issues on which to conduct research projects and to extend existing knowledge in the areas of suicide, aging, and mental health. She has an active and vigorous research program that is capable of obtaining continued VA Merit Review funding, as well as extramural peer review funding. The Research Career Scientist Award will support Dr. Byers’ on-going research activities in these areas, advancing the current landscape of VA’s suicide prevention programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is a problem in many types of infectious disease, but one area of particular concern is in individuals with cystic fibrosis (CF) infected with Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Pa). This study will identify evolutionary mechanisms that drive AMR heterogeneity in Pa populations, and ascertain novel genomic loci that are involved in regulatory pathways that control in vivo AMR. The project will answer a number of unsolved questions that will advance understanding of AMR in the context of CF, and suggest improvements for antibiotic treatment and susceptibility testing in clinical labs.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Uterine fibroids are prevalent tumors of uterus characterized by excessive fibrotic tissues. Using new cutting-edge computational methods, we have found that small groups of senescent cells in fibroids work in concert with immune cells to produce soluble factors in fibroid tissues to create a feed-forward loop leading to fibrosis. This project seeks to unravel key cell-cell communication networks involving senescent and immune cells in fibroids to develop new treatments for uterine fibroids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human cell division is regulated at the G1/S transition before DNA is replicated. The primary drivers of cells through the G1/S transition are the cyclin-dependent kinases Cdk4 and Cdk6 in complex with D-type cyclins. The goal of this project is to determine the mechanisms that Cyclin D-Cdk4/6 complexes use to drive cell division, to identify the targets of Cyclin D-Cdk4/6 kinases in cells, and to discover small molecules that inhibit Cyclin D’s ability to target substrates for phosphorylation by Cdk4/6.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative / Public Health Statement The tumor suppressor p53 and proto-oncogene MYC are regulators of two of the most important pathways in preventing the development of human malignancies. Completion of this research will aid in the development of methods to reduce fractional cell killing and cancer cell evasion of therapeutic treatments.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: NARRATIVE: ECHO PROJECT Handoff standardization strategies have been implemented across hospitals to mitigate deleterious postoperative handoff events, but the "one-size-fits-all" approach has failed to promote critical collaborative handoff functions, consequently contributing to communication errors and care continuity failures. To address these failures, we propose to develop and implement the INTERACT (Intelligent interactive care continuity) handoff bundle, a flexible standardized, EHR-integrated, and resilient sociotechnical intervention comprised of a telemedicine-augmented handoff process (i.e., the social component) supported by a Machine Learning (ML)-augmented handoff report (i.e., the technical component). This project aligns with AHRQ’s patient safety initiatives for “making health care safer with higher quality care” and is responsive to PA-20-068 by rigorously testing an innovative solution to improve communication and coordination during care transitions.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: EnhanCed HandOffs (ECHO)

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: WM S. MIDDLETON MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSP
PHR: Melanoma is one of the five most frequently diagnosed cancers in VA patients. Veterans appear to be at higher risk of melanoma due to deployment to tropical/subtropical zones with high ultraviolet (UV)-index climates and exposure to certain chemicals. Despite recent advances in the treatment of melanoma, existing therapies are not able to fully manage melanoma incidences or fatalities. Therefore, new molecular targets and treatments will be required to effectively manage this cancer. The goal of this study is to define the role and mechanism of the protein SIRT6 in melanoma. SIRT6 plays complex roles in several other types of cancer, but its function in melanoma has not been fully established. We will investigate the role of SIRT6 and the therapeutic significance of inhibiting SIRT6 – alone and in combination with existing melanoma therapies – in several clinically-relevant models. The outcomes of our proposed study may lead to the development of novel diagnostic, prognostic and therapeutic approaches that will improve the management of melanoma in Veterans.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Because of recent policies to decrease opioid use, some people using long-term opioid therapy (LTOT) are encouraged or required to stop (discontinue) taking opioids. That has led experts to be concerned that patients whose LTOT is discontinued could have untreated pain, turn to other substance use and possibly illicit opioids, or have worsened mental health symptoms leading to suicide. To guide safer policies, guidelines, and care, this study will interview patients and doctors about discontinuing LTOT and use the results to develop a patient-centered decision aid to improve patient-provider communication around discontinuation of LTOT.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Patient Perspectives on Prescription Opioid Discontinuation: Understanding and Promoting Safe Transitions

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tumor cells invariably have defects in the biochemical mechanisms that regulate cell growth and division. E2F proteins, which activate transcription of genes to drive forward the cell cycle and proliferation, are commonly turned on in cancer. This project aims to develop a molecular picture of how E2F proteins function and how they are switched on and off, with the goal of identifying strategies to develop therapeutics that act as E2F inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall program will study a genetic pathway that controls cell cycle progression and that is frequently mutated in human cancers. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The cochlea houses diverse types of neurons that collectively help animals to hear, locate and interpret a wide variety of sounds in the world. We will study how these neurons acquire the specialized properties needed for normal hearing, including the ability to withstand constant exposure to noise. Our work will improve the design of cochlear implants and inform efforts to repair the damaged cochlea, for example by replacing lost neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative The Proteomics Core run by Dr. Peter Jackson will facilitate the analysis of protein-protein interactions, post- translational modifications, and the identification and analysis of protein complexes to comprehensively understand all paralogs of Cdk4/6, cyclin D1-3, Rb and E2Fs. By combining affinity-purification of wild type and mutant proteins, including mutations in protein modifications and patient-derived mutations, coupled to mass spectrometry, plus shotgun and phosphoproteomics techniques, and using a new ultrasensitive timsTOF mass spectrometer, this core will deliver state of the art data and analyses of the core proteins analyzed in all three projects of this grant. The high throughput of this facility and rapid data communication will be an important hypothesis generating function favoring new understanding of the molecular drivers of cancer linked to the cyclin D/CDK4/6 complex and those highly responsive to the clinically important cancer therapeutic palbociclib, a CDK4 inhibitor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal this P01 proposal to better understand mechanisms in the core Cyclin D-Cdk4/6-Rb-E2F pathway regulating the G1/S transition controlling human cell division to facilitate development of novel cancer therapeutics. To test these hypotheses, all projects will rely on the cell phenotyping and molecular imaging core to generate mutations and analyze their effects on cell cycle progression and protein interactions. To support the program projects, this core aims to 1) use CRIPSR/Cas9 genome editing to generate mutant cell lines; 2) image gene expression, cell growth, and cell cycle transition dynamics at single cell resolution; and 3) build and maintain software that analyzes the terabytes of time lapse imaging data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative About 70% of alcohol use disorder patients do not develop severe alcohol-associated liver disease. The current project explores whether gut microbiota and their metabolites are key players determining transition from alcohol use disorders to severe alcohol-associated liver disease. Finally, therapeutic efficacies of microbial metabolite urolithin A against alcoholic liver diseases progression will be examined in humanized microbiota mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Tens of millions of people in the world are burdened by epilepsy, and many of these patients have seizures that cannot be controlled with existing therapies. There has been a recent surge in interest in leveraging cannabis-related molecules to control treatment-resistant epilepsy. Our project will determine how the body’s own cannabinoids get generated and released following neuronal hyperactivity in the intact brain. We will then test how effectively cannabinoid-sensitive inhibitory neurons can be targeted for novel non-invasive therapies to control chronic spontaneous seizures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Polypharmacy, or taking multiple concurrent medications, is very common in older adults with cancer undergoing curative-intent chemotherapy. Polypharmacy is associated with adverse outcomes including receiving less chemotherapy, which in turn can affect cancer-related survival. “Deprescribing,” or the planned discontinuation of medications, is an intervention that can address polypharmacy, but it has not been studied in older adults with cancer receiving curative-chemotherapy; this proposal refines and tests two deprescribing intervention strategies in these patients.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: NORTH AMERICAN PRIMARY CARE RES GROUP
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of the proposed national Practice-Based Research Network (PBRN) conferences to be convened annually from 2023 through 2025 is to enhance the skills and knowledge of clinicians and researchers in evidence-based research to improve the health of the U.S. population and the value of health care patient safety. The Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) conference grant to support these PBRN meetings will assist AHRQ in accomplishing its mission to create evidence that will make health care safer, higher quality, more accessible, equitable and affordable; the conference intends to ensure the produced evidence is summarized, communicated, and applied among clinicians and researchers.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  There are significant unmet needs for youth with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) leading to increased crises and emergencies, which are exacerbated during the COVID-19 pandemic. This study will examine the interplay between polypharmacy of psychotropic medications and key ASD behavioral treatments, as well as their impact on psychiatric adverse events in a real-world setting. Our findings will have significance to the entire ASD community by informing individuals, families, and providers on effective treatments for reducing the risk of behavioral health crises and guiding policy decision-making at the payer, state, and national levels.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: The interplay of behavioral therapies, pharmacological treatments and psychiatric adverse events among Youth with Autism Spectrum Disorders

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this study is to further develop a 3D UTE-AdiabT1r sequence for robust mapping of PGs, a 3D UTE-MT sequence for robust mapping of MMF, an IR-FS-UTE sequence for high contrast imaging and T2* mapping of the CEP to evaluate calcification and dehydration, and a UTE-DESS sequence to study apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) for evaluating IVD degeneration in lumbar spines from young (<40y, n=10), mid-age (40-70y, n=10), and elderly (>70y, n=10) donors. This study will further validate the series of UTE sequences developed to assess IVD degeneration and regeneration using a mature rabbit annular puncture chronic disc degeneration model. In the final step, the optimized UTE sequences will be used to study IVD degeneration in patients with chronic LBP (n=40) and age-, sex- and BMI-matched healthy volunteers (n=40), compare UTE and clinical MRI metrics of the NP, AF, and CEP of the lumbar spine in the two groups, and correlate them with clinical evaluations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative India provides a unique context with which to disentangle the effect of bilingualism on cognitive aging because bilingualism is much more equally distributed among socioeconomically diverse groups in India than it is in Western and high-income countries. Leveraging already-funded, rich population representative data from India, the findings of the proposed investigation will yield new insights on the intersection of bilingualism and cognitive aging, discerning whether bilingualism buffers the effects of blood-based and neuroimaging biomarkers of Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) and uncovering the mechanisms by which bilingualism confers cognitive reserve against biological risk of ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use disorder imposes a substantial public health burden. Despite this, effective therapies are lacking, and treatment for compulsive drinking is particularly inadequate. This research seeks to understand how chronic ethanol exposure disrupts specific brain circuits that are required for compulsive alcohol drinking. The data gathered from this study will provide novel therapeutic strategies targeting compulsive alcohol drinking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oncolytic viruses are viruses with selective ability to replicate in cancer cells and are increasingly recognized for their potential to activate an immune response to cancers. In the current proposal, we will aim to determine how the immune responses to oncolytic viruses impact the development of anti-tumor immunity in animal models and patients. These findings will bear direct impact on the oncolytic virus engineering strategies and will guide the design of clinical trials implementing these agents in combination with other immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it provides evidence on how health systems— through which a growing proportion of medical care is delivered in the United States—influence care of older Americans with the greatest health needs. Understanding whether and how health systems change quality, utilization, and spending for medically complex Medicare beneficiaries is critical for implementing care models and policies that improve the health of medically complex patients. The proposed research is relevant to AHRQ's mission as it pertains to generating knowledge that contributes to improving care for vulnerable populations and promoting a higher value health care system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Precise control of kinase signaling pathways is critical for neuronal development and function. Mutations in the understudied serine-threonine kinase TAOK1 are strongly associated with both autism and neurodevelopmental delay. Integrating innovative approaches in kinase biochemistry, proteomics, chemical-genetics, structural biology and stem cell modeling, we will determine the molecular function of TAOK1 kinase and determine how TAOK1 dysfunction contributes to the etiology of neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The rates of suicide and suicidal ideation and behaviors (SIB) among Black youth have almost doubled in the past decade, making the studying of Black youth suicide and SIB a public health priority. The proposed study aims to improve our understanding of the uniqueness and complex etiology of Black youth suicide and SIB through a multi-dimensional approach, including the identification of risk and protective factors and an empirical evaluation of Durkheim’s social integration theory and Tarde’s imitation theory on Black youth suicide and SIB. The results of the study will provide valuable information for future policies targeting suicide reduction among the Black youth population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study will determine how pathological stress on the heart induces metabolic adjustments to both the heart and adipose tissue, and how these reciprocal responses mediates both cardiac metabolic remodeling and the development of decompensated cardiac hypertrophy with potential consequences to systemic metabolism. We will first test the role of cardiac natriuretic peptide responses to altered cardiac fat oxidation as an activator of adipose tissue plasticity, independent of adrenergic activation of adipose tissue, and second, examine the potential for a cardioprotective role of the beiging of white adipose tissue and brown adipose tissue activation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Major depressive disorder is the second leading cause of global disability and results in significant functional impairment, morbidity, and mortality. Despite evidence of impairments associated with emotionally-laden (i.e., hot) cognitive processes and behaviors, there remains significantly limited information regarding hot cognitive function in adults across the lifespan with depression that hinders mechanistic understanding and new treatment development. The knowledge gained in this preliminary pilot study will provide the necessary information to create a program of research to inform underlying mechanisms of hot cognitive function and confirm such mechanisms of action to then develop new and personalized mechanism-based therapeutics to remediate hot cognitive dysfunction and optimize overall health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  The goal of this proposal is to elucidate calcineurin-signaling cascades governing stress responses and virulence of the human fungal pathogen Cryptococcus, which has a significant global public health impact and infects both immunocompromised (HIV/AIDS, transplant recipients, and others) and immunocompetent individuals to cause life-threatening diseases of the lungs and brain (pneumonia, meningoencephalitis). Combined, Cryptococcus species are responsible for >220,000 infections each year and more than 181,000 deaths worldwide, resulting in >15% of all HIV/AIDS-associated deaths. The studies proposed will 1) identify and characterize novel calcineurin-interacting proteins and study these as short- and long-term effectors of stress-responsive virulence pathways, and 2) define the roles of calcineurin re-localization to P-bodies/stress granules during stress in operating a bifurcated stress-response pathway required for pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Serine deprivation is a promising therapeutic approach in cancer, but dietary serine starvation may be difficult to achieve in humans. Here, we present a novel therapeutic serine-degrading enzyme that can reduce circulating serine levels by greater than 90% in the absence of dietary changes. In this proposal we will further characterize enzymatic serine degradation as a potential therapeutic option in multiple tumor types, including luminal breast tumors which are auxotrophic for serine and therefore highly sensitive to serine depletion therapy.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric polypharmacy (defined as ≥5 concurrent medications) is a major public health problem with high prevalence among the priority population of children with medical complexity. Pediatric polypharmacy is necessary for symptom and disease management, but major opportunities exist to improve outpatient medication management, safety, and value. We will conduct a hybrid type 2 randomized controlled trial to study the effectiveness of a structured pharmacist-led Pediatric Medication Therapy Management (pMTM) intervention on improving the proactive management of polypharmacy by reducing medication-related problems (MRPs), with an evaluation guided by the RE-AIM (Reach, Effectiveness, Adoption, Implementation, and Maintenance) framework to determine whether pMTM could be transformational for optimizing polypharmacy among children with medical complexity.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Optimizing the Clinical Management of Polypharmacy for Children with Medical Complexity

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Through this program, I-RED Southeast XLerator Network will develop a suite of experience-based entrepreneurship education products and commercialization education tools to address the needs of academic institutions and their faculty, researchers, innovators, and graduate/undergraduate students in the Southeast IDeA states region. The ultimate aim of these entrepreneurship education and training products is to foster the translation of promising biomedical discoveries and technologies from research laboratories into the creation of commercial products which both improve human health and promote economic growth. As a result, it will significantly enhance commercialization knowledge, mature the entrepreneurial ecosystem, identify more market-ready technologies and patents, see more startup entities formed, increase dilutive and non-dilutive funding to these entities, and accelerate the commercialization of biomedical and health tech innovations in the region – with the fundamental goal of positively impacting human health and patient’s lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kennedy’s disease is a progressive genetic neurodegenerative disease caused by an abnormal androgen receptor (AR) protein. There is currently no effective treatment available to slow, stop, or reverse the disease. Based on promising preclinical results obtained under a funded Phase 1 STTR grant, this Phase 2 SBIR grant application proposes to perform preclinical development studies with our androgen receptor antagonist and degrader ONCT-505 to destroy the AR protein as a potential therapeutic for Kennedy’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The rate of cellular turnover slows during aging, can be accelerated during injury and repair, and is precociously stimulated during carcinogenesis; but the mechanisms guiding turnover in living tissues is not well understood. The proposed studies will determine how the elimination of unfit cells by extrusion from epithelia stimulates the nearby stem cells to generate new cells and maintain overall cell numbers in the tissue. Discoveries arising from this work will provide new insights into mechanisms that can be harnessed to promote cellular replacement or prevent the unwanted addition of new cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To reduce the risk of death, re-hospitalization, and growth faltering following hospitalizations among children living in Sub-Saharan Africa, it is critical to understand mechanisms underlying this risk, including how azithromycin affects these outcomes. Utilizing samples and data from an ongoing placebo-controlled RCT of azithromycin for post-discharge morbidity and mortality, we will characterize enteric pathogens and antibiotic resistance utilizing highly sensitive molecular diagnostic tools to determine the role of these enteric pathways on post-discharge outcomes and azithromycin’s effect.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Students with blindness are systematically excluded from chemistry because of the unmet challenges of making the laboratory, data, and imagery accessible. In a collaboration involving Baylor researchers, five teachers/accessibility specialists at the Texas School for the Blind and Visually Impaired (TSBVI), and three PhD chemists with early blindness, this project is: (i) developing and testing new methods of making 2D/3D curriculum more accessible, and (ii) adapting chemistry labs at Baylor to be robotically accessible to 30 TSBVI high school students for annual Special Research Experiences. An external evaluation will use a randomized controlled trial to test the hypothesis that Special Research Experiences positively affect TSBVI student interest, confidence and sense of belonging in STEM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The ability of cells to perceive mechanical cues is critical for development, tissue homeostasis, and immune function, and is dysregulated in disease states including cancer and muscular dystrophies. This project aims to reveal fundamental mechanisms of how forces transmitted through the actin cytoskeleton are converted into biochemical signals which govern cell physiology and regulate gene expression. In the near-term, our studies will enable rigorously determining the specific functions of these pathways, which in the long-term will guide efforts to target them therapeutically.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to develop novel multiparametric MRI biomarkers that precisely identify regions of brain tumor within areas of contrast-enhancement and peritumoral edema, which cannot be identified using standard MRI. Powered by recent advances in machine learning, our approach has the potential to cause a fundamental shift in the treatment management of patients with brain tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Viral myocarditis is a heterogeneous disease that is difficult to study and diagnose, particularly in infants and neonates. This proposal integrates innovative single-cell and spatial analysis assays together with more traditional pathogenesis studies to identify the viral and host factors that determine the outcome of viral myocarditis in a model of neonatal myocarditis. Successful implementation of these studies will lead to entirely new approaches and molecular tools to study viral myocarditis and can lead to novel diagnostic principles or to novel treatments for acute viral myocarditis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  CAR-T immunotherapy is an emerging therapeutic approach for treatment of malignancies which are refractory to conventional cytotoxic therapies such as B cell leukemia and lymphoma, but treatment failures are also common and post-CAR-T therapy relapses have been found to be common and limited the long term success of the therapy. Modulation of metabolism of CAR-T cells is emerging as an alternative strategy to overcome some of the challenges and in this application we propose MCJ, an endogenous brake for the mitochondrial metabolism, to be our target. We propose to investigate 1) the role of MCJ in human CD8 T cell metabolism and function, and 2) whether disrupting MCJ expression in CAR-T cells enhances the efficacy of this anti-cancer immunotherapy using mouse models and human cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The goal of this project is to develop a genetically encoded calcium integrator for noninvasive whole-brain mapping of neural activity in animal models, using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). These tools will be derived from water channels known as aquaporins, optimizing using techniques drawn from mammalian synthetic biology and molecular engineering, characterized in model cell lines and neurons, and finally demonstrated in mouse models involving chemogenetic and optogenetic neuromodulation of the neural reward circuitry. By enabling noninvasive access to neural activity at a whole-brain scale and in a repeatable fashion, the proposed work will establish a transformative capability for basic neuroscience research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Narrative One of the most common causes of death and disability in this country is from a heart attack: damage to the heart muscle. Following a heart attack, it is now clear that enzymes are made that continue to chew away at the heart muscle and eventually cause the heart to change shape and fail. This study will identify how to control a critical enzyme which causes the heart to fail following a heart attack and thereby develop new tests and treatments for patients after a heart attack.
