IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative: Cardiac arrest is a major contributor to mortality and morbidity in the USA; current methods for monitoring the heart are antiquated and provide limited information. The technologies that we propose to develop will directly assess several new aspects of the heart such as the control by the autonomic nervous system in real-time. This will provide precise information on neural control of the ischemic heart and support novel treatments for ischemic disease by modulating autonomic nerves that project to the heart.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Already a global epidemic, the prevalence of type 2 diabetes is expected to quickly rise in the coming decades, posing a serious threat to the global health. The goal of this project is to investigate novel molecular and physiological mechanisms in regulating beta cell function and stress responses at chromatin level, and to test a new strategy to prevent beta cell failure and ameliorate diabetes progression. Results from this study may pave the way towards next generation clinical solution for type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project narrative Neural tube defects (NTDs) are debilitating and deadly congenital mallformations resulting from a failure of the neural tube – the precursor of the brain and spinal cord – to close during embryonic development. Neural tube closure is driven by active rearrangements of multiple embryonic cell types, but the ‘instructions’ for these cell movements are poorly defined. By identifying genes that control cell movements within experimentally accessible zebrafish embryos, this proposal will advance our fundamental understanding of neural tube development and help to identify new genetic risk factors for NTDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE The increasing development of scores (sociogenomic PGS) that predict polygenic contributions to complex behaviors and traits, like reproductive behavior and income, has the promise to improve genetic and social science research, but, if not implemented carefully, threatens to exacerbate social inequities and disparities. Through extensive review of current research on developing sociogenomic PGS, exploration of diverse viewpoints on the potential harms and benefits of sociogenomic PGS, and assessment of the legal protections and barriers for implementation, this project seeks to better understand the ethical and social impacts of this new technology. Our findings from stakeholder perspectives and development of legal case studies will provide guidance for how to move forward with sociogenomic PGS research in ways that promote public health and social justice.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Women are at extreme risk for HIV during pregnancy and postpartum, therefore antiretroviral pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is increasingly being used. Here, we propose to use two existing cohorts of HIV-uninfected pregnant women and their infants from Umlazi, KwaZulu-Natal to address our hypothesis that vaginal microbiota and inflammation are important mediators of HIV risk, but also of adverse birth outcomes. The project will also examine the effects of PrEP use during pregnancy and breastfeeding on infant health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The Primary Immune Deficiency Treatment Consortium (PIDTC) has built multicenter collaborations at 47 centers in the US and Canada to learn best treatment strategies and improve outcomes for primary immune deficiencies (PIDs). The PIDTC Annual Scientific Workshops, begun in 2011 and continuously funded by R13 awards, bring together a diverse group of investigators, physicians, patient advocates and trainees to focus on critical topics in severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS), chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) and primary immune regulatory disorders (PIRD). The 3 upcoming PIDTC Scientific Workshops and Education Days are planned to be in Cincinnati, Ohio, in April 2023, followed by Atlanta, GA, and Washington, DC, with the 2023 meeting titled “New Treatments for Primary Immune Disorders.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because peri-prosthetic infection (PJI) is a significant healthcare burden, which not only impacts very detrimentally the patients’ morbidity and mortality but also exponentially increases the cost of treatment for total joint replacements. Thus, the proposed research to develop a platform bearing surface technology and implementation strategies to treat PJI is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to the application of our fundamental knowledge of living systems to enhance health, lengthen life, and reduce illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance/Project Narrative Production of collagen matrix during postnatal heart development is critical for proper growth and maturation of this organ, and related pathways are responsible for the accumulation of fibrotic material in the heart of post-MI patients. Cardiac fibrosis contributes to progressive heart disease, and new therapies directed at limiting the fibrotic response are desperately needed, especially end stage heart failure. This dual-PI application will investigate the crosstalk between cardiac fibroblasts and muscle cells mediated by extracellular matrix that contribute to development and disease progression with the goal of defining new targets for future therapeutic strategy development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Sickle cell disease (SCD) is a devastating, painful hereditary blood disorder with significant global morbidity and early mortality. Hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) transplantation remains the only curative therapeutic option, however little is known about the impact of SCD pathophysiology on HSCs. This project will identify mechanisms by which SCD impairs HSC function, thereby highlighting targetable pathways to improve the safety, efficiency, and accessibility of autologous HSC transplantation following gene therapy for SCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative HCC is one of the most common cancers with an incidence rate that has the highest increase amongst all cancers over the last decade. Our proposed studies focus on discovering the critical changes in the diabetic liver that provide a pro-invasive milieu for transformed cells. We will focus on matrix behavior that is permissive for invasion or metastasis, and these studies will result is data that will directly be translatable to human HCC and will advance the field in HCC therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Advanced age and obesity are important risk factors for Alzheimer's disease (AD). We have discovered a novel metabolic pathway that profoundly influences longevity and obesity in mice. We will investigate the hypothesis that inhibition of this pathway in genetically-modified mice will reduce AD neuropathology and cognitive deficit, including in mice fed a high-fat diet.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Cytokines and chemokines are bioactive molecules produced in responses to physiological events, directing and shaping immune responses to immunization, infection, transplantation and disease, and many such molecules are being considered for therapeutic use or as part of natural immune adjuvants to vaccination. These molecules are however species specific and utilizing human or rodent cytokines in nonhuman primates often leads to erroneous results due to the fact that NHPs will rapidly mount immune responses against the foreign proteins. Thus, the goals of this grant are to continue and to expand the services and reagents provided by this unique resource to investigators using nonhuman primates as preclinical models for human disease and immunotherapy.

PHR: Noise-induced hearing loss affects nearly 40 million Americans. We have newly identified a pathway critically involved in the ear's early response to loud sound. In this grant, we aim to learn more about how this pathway is involved in hearing and deafness, so that we may develop drugs to target this pathway and prevent hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite having therapeutic effects, marijuana use leads to a wide range of adverse physical and mental effects. One important way to reduce these harmful public health consequences is by imposing excise taxes on retail marijuana. We propose to evaluate how excise tax structures impact marijuana consumption and product choices among different marijuana forms and between legal and illegal products. The empirical evidence will inform how to set excise tax structures to mitigate harms for states contemplating taxation policies as they legalize, and for states and localities with legal retail sales contemplating reforms to their current tax structures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Chlamydia trachomatis is the etiological agent of blinding trachoma and a sexually transmitted infection that can result in serious complications including pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), ectopic pregnancy, and infertility. The molecular mechanisms used by C. trachomatis to co-opt host vesicular trafficking for the acquisition of essential nutrients are poorly understood since until recently chlamydia was intractable to genetic manipulation. This proposal will define how the essential C. trachomatis Inc protein, CT229, coordinates interactions with host and bacterial factors to acquire essential nutrients required for proliferation and inclusion stability, which will ultimately identify novel targets for therapeutic intervention and greatly expand our understanding of host-pathogen interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Oxidative stress is often associated with inappropriate activation of immune cells, including macrophages, leading to atherosclerosis which is the underlying cause of heart attacks, strokes, and ischemic limb loss. This project seeks to identify and characterize mechanisms that link oxidative stress in fat cells (adipocytes) to chronic macrophage activation through activation of specific cellular receptors and release of bioactive materials. The novel molecular pathway identified in this proposal could lead to new strategies for therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Antisense oligonucleotides are a powerful tool to study RNA function that cleave the desired target by recruiting endogenous RNase H; yet they have limited clinical utility and have off-targets. Herein, we propose to further develop the small molecule equivalent of antisense oligonucleotides, where we have engineered small molecules that selectively bind to a given RNA target to recruit an endogenous RNase, a strategy that provides a powerful and facile platform for selective destruction of any RNA. We will apply these methods to disable an oncogenic miRNA that has known roles as a driver of metastatic triple negative breast cancer and seek to improve small molecule selectivity, potency and efficacy in breast cancer cells both ex vivo and in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CHIP is a key enzyme in cellular protein quality control. On a cellular level, altered CHIP function sensitizes cells to stress, and at an organismal level, the inability to respond to stress results in degenerative pathologies and accelerated aging. Our overall goal is to determine the mechanisms and dysfunction caused by disease-causing CHIP mutations at the atomic, cellular, and whole-body level. We will use novel cell systems in combination with our preclinical models to test novel therapies to counteract the loss of CHIP function. In doing so, we will establish a new framework to better understand this aging and CHIP biology that, in turn, will allow us to develop precision medicine approaches to alleviate degeneration caused by the loss of CHIP function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study has the potential to improve patient outcomes by comparing two scalable smoking cessation interventions in a health system setting that will reach a large number of older adults who are at high risk for tobacco-related diseases. By delivering evidence-based and practical smoking cessation interventions in conjunction with lung cancer screening, participants may be especially amenable to receiving support for quitting. Results from this study, including a short-term economic analysis, budget impact, and feasibility data, will provide critical data to address future implementation within this and other large health systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emergent literature shows that pregnant populations and their infants are at greater risk for adverse health and environmental effects from climate change. Few studies have examined the impacts of climate change on leading maternal and infant complications (e.g., gestational diabetes, severe maternal morbidity, hypertensive disorders of pregnancy, preterm birth); and even fewer have examined prenatal exposure to temperature extremes in the context of other social environmental stressors (e.g., residential segregation and poverty). The proposed project will examine prenatal exposure to extreme heat and cold events on excess maternal and infant health risk to provide much-needed foundational knowledge on the relationship between a changing climate and pregnancy risk and potential interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Justice-involved emerging adults (EAs; aged 18-25) are one of the highest-risk populations for opioid and other substance use and other significant problems (criminal behaviors), but they lack access to and engagement in evidence-based practices. The deleterious outcomes and long-term costs of substance use for EAs, communities, and society (estimated at over $740 billion annually and greater than costs for any other health problem), make this a priority. The overarching purpose of the proposed study is to investigate an increasingly common, but under-researched, practice of employing paraprofessional coaches to improve EAs’ access to and engagement in evidence-based substance use practices, focusing on the paraprofessional coaches’ outcomes and the role of lived experience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This proposal aims at understanding the host immune and genetic factors as well as parasite characteristics that are associated with protection from clinical Plasmodium vivax malaria. Our objectives are to elucidate the mechanisms driving the development of broadly inhibiting anti-Plasmodium vivax antibodies, to identify host and parasite genetic factors associated to protection and to uncover immune pathways of protection and novel potential antigenic targets. Accomplishment of these goals will be reached by leveraging a longitudinal Plasmodium vivax patient cohort displaying contrasted clinical outcome of infection, in combination with state- of-the art technologies on site and our ability to perform short-term cultures of Plasmodium vivax, and will provide invaluable information to design evidence-based intervention strategies for the elimination of this human malaria parasite.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: The Diabetic Foot Consortium aims to validate biomarkers that promote healing and prevent recurrence of diabetic foot ulcers and leverage their growing database of patient, wound, therapies and biomarker characteristics to advance standard care. Proper design of biomarker validation studies and analyses using advanced machine learning methods are critical to accomplish these goals. With more than 23 years of experience, the University of Michigan data coordinating center will continue to apply cutting-edge statistical and operational methods to these studies, maximizing the clinical impact of the consortium in this complex and challenging therapeutic area.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Recent cancer treatment strategies stimulate patient's own immune system to mount a strong immune response against otherwise immuno-evasive cancer cells, with promising results in various solid tumors, but this approach is inefficient for treatment of liver cancer. Since freezing tumors by cryoablation triggers anti-tumor immune responses, we posit that cryoablation may enhance treatment effects in liver cancer for personalized cancer therapy. We will use a mouse model of liver cancer that mimics the important stages of liver injury seen in humans, and establish a novel combination of immune cell targeting and metabolic imaging to detect the cryoablation-induced modulation of the immuno-metabolic interplay in liver cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In the past several years, important progress has been made in identifying genes implicated in neurodevelopmental disorders. It is now recognized that KCNQ2 loss and gain of function mutations lead to developmental epileptic encephalopathy that might also include respiratory dysfunction and severe central hypoventilation syndrome. Therefore, the goal of this application is to understand the essential role of KCNQ2 in control of breathing that may explain both the origins and developmental progression of symptoms, as well as to propose strategies for effective therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Endometriosis remains an enigmatic disease whose basic biology still eludes us. Animal models, in which the induced disease is reflective of the human condition, offers the best hope for understanding the early events associated with the pathophysiology of this disease and more importantly the basic knowledge as to how inflammation, a hallmark of the disease, promotes lesion development. Studies proposed in this application focus on how inflammatory cytokines and the NOTCH signaling pathway contribute to the development of endometriosis and their potential as therapeutic targets.

PHR: One of the most successful chemotherapy drugs is cisplatin, also known as penicillin for cancer. However, patients many times couldn't stay in the effective anti-cancer treatment from cisplatin, because it causes injury to kidneys. With the success of this study, we could provide our patient with non-invasive early detection and mitigate cisplatin induced acute kidney injury for them to stay on their effective anti-cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative Black women have higher breast cancer mortality, and different prevalence of key DNA repair pathway mutations, notably p53. These DNA repair pathways may interact with other mechanisms of treatment resistance, including immune responses. This project will elucidate the relationship between p53, DNA repair mechanisms, and immune response and evaluate the implications of these pathways for mortality disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Development of male and female sex in vertebrates relies on a conserved set of interactions among a multi- component network of differentiation genes. The key gene that initiates this process in many vertebrates is a copy of the anti-Müllerian hormone on the Y chromosome (Amhy). Understanding how this is properly regulated in vertebrates has important implications for human health, as disruptions in this process can lead to several disorders of sex development, including sex reversal, intersex phenotypes, and gonadal dysgenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Young children with autism often have long wait times for diagnosis and intervention; this is especially true of children from Latinx families and may prevent these children from getting the earliest possible intervention. The proposed project will adapt and test a comprehensive, on-line, parent-mediated, free intervention (OPT-In- Early Bilingual Latinx Version) for Latinx families in the US; it can be used during these wait times and supplement professional intervention. Results of this study will lead to a large-scale test of this intervention, with the goal of making it freely available to Latinx families and optimizing their children's development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative  This project will uncover how signaling at cardiomyocyte intracellular membrane microdomains contributes to cardiac hypertrophy and heart failure. Although a number of signaling pathways have established roles in cardiac disease pathogenesis, the topography of hypertrophic signal transduction circuitry within the complex architecture of the adult cardiac myocyte is ill-defined. We will interrogate the functions of protein palmitoylation, a reversible lipid modification, in spatiotemporal regulation of compartmentalized signaling events in cardiomyocytes that may potentially be leveraged for the development of more targeted strategies to treat cardiac disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative: Current therapies for autoimmune disease chronically suppress the immune system, which risks severe infection. DSG3-CAART is the first precision T cell immunotherapy for autoimmune disease to enter clinical trials, which presents a unique opportunity to investigate the immunomodulatory effects of this novel targeted therapeutic approach in humans. The proposed studies will elucidate the cellular and molecular determinants of DSG3-CAART activity and host immune response, using clinical samples collected from subjects enrolled in the DSG3-CAART phase 1 study.

PHR: NARRATIVE Acute lung injury (ALI) and the acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) are consequences of pulmonary or systemic infections that increase the buildup of protein-rich fluid in the lungs. PHR: Project Narrative: The severity of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease is positively associated with hyperinsulinemia and insulin resistance. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lysosomes function as critical nodes for macromolecular recycling, metabolic rewiring, and pro-growth signaling in cells and mechanisms that regulate quality control of the lysosome invariably also impact these broader cellular pathways and processes. Using affinity-based capture of intact lysosomes coupled to mass spectrometry-based proteomics, we have identified the Ferlin family of membrane repair factors as novel lysosome membrane proteins. Our proposal will investigate a novel function for Ferlin proteins in promoting enhanced lysosome function and stress resistance in the context of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We are in perhaps the most exciting era of cancer research to date, with the ability to cure once deadly cancers through hematopoietic stem cell transplantation; but it is nothing short of tragic for a patient to then die during their immunocompromised state because of a respiratory viral infection that is usually considered trivial in healthy people. This project studies the ability of cross-neutralizing antibodies to protect against four of the main respiratory viruses that cause severe disease in stem cell transplant recipients. This research will reveal how these antibodies work, help predict their success or failure in clinical use, and impact the design and testing of next-generation antibody candidates that can overcome resistance from viral evolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Although natural killer T (NKT) cells are emerging as critical players in the pulmonary immune system, knowledge about their role in human influenza virus infections remains rudimentary due to a lack of suitable animal models. This proposal will use a highly translational genetically edited pig model to examine the contribution of NKT cells to three important aspects of influenza virus infection: (i) virus susceptibility, (ii) immunity afforded by inactivated and modified live virus vaccines, and (iii) vaccine associated enhanced respiratory disease illness. The objectives will advance our basic understanding of anti-influenza immune responses and provide a foundation for therapeutically targeting NKT cells to mitigate influenza virus infections in humans.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We rigorously evaluate the health impacts of a employer-sponsored sales ban on sugary beverages and brief counseling to support reduced consumption, and how they work together. This multilevel intervention (targeting the food environment and individual employees) offers an efficient, scalable strategy for preventing obesity in millions of American working adults. Our findings will also contribute to scientific knowledge about the role of cravings in triggering sugary beverage intake and how interventions can reduce them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE With the advent of spatial transcriptomics, there is now a strong need for computational methods able to deconvolve the underlying biological signals. Here we propose algorithms for systematically and robustly identifying cell-cell interactions through an integration of spatial transcriptomics with matched single-cell RNA- Seq data. Overall this proposal is innovative for its novel algorithms, which are deployed and tested in the male germline and the placenta.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with sickle cell anemia suffer from progressive cognitive decline as they age, yet the pathophysiology of this cognitive dysfunction is poorly understood, which poses a barrier to the development of predictive biomarkers. Through longitudinal cognitive testing and brain MRIs evaluating metabolic stress, structural connectivity and functional connectivity, we aim to determine the mechanism of cognitive dysfunction in children with SCA and develop neuroimaging biomarkers predictive of both acutely reversible injury and long- term cognitive trajectories. The impact of this proposal lies in the potential improvement of risk stratification algorithms clinically used to guide patient care, and the development of biomarkers that can assess treatment effect of new interventions, ultimately improving clinical outcomes in this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Statement These exploratory studies are relevant to public health. First, this project will provide proof-of-concept evidence that it is possible to generate beta cells via direct programming of stem cells for the treatment of type 1 diabetes. Secondly, the engineered universal donor stem cell-derived beta cells can be transplanted into many patients without immune rejections, which could substantially reduce cell-based therapy cost.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative A bacterium known as Helicobacter pylori colonizes the stomach in about half of all humans; most do not develop any symptoms related to this infection, but some develop stomach cancer or peptic ulcer disease. Stomach cancer is the third leading cause of cancer-related death worldwide and H. pylori infection is the leading cause of stomach cancer. The long-term goals of this research are to understand the molecular mechanisms by which H. pylori infection can lead to disease, and to understand the basis for variation in clinical outcomes among H. pylori-infected persons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE ASXL1 is an epigenetic regulatory protein that plays an important role in both normal neutrophil development and the biogenesis of myeloproliferative disorders. There is a particularly high frequency of ASXL1 mutations in CSF3R-mutant myeloproliferative disorders, which are characterized by an expansion of mature neutrophils. The goal of this proposal is to uncover the molecular mechanism by which ASXL1 contributes to both normal and abnormal neutrophil production.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE While fragility fractures are costly to individuals and healthcare systems, and while highly effective methods exist for preventing fragility fractures, there are currently no risk prediction models that reliably identify persons with HIV (PWH) at greatest risk for fracture. Leveraging an outstanding team of collaborators and research platforms, we will develop, validate and disseminate a Fracture Risk Assessment Calculator that incorporates modifiable HIV-relevant risk factors (FRAC-HIV) to calculate the probability of a fracture among PWH within one year. Our findings will lay the foundation for future intervention trials that will incorporate FRAC-HIV into clinical care algorithms to prevent fractures among PWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major hurdle in the advancement of therapies that alter the progression of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is our inability to precisely phenotype individuals with variable disease trajectories. Existing pharmacotherapies fail to impact the rate of FEV1 decline, and the mechanisms that underlie distinct trajectories of disease progression are not well understood. The proposed project will use a combination of clinical and computed tomography data to determine the structural mechanisms underlying disease progression in COPD and establish novel imaging biomarkers to identify individuals at high risk for disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breast cancer is the most frequent type of cancer that occurs in women (>200,000 cases/year) and accounts for ~40,000 deaths each year in the United States. Triple Negative Breast Cancers (TNBC) are an important clinical subtype because they lack the three known important therapeutic targets used in the breast cancer clinic, namely the Estrogen Receptor, the Progesterone Receptor, and the HER2 protein. In this application, we propose to study the chemotherapy and immunotherapy responsiveness of TNBC and explore the hypothesis that much of the therapy resistance seen is due to a tumor's ability to change from one type of cellular “state” into a more resistant “state”. We hypothesize that we can prevent these state changes using drugs that interfere with DNA structure changes, therefore possibly identifying new therapeutic interventions that might overcome drug resistance in TNBC patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Many cortical and subcortical brain regions work together to coordinate social emotional brain states. In this study we propose to build a model from experimental data that explains how these regions work together to generate aggression. We will test this model using established and emerging therapeutics utilized to treat aggression in the clinic, and we will develop new brain stimulation methodologies to regulate aggressive brain states uncovered by our model.

PHR: Project Narrative Microglia lose essential homeostatic functions and shift towards a toxic activated phenotype during aging, Alzheimer’s disease, and other neurodegenerative disorders and concurrently have increased calcium dysregulation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Motor functional neurological disorder (mFND) is a prevalent and disabling neuropsychiatric disorder whereby individuals present with psychogenic (medically-unexplained) motor symptoms driven in part by abnormalities within and across salience and motor control brain networks. This neuroimaging project, with a longitudinal component, aims to use advanced structural and functional brain imaging to comprehensively characterize clinically-meaningful neurobiological subtypes of mFND. The long-term impact of this research is to define the pathophysiology of mFND, identify prognostic biomarkers, and catalyze the development of new biologically- informed treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Type 2 Diabetes (T2D) typically develops in the backdrop of obesity-induced insulin resistance, but manifests clinically as hyperglycemia only with β cell dysfunction. Several T2D therapies increase insulin secretion, but molecular determinants of other aspects of β cell biology affected in T2D – loss of maturity, altered cell-cell and cell-stroma interactions – remain incompletely understood. In this application, we focus on cause and effects of β cell Notch activation, a maladaptive response to obesity that drives β cell dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The studies described in this proposal would lead to a better mechanistic understanding of the role of interactions between the ventral hippocampus and amygdala in processes associated with behavioral responses to previously experienced threats. Specifically, it has been established previously that PTSD patients exhibit deficits in recall of extinction memory and display increased activation of the amygdala. Thus, explaining behavioral features of extinction at the neuronal network and cellular level, we would shed light on the mechanisms of extinction impairments in human PTSD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Severe neurologic complications (e.g., stroke) of COVID-19, may represent the tip of an iceberg, signaling unrecognized changes in brain structure and function among the more than 90% of patients who experienced only mild COVID-19 or asymptomatic infection with SARS-CoV-2. Unrecognized brain effects of SARS CoV-2 infection may impact daily functioning and be harbingers of future neurodegeneration and overt neurologic dysfunction. Here we will define neurological complications related to mild SARS CoV-2 infection, using sophisticated neuroimaging, neuropsychiatric examinations and detailed testing of neurocognitive functions, and will characterize their nature and scope as the first necessary steps toward addressing the problem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE The overall goal of this academic-FDA partnership R01 project is to generate diverse training and challenging testing datasets of low-dose CT (LDCT) scans, prototype a virtual CT workflow, and establish an evaluation methodology for AI-based imaging products to support FDA marketing authorization. Upon completion, our Adversarially Based CT (ABC) workflow/platform will be made publicly available, and readily extendable to other imaging modalities and other diseases. This ABC system will be shared through the FDA’s Catalog of Regulatory Science Tools, and uniquely well positioned to greatly facilitate the development, assessment, and translation of emerging AI-based imaging products.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Although many prelingually-deaf infants who receive a cochlear implant do not develop optimal auditory perception skills, clinical auditory speech perception tests are not administered until children are approximately 4 years old. The proposed research will investigate how perception of acoustic modulation, an important factor for speech understanding, develops in CI infants and how it predicts later speech perception. This work will help lead to clinical measures of device efficacy and auditory benefit for CI infants which will enable earlier, and more impactful, clinical interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This collaborative, innovative and high impact interdisciplinary project (continuing renewal of our ongoing caries risk study U01-DE021412-11) provides a unique opportunity to assess U.S. children over time culminating with much needed access and focus on adolescence- a life stage in which people have persistent caries problems over the last few decades, is challenging to recruit, and has been largely neglected in oral health research, practice, and policy. The relevance, impact, and significance of the project is that it will result in the creation of critically important and novel prediction models, and understanding of relationships among oral and systemic health risk factors and comorbidities into early adolescence, which is essential to designing future implementation efforts to target efficient, cost-effective, preventive, person-centered care for dental caries, as well as collaborative interprofessional care to reduce disparities and improve adolescents' health. This proposal is responsive to NIDCR’s 2021-2026 Strategic Plan Goals 2 [Develop more precise and individualized ways of managing and preventing oral and craniofacial diseases ] and 3 [Accelerate the translation of research and the uptake of new discoveries into oral and general healthcare practices that reduce health inequities and disparities and improve oral health outcomes for individuals and communities worldwide].

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) effects an estimated 5.8 million Americans with the number of patients expected to triple over the next 30 years, yet there are currently no medications that stop or prevent the disease. Critically, the identification of the mechanisms that precede the pathogenesis of AD and are distinct from normal healthy aging, which will be investigated in this application, will likely inform novel therapeutic strategies, including ones that may be used before the onset of disease symptoms which makes this project highly relevant to public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Currently, there remains a lack of research on integrated interventions to address co-occurring harms related to HIV/STI and overdose epidemics, particularly among sex workers, who face disproportionate HIV and STI burdens and severe gaps in access to evidence-based addiction services. While structural and system-level interventions such as community empowerment and changes in policing practices have strong potential to mitigate harms associated with overlapping HIV/STI and overdose epidemics, there remains a scarcity of data on how the implementation of such interventions impacts HIV/STI and overdose incidence and engagement with addiction services among sex workers. As such, the goal of this competing renewal is to evaluate the impacts of `naturally occurring' interventions of community empowerment (CE) and changes in policing practices on incidence of HIV/STIs and overdose (OD), and engagement with addiction services among street and indoor sex workers in an urban Canadian setting. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: We have found that as mice age or suffer from disease, they activate more and more of their white blood cells to release highly toxic material from their nuclei, called NETs, which induces both inflammation and thrombosis. Thrombotic events are now the biggest killer in United States and heart failure, caused by chronic inflammation, is on the rise. The goal of this application is to figure out how the release of NETs and its consequences could be inhibited to prevent thrombosis and improve the health of our aging population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Multiple myeloma, a bone marrow cancer characterized by the secretion of substantial quantities of abnormal antibodies (monoclonal protein), is currently considered to be incurable, and despite improvements in survival over the past decade, nearly all patients will die of their disease. We have developed a novel strategy to kill myeloma cells by disrupting monoclonal protein secretion via inhibition of Rab protein-mediated intracellular trafficking processes. The ultimate goal of the studies described herein is the development of novel therapeutic agents which can be used to safely and effectively treat multiple myeloma so that these patients may live longer and develop fewer complications from their disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Skeletal muscle is formed by protein filaments that slide past each other, pulled by miniature molecular motors that produce force and cause shortening. In healthy relaxed muscle, the motors are switched off in an energy-saving mode, while genetic mutations can damage the motors, causing increased energy usage and muscle diseases. We will use powerful microscopes to observe the atomic structure of these motors, illuminating how they work normally, malfunction in disease, and are repaired by drugs that restore or enhance their function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Knowledge of the etiology of type 2 diabetes (T2D), a pandemic that affects >400 million worldwide, is incomplete. Elevations in certain lipid moieties precede glucose abnormalities in animal models of type 2 diabetes, however, the longitudinal relationship between lipids and T2D in humans is unclear. Using two well- characterized cohorts with >10-year follow-up data from participants prospectively monitored for incident prediabetes, T2D and complications, our planned lipidomics analysis will provide novel data on the role of specific lipid signatures (sphingolipids and ceramides) during the transition from normal glucose regulation through prediabetes to nascent diabetes and diabetes complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Current approaches for treatment of organ injury has focused on the delivery of growth factors or stem cells without any major benefit, in which fibrotic scarring interfere with functional integrity of the damaged organs. We have shown that specialized endothelial cells lining the blood vessels in each organ by production of unique growth factors could support organ repair without provoking fibrosis or tumorigenesis. To translate the potential of endothelial cells for regenerative medicine to clinic, we have proposed experiments to understand how endothelial cells acquire organ-specific functions to optimize their efficacy in regeneration, with the intention of transplantation these tissue-specified ECs to augment the repair of lung, blood and broken hearts without scarring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  PUBLIC HEALTH RELAVENCE Synthetic drugs of abuse, including stimulants (e.g., cathinones, methamphetamine) and opioids (e.g., fentanyl) are associated with high rates of abuse and toxicity, and although these drugs are often used as mixtures (e.g., multiple stimulants, or stimulants and opioids), relatively little is known about how interactions among them drugs impact their abuse-related and toxic effects. This project combines well-established animal models of abuse (self-administration) and toxicity (cardiovascular recordings) with quantitative analysis to determine the nature of the interactions between the abuse-related and toxic effects of stimulant-opioid drug mixtures that are at the center of the current polysubstance abuse epidemic. Together, results of the proposed studies will provide essential information about the complexities associated with the co-use of multiple substances from different pharmacological classes that will ultimately advance efforts to develop novel and effective treatments for abuse-related and toxic effects of polysubstance abuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Compared to men, late-life women are at greater risk of cerebral small vessel disease, bear a greater burden of Alzheimer’s disease, and may develop Alzheimer’s disease via different pathways. NIH has recently prioritized understanding sex differences in Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias, specifically highlighting sex in its high priority research area in epidemiology of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding whether cerebral small vessel disease can explain sex differences in the Alzheimer’s disease pathophysiological cascade in the population at large can provide insight into markers of target engagement and sex-specific intervention targets which could be used to reduce Alzheimer’s disease dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE As the organism ages, adult regenerative neural stem cell niches no longer produce new neurons. Adult neurogenic niches have been found to be important for aspects of learning and memory, raising the intriguing possibility that boosting the production of neurons by these niches may help preserve or enhance cognitive function with advancing age. Uncovering the immune-based mechanisms underlying the decline and rejuvenation of adult neurogenic niches during aging should give important insights into the factors that control regeneration in the normal aging nervous system as well as in age-related neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed project will answer key questions to inform the HIV, oncology, and geriatric clinical management of older people living with HIV (PLWH) diagnosed with a non-AIDS defining cancer (NADC). In order to disentangle the influence of HIV from the socio-behavioral factors associated HIV acquisition, we will leverage claims data from more than 5 million Medicaid beneficiaries across 14 states between 2001-2017 which provides an appropriate comparison population for older (i.e., >50 years of age), low income PLWH. Findings from this study will inform how aging in the presence of HIV affects the risk and consequences of non-AIDS defining cancers, and impacts HIV care and age-related outcomes among older adults.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The rapid adoption of mobile and interactive technologies by American families has outpaced research on their potential effects on child development and health. This project proposes to examine how the mobile media use of parents and young children predict changes in child executive functioning from 2 to 4 years, potential mechanisms such as displacement of parent-child interaction and executive function-building activities, and whether these effects are moderated by child sex or psychosocial stressors. The novel forms of media measurement used in this project – including mobile sampling and coding of interactive design affordances – will allow study results to reflect the complex ways in which modern media are used within families’ everyday lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The human visual system has the remarkable ability to quickly and ﬂexibly combine visual features, like shape and color, into the coherent objects that we perceive, enabling effective interaction with the world. In this project, we use state-of-the-art techniques in deep learning and neuroimaging to synthesize two inﬂuential theories for how the visual system accomplishes this feat. Understanding this fundamental visual operation will both en- able implementing it in useful machines, like self-driving cars, to improve public safety and industrial efﬁciency, and help develop treatments for patients with neurological deﬁcits in combining visual features (such as Balint's syndrome or visual agnosia).

PHR: Project Narrative Acute kidney injury (AKI) is a global public health concern impacting about 13 million patients every year, and currently has no FDA-approved drugs for its prevention or treatment. Therefore, there is a great need for developing effective therapies for AKI that is associated with high morbidity and mortality. The proposed research is relevant to public health as it will develop novel therapeutic intervention that can treat AKI whose pathogenesis involves activation of inflammatory and apoptotic pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Pulmonary fibrosis, the scarring process of the lung, is usually irreversible and potentially fatal. We propose experiments to determine how mechanical properties of the fibrotic environment modulate macrophage phenotype/immunity through metabolic reprogramming. These studies will lead to a greater understanding of the development of pulmonary fibrosis and provide novel therapeutic targets for drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to identify novel positive and negative regulators of protection against Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the single deadliest pathogen in the world. Leveraging exciting preliminary data of Mtb-infected lungs analyzed by single cell RNA-sequencing, this project will identify pathways used by macrophages to restrict tuberculosis growth, as well as identify the mechanism by which neutrophils inhibit productive responses against this infection. Discovering new immune regulators of tuberculosis control will provide targets for host-directed therapies, which are in dire need due to lack of an efficacy vaccine and extremely long antibiotic treatment course for tuberculosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Spinal motoneurons are the final common pathway to all movement and receive 30-50,000+ synapses per cell, majority of which come from pre-motor interneuronal networks. Peripheral nerve injury promotes plasticity of spinal circuits resulting in persistent motor deficits such as a loss in the stretch reflex and muscle co-contraction. The objective of this award is to investigate two sources of circuit dysregulation that impact motor performance following axotomy: aberrant synaptogenesis in the deep dorsal horn and the loss of presynaptic inhibition on propriosensors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE RNA oxidation precedes motor neuron degeneration in ALS, yet its consequences in the context of disease are not understood. This project seeks to identify the effects of RNA oxidation on several aspects of RNA processing and the cellular mechanisms by which it might lead to neuronal death. If successful, this work will clarify the molecular mechanisms underlying RNA oxidation and identify potential therapeutic intervention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative Motor impairments are among the most debilitating symptoms in a wide range of neurodegenerative disorders, including Parkinson's disease. This project will determine the role of distinct subpopulations of neurons in parafascicular (PF) thalamus in regulating locomotion and motor learning processes, which are commonly disrupted in movement disorders. By characterizing the dysfunction of PF subpopulations in a mouse model of Parkinson's disease, this project will identify PF circuit manipulations capable of treating multiple motor phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Neuromodulation is a biomedical technology that acts directly upon nerves by delivering an electrical stimulus, chemical agent, or energetic wave to a target neuroanatomical site. Of the various forms in clinical use or development, ultrasound neuromodulation is an appealing modality because it uninvasively combines high spatial resolution and depth with the ability to physiologically modulate excitable cells in endogenous and genetically modified tissues. Fundamental knowledge on the biophysical mechanisms of the actuators utilized in ultrasound neuromodulation—mechanosensitive ion channels—will aid in modulating cellular electrical excitability, engineering sonogentic tools, and translating laboratory findings to a clinical setting to help promote a modern era of minimally invasive ultrasound-based neuromodulatory treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal seeks to characterize how different combinations of transcription factors in neurons instruct them to acquire their cell-type specific morphology, connectivity and physiology during development. Understanding the regulatory mechanisms that underlie neuronal diversity of the visual circuits will enable adult or induced stem cells to be differentiated into neurons that can precisely and predictably integrate into existing neural circuits, and will provide new approaches to treat blindness, brain injury and neurodegeneration. Through computational modeling of gene regulatory networks, the project aims to discover new molecular mechanisms that mediate synapse-specific wiring of the brain, which will help the development of effective treatments for a variety of neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Temporal lobe epilepsy is highly refractory to drug treatment and, when possible, requires surgical removal of the “focus”, which is still unsuccessful in many cases. The proposed experiments employ cutting-edge techniques to determine if the “focus” actually involves more distributed brain networks, offering a potential explanation for the failure of invasive surgeries. Looking towards future therapies, this project tests whether non- invasive neuromodulation with ultrasound, focused on a key node of this extended network, is able to control seizures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Knee and limb underloading are ubiquitous after anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) reconstruction and fails to resolve with the standard of care rehabilitation. This underloading behavior is clinically concerning and considered maladaptive, as it affects patient function, has been linked to risk for re-injury, and appears to be a precursor for post-traumatic knee osteoarthritis that affects upwards of 50% of patients who undergo an ACL reconstruction. This application will lay the foundation for a novel split-belt training paradigm to improve knee and limb loading after ACL reconstruction by identifying the optimal split-belt treadmill training parameters to elicit both acute and long-term improvements in loading mechanics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many trainees express an interest in research during residency training, but clinical demands limit the opportunity to engage in meaningful, longitudinal investigations and/or to acquire the fundamental skillsets that build the foundation of a clinician-investigator career. The overarching goal of the Pittsburgh Innovation in Collaborative Training of Residents Alliance, or PICTOR Alliance program, is to recruit, retain and accelerate independence of a pool of resident-investigators to perform basic translational and clinical translational research using a highly integrative approach that draws upon the experience of a diverse group of established investigators within four clinical departments (Medicine, Pathology, Pediatrics, and Surgery) focused on heart, lung, blood, and sleep research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This pilot project seeks to test the Promoting Positive Care Interaction (PPCI)—a theory-based four-step intervention including: 1) stakeholder engagement in developing facility specific goals; (2) environment and policy assessments; (3) flexible staff education; and (4) ongoing mentorship, motivation, and support (in- person visits and text messages) for staff in an effort to find the most effective way to improve daily care interactions between staff (nursing, activity, housekeeping, and dining service) and residents with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) in Assisted Living Facilities (ALFs). The proposed study will specifically help us to: 1) understand whether the four steps of PPCI can be conducted as planned, and 2) determine whether PPCI can improve selected resident outcomes (quality of life, agitation, and resistiveness to care), staff outcomes (quality of care interactions, knowledge, perceived competence related to care and communication, stress, and relationship quality), and organizational outcomes (environment and policies). This information will guide the future implementation of PPCI on a larger scale to further improve daily care interactions in ALFs and promote resident and staff well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid misuse and abuse are a rapidly evolving public health crisis. The proposed research could improve our knowledge of a potentially effective medication for heroin-induced adverse effects in nonhuman primate models. If proposed aims are achieved, this project will facilitate design of new treatment options that can ameliorate adverse consequences of using opioids afflicting a large population worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an existing gap of knowledge about the mechanisms that drive the development of depression in HIV infection and/or methamphetamine (METH) use. The central hypothesis of this proposal is that HIV and/or METH-induced inflammasome activation primes for depression. Our translation objective is to demonstrate that HIV infection and/or METH exposure contribute to, and accelerate the pathomechanisms of depression via the alterations of the gut-brain axis, which involves inflammasome activation and chronic brain neuroinflammatory responses.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Relevance  Many birth defects and a wide spectrum of highly prevalent cancers arise from aberrant regulation of the Hedgehog (Hh) signaling pathway. Most components of this pathway were first discovered in Drosophila and then found to have equivalent roles in mammals, leading to improved diagnoses of human disease and the development of promising anti-cancer drugs. Further progress in addressing these health issues will be spurred by a deeper understanding of the mechanism of Hh signaling, gained from the continued genetic analysis in Drosophila outlined in this project, focused on the key question of how the transcriptional effector of Hh signaling is activated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an antibiotic resistant ESKAPE pathogen, and an etiological agent of nosocomial pneumonia, sepsis, and acute lung injury (ALI). Despite the severity and prevalence of these debilitating conditions, there are currently no specific therapies available to facilitate treatment and augment patient recovery. This proposal will test the transformative concept that the P. aeruginosa T3SS effector ExoU induces an indirect cell lysis pathway via activation of gasdermin D-mediated pyroptosis – this novel pathway represents a potential target for the development of therapeutics to treat pneumonia, sepsis, and ALI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: What Precursors Become Lung-Resident CD4 Memory that Protect Against Respiratory Infections or Cause Lung Pathology? Respiratory infections, which include the major SARS and influenza pandemics of the 21st century as well as yearly influenza outbreaks, are a leading cause of mortality and morbidity across the world. This grant will define the pathway of development of an immune T cell type known as CD4 TRM that become resident in the lung where they can rapidly protect against respiratory infections but may also cause lung damage, so we will explore their mechanisms of protection and damage. The results will give us new insights into how to develop vaccines that efficiently induce protection in the lung and treatments that minimize lung damage during an immune response to respiratory infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The exacerbation of rising temperatures and urbanization poses an increased risk to vulnerable urban populations from heat exposure at night, as urban heat islands release heat slowly during summer nighttime. Although adaptation planning for high temperatures during the day has been developed and implemented at the city-wide or governmental levels, heat adaptation behaviors in individual households are less understood, particularly during nighttime hours. To gain insight into the combined effects of individual behaviors, built environment, and nighttime heat exposure on heat adaptation behavior in residential houses, we propose to (1) establish a Community Advisory Board, comprising local residents and academic researchers and (2) examine the collective impact of indoor home heat exposure, individual attributes, and built environment factors on individual-level heat adaptation behavior and provide guidance on effective heat adaptation strategies to community leaders and vulnerable residents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE - Enriching a Diverse Pregnancy Cohort from the San Francisco Bay Area to Expand Data Access and Individual Results Return on Environmental Exposures to Participant Communities We propose to enrich our existing Chemicals in our Body (CIOB) cohort of primarily Latina, White and Asian as well as Black mothers and children, by recruiting additional Black pregnant participants from Oakland, CA to improve our ability to address environmental contributors to health inequities. We will enhance the scope and methods of prenatal chemical measurements that integrate new neighborhood measures of structural racism and socioeconomic marginalization and facilitate analyses of multiple chemical and social stressor exposures on perinatal and maternal health. We will make our data available to the broader research community via an online repository, and report back individual-level chemical exposures to our participants to advance research, inform clinical practice, and elucidate opportunities for intervention and policy change to address the double jeopardy of environmental and social stressor exposures on maternal and perinatal health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Public Health Impact The current proposal is relevant to public health because discovering the variation of real world post-surgical physical therapy frequency and intervention type and effects on meaningful gait outcomes in children with cerebral palsy (CP) after orthopedic multi-level surgery (MLS) will inform future work to determine the most effective strategies to improve health and motor outcomes for children with CP after MLS. Thus, the proposed R03 application is relevant to the NCMRR and NICHD mission to 1) improve child and adolescent health in the context of disability, 2) examine frequency and intensity of specific intervention types during a sensitive period of rehabilitation, 3) examine person centered real world outcomes, and 4) address the need for innovative methods in research design by harnessing the power of electronic health record data to determine real world application of treatments and outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Secure attachment relationships set the foundation for later functioning, including social relationships, health, and well-being; yet, we know little about the daily contexts that foster attachment relationships between infants and those who care for them. Addressing the need for more ecologically-valid approaches to our understanding of children’s early caregiving experiences, this study uses the TotTag—a wearable device that can dynamically and unobtrusively measure patterns of physical proximity between children and caregivers continuously, regardless of location—to allow for assessments of time children spend in proximity to their caregiver in addition to caregiver sensitivity. The insights gained regarding the association between attachment security from two aspects of caregiving will help set the foundation for a better understanding of how caregiving behavior may promote attachment security.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Mutations in gene regulatory proteins during human development are a common cause of debilitating human disorders. The aim of this proposal is to implement a novel and highly tractable experimental platform to characterize the molecular functions of an understudied regulator of human peripheral nervous system development. Our work will yield novel insight into how molecular abnormalities that affect the nervous system arise and how they potentially can be reversed by targeted therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative A growing body of research shows that autism screening tools are not as accurate for identifying autism in Black and Hispanic children compared to White children. The current project uses rigorous methodologies to determine the sources of psychometric scoring inequities across Black, Hispanic, and White children on two popular autism screening tools, and quantify the impact on overall screener performance for Black and Hispanic children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to use a novel type of microscopy (pump-probe imaging) to image the aggressiveness (metastatic potential) in melanomas. This is important because the current diagnostic standard in humans has serious defects; for example, it misses many “thin lethal” cancers which are undertreated. Success will provide a simple method to improve patient outcome by identifying patients who were initially misdiagnosed as not having metastic cancer, and could significantly decrease treatment costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative With the strong overlapping macromolecule signal and its low concentration, lactate measurement is subject to low reliability with existing techniques either on 3 T or 7 T. HOPE (Half-intensity with macrOmolecule- suPprEssion) is the short-TE proton MRS we developed to suppress macromolecule signal and achieve substantial improvement of lactate measurements with significant higher reliability and usable data rate. We propose to measure lactate and other metabolites (e.g. glutamate, glutathione) in brain regions of white matter, gray matter and CSF in first episode and chronic schizophrenia in order to better understand the dynamic progression of lactate abnormalities in schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fetal growth restriction raises the risk of stillbirth and neonatal death. Currently, no effective therapeutic strategies exist to prevent or treat fetal growth restriction due, in part, to an incomplete understanding of the mechanisms regulating uteroplacental blood flow and fetal growth. This project will accelerate our understanding of the role of circulating metabolites in the regulation of uteroplacental blood flow and, in turn, fetal growth.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parents can help protect their adolescent children from experiencing adolescent relationship abuse (ARA), especially through parental monitoring. Parents accompany adolescents to well-child visits; therefore, the pediatric primary care setting is an ideal location to deliver an ARA prevention intervention. In this proposal, we will create and pilot test an ARA prevention intervention for middle school age adolescents and their parents, which can be delivered by healthcare providers in pediatric primary care settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: There is a paramount need for clinician scientists who are skilled in modern scientific methods and have the background to develop novel approaches to the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of infectious, immunologic, and allergic diseases in children and adults. The Duke NIAID Scientist-Clinician-Investigator Stimulating access to Research in Residency (Duke NIAID SCI-StARR) Program will continue the successful approach of providing dedicated research time and training to Resident-Investigators from the Departments of Medicine, Pediatrics, and Surgery to foster their maturation into independent physician-scientists who use cutting-edge methods of laboratory and clinical research to pursue long-term academic careers investigating important issues related to human health. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although shift workers, particularly those who work at night, are at a higher risk of severe cognitive impairment such as Alzheimer’s disease (AD), we do not have a biomarker sensitive enough to reflect the level of adaptation to shift work and predict the risk of future cognitive impairment. The proposed study aims to examine the feasibility of establishing a cohort of active and retired shift workers and generate preliminary data on whether objective sleep quality measures and/or epigenetic changes in circadian genes are associated with variation in symptoms related to shift work tolerance and cognitive function. Research findings will significantly impact public health by informing personalized, optimized biobehavioral strategies to prevent AD in the early stage of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patient activation, cognition, and self-management for LVADs Left-ventricular assist devices (LVADs) are the most complex machines ever designed for home use with difficult self-management (SM) and high health care use (HCU) but little is known about the factors influencing patient outcomes. Patient activation (PA) is the willingness and ability to manage a health condition and may offer unique opportunities for improving LVAD SM and HCU. We seek to understand the relationships between cognition, PA, LVAD SM, and HCU, and to explore PA as a mediator of the influence of cognition on outcomes, by studying patients prior to and within 12-months after LVAD surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While people required to register as sex offenders (PRR) under sex offender registration and notification (SORN) policies struggle with substance use at higher rates than the general population and have limited access to substance use treatment and other social services, no research has explored or addressed how the SORN policy context influences individual and macro-level substance use risk environments. This study will qualitatively explore how SORN policies influence PRR experiences with substance use, risk of substance use related harms, and access to treatment and harm reduction services, from the perspectives of PRR and stakeholders. Results from this proposed research will inform important future multi-level interventions that address policy and social determinants of substance use and co-occurring health issues for PRR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Project Narrative No studies have taken a systematic mechanistic approach to investigate how occupational exposure to tungsten affects the heart or cardiovascular disease risk factors, despite compelling epidemiological data linking tungsten exposure to increased cardiovascular disease risk. This project will investigate the effects of inhaled tungsten particulates on NRLP3 inflammasome activation of IL-1β signaling pathways, leading to cardiac remodeling and cardiovascular disease development. Discoveries from these studies with impact Research to Practice initiatives to inform identification of at-risk occupational populations, development of monitoring programs, and identification of effective counter measures to block immune fibroblast crosstalk, which could mitigate cardiovascular disease risk.

PROJECT_TITLE: Defining the Role of IL-1? in Tungsten-Mediated Cardiovascular Disease
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Evidence suggests, that endosomal microautophagy (eMi), a protein degradation pathway distinct from macro- and chaperone mediated autophagy, is impaired in Alzheimer’s disease. In the proposed experiments we will determine the impact of pathological tau on mitochondrial function and on various microautophagy pathway proteins. Further, we will directly stimulate eMi to determine if it can prevent or rescue tau induced dysfunction in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Neurocysticercosis (NCC) causes significant disability in regions of the world where populations are exposed to pigs and is increasingly reported, albeit typically at advanced stage, in the United States. No guidelines for early detection of NCC exist. This research will contribute to the fundamental knowledge of NCC prevalence in an at-risk US population (the household contacts of NCC patients) and identify an effective NCC screening approach that will detect and prevent future NCC cases, thereby reducing disability due to NCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Due to the rapid nature of innovation in cancer research, challenges exist in training and retaining physician- scientists conducting rigorous translational research. The Columbia Cancer Research Training Program for Resident-Investigators (CAPRI) addresses the critical shortage of well-trained cancer physicians from multiple disciplines. The continuation of CAPRI, which provides comprehensive research training, will ensure a cadre of future clinical investigators who will conduct high-impact research spanning the cancer care continuum.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Though, several studies including our own have demonstrated that RNAs are targeted to synapses and that these RNAs play a critical role in memory storage, we do not know much about RNAs localized to specific synapses in vivo. In this proposal, by characterizing RNAs associated with a GFP tagged molecular motor protein KIF5C, we will isolate and characterize KIF5C targeted RNAs in ventral hippocampus-medial prefrontal cortical and ventral hippocampus-basolateral amygdala synapses. Successful completion of these studies will assess whether populations of RNAs become selectively enriched in specific synapses in vivo and their significance in the consolidation of contextual fear memory.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE A parent's history of adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) can increase their child's obesity risk, though this association is not well understood. The impact of neighborhood environment is particularly understudied, despite its influence on both ACEs and obesity risk. This study will examine the relationship between a parent's history of ACEs, their child's obesity, and the family's neighborhood environment, in order to inform targeted place-based approaches to reducing obesity for millions of individuals affected by ACEs and obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The Boston University-Boston Medical Center (BU-BMC) Multi-Disciplinary Program for Promoting Research In MEdical Residency (PRIMER) will provide comprehensive ~2-year (contiguous 22 months of protected research time at 80% effort; 17.6 months of exclusive research time) transdisciplinary training for two internal medicine residents every year for the duration of the grant to pursue research in heart, lung, blood and sleep (HLBS) diseases, while ensuring their clinical training and medicine board eligibility, and transition to a K38 award as part of a clinical HLBS fellowship. The goals of PRIMER include mentored research under the guidance of a well-funded senior BU-BMC faculty member in one of four HLBS training tracks, career guidance by a senior mentor, professional development, and acquisition of key competencies for clinical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it is aimed at 1) increasing knowledge of the impacts of exposure to humanitarian emergencies on substance use and the development of substance use disorders and 2) informing methods of preventing substance use disorders among people affected by humanitarian emergencies. This project will evaluate the prevalence of substance use among internally displaced persons in Ukraine and adapt a substance use prevention intervention, likely Acceptance and Commitment Therapy-based sessions, specifically for use among this population. The proposed research is directly relevant to NIDA’s 2022-2026 Strategic Plan for Research via its focus on testing innovative approaches to prevent substance use disorders in real-world settings and has specific relevance for domestic populations in the United States, particularly the rising numbers of refugees and other individuals migrating due to the increasing number of global humanitarian crises.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative The infectious disease tuberculosis (TB) is spread primarily through the air and kills over a million people every year. This proposal uses a new technique to better understand how subsets of the bacteria that cause TB, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, can survive stresses such as drying out and being exposed to antibiotics. Eventually, this may aid in finding methods of curing TB patients more quickly as well as preventing spread of the disease.
