IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE  Interactions between the pathogenic Porphyromonas gingivalis and Fusobacterium nucleatum in the oral cavity exacerbates periodontal disease. There is a critical need for narrow spectrum antibacterials that selectively eliminate these bacteria, while sparing the beneficial bacteria in the mouth. This research proposes to characterize and advance a key enzyme in the bacterial fatty acid synthesis pathway, enoyl-ACP reductase II (FabK), as a narrow spectrum target for antibacterial therapy of periodontal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Physician scientists and surgeon scientists are critical to research, innovations and novel therapeutics that improve the health and wellness of our nation. Research today provides hope and the foundation for new treatments and cures for tomorrow. The Ohio State University (OSU) R38 StARR Program aims to train Resident-Investigators in clinical training programs at the OSU Wexner Medical Center to pursue research relevant to immune mediated diseases, infections and novel immunotherapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: U24 Narrative The childhood physical and social home environment is critical for development, as children and adolescents are uniquely sensitive to environmental exposures and the home represents a large portion of their exposome. We have collected prospective data starting in pregnancy for 650 participants now entering adolescence and now seek to characterize their home exposome, including racism experienced, economic factors, as well as chemical exposures to conduct exposomic research that robustly informs how environment influences health in adolescence and into adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed summer program (Engaging Multidisciplinary Professional Opportunities for Women in Environmental Research) EMPOWER 2.0 will create research educational activities centered on the four steps of risk assessment—hazard characterization, dose-response relationships, exposure assessment, and risk characterization—to assess environmental contaminants in air and water found in Atlanta neighborhoods. We will provide hands-on training for high school students and teachers in air quality monitoring, environmental sampling, and toxicological assessment of model compounds to simulate exposure of ambient particulate matter, and bacteria commonly found in contaminated water.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Fifty years ago, Michigan residents were exposed to polybrominated biphenyls (PBBs), a persistent endocrine- disrupting chemical through their food and work. The Michigan PBB environmental epidemiology cohort (EEC) now includes over 7500 individuals and three generations but lacks representation from Michigan’s urban residents and younger people who were exposed to PBB in childhood or in utero, both of whom may have unique exposures and health concerns. The diversification of the Michigan PBB EEC and expansion of data sharing will allow future researchers to address health disparities, particularly within the context of the exposome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Relevance HIV/AIDS remains an important threat to global public health; at least 38 million people are currently infected with HIV-1 and only ~68% are being treated with anti-retroviral drugs. A vaccine to protect against HIV-1/AIDS is urgently needed, especially in the developing world. Here, we will use novel mouse and primate animal models to decipher the developmental pathways of protective neutralizing antibodies and use this information to improve our immunization regimens, concentrating on developing sequential priming and boosting immunogens that prevent elicitation of off-target antibodies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Well-characterized longitudinal epidemiological cohorts are crucial resources for identifying novel risk factors, examining exposure-outcome associations, and determining the role of biomarkers in disease development and progression. The Survey of the Health of Wisconsin (SHOW) – a cohort representative of the state of Wisconsin has baseline and longitudinal follow-up data and environmentally annotated biological specimens on participants who consented for use of their data and specimens in future unspecified research, which makes SHOW an invaluable resource for environmental epidemiology research. We propose SHOW-Forward to further expand and diversify the SHOW cohort and establish the SHOW Real World Data Collaborative infrastructure to ensure enduring access for the scientific community to well-characterized and rich cohort data, including social determinants of health, multiple exposures, health outcomes, and biological specimens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Research supported by NIAID has allowed scientists to use recent advances in DNA analysis to provide the research community with millions of antibody sequences from healthy individuals and from patients with autoimmune disorders. This proposal is designed to develop a strategy that uses this information to improve and lower the cost of therapeutic antibodies which today are one of the most effective strategies for treating a variety of illnesses including cancer, allergies, infections, and cardiovascular diseases. The results of this work may also be used in future studies to develop new and more effective therapies for the treatment of autoimmune illnesses such as multiple sclerosis and lupus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance use and co-occurring mental health concerns continue to be a major public health concern among youth in the foster care system making access to substance use prevention services a key priority. Digital behavioral health technologies have the potential to rapidly and efficiently increase access to prevention resources and interventions, but linkage to such available technologies requires facilitation by systems already serving these youth. The proposed Hybrid II mixed methods study will evaluate implementation effectiveness of a telementoring program with Court Appointed Special Advocates (CASA) to increase foster youth referrals to a digital behavioral health app (FostrSpace) and determine FostrSpace's effectiveness in preventing youth substance use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Pre-pregnancy obesity has long been associated with indicators of impaired emotion regulation in children – e.g., increased rates of psychiatric disorders with emotion regulation deficits such as depressive and anxiety disorders. Our proposal aims to test the overarching mechanistic hypothesis that pre-pregnancy maternal obesity negatively influences emotion regulation and thus increases risk for psychopathology in children through its effects on the maternal gut microbiome and metabolome. The project will include the collection of demographic, clinical, behavioral, and neuroimaging data, as well as microbiome and metabolomic data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENT A major health challenge facing our society is a pervasive range of neurological disorders, which becomes more acute as our population ages. The goal of this project is to continue support of a summer residential research program at the University of Minnesota with the goal of inspiring new generations of bright, talented undergraduate students to enter neuroscience research as a career. The hope is that these future scientists will contribute to the health infrastructure by finding cures for these common, but devastating diseases of the nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Proper control of inflammation within the gastrointestinal (GI) tract is critical for human health, yet many aspects of how this is regulated remain unclear. We will investigate the role of small lipid extracellular vesicles called exosomes in conferring immune regulation in the GI tract during health and inflammatory disease. This work will contribute to the development of novel biomarker and therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease that involve exosomes and their cargo.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project applies innovative research methodology to four real-world databases to further elucidate the extent to which cognitive-behavioral correlates of reading comprehension act as risk- (deficits) vs. protective factors (strengths) for the development of poor reading comprehension in the face of adequate decoding (i.e., specific reading comprehension deficit) across the full distribution of readers. The current proposal aims to (1) investigate the nature of specific reading comprehension deficit in large representative samples of childhood and adolescent readers and (2) identify domain-specific, domain-general, and social skills-related correlates of specific reading comprehension deficit. Findings generated from this proposal have multiple implications for research, policy, and practice, including the ability to inform theoretical frameworks, hypotheses, and approaches aimed at understanding reading comprehension difficulties as well as develop more accurate identification methods, better prevention, and more efficacious intervention programs to effectively support children who struggle to comprehend text.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Paneth cell -defensins are antimicrobial peptides proposed to have two interrelated and fundamental functions: shaping the composition of the colonizing microbiota and contributing to innate immunity in the intestinal tract. These functions predict profound influence on human health. The proposed research will generate and characterize two complementary new mouse models to investigate Paneth cell -defensin function with a focus on the dramatic and physiologically driven intestinal changes that accompany maternal lactation, a critical but understudied window of mammalian biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) shows progressive histological and behavioral hallmarks correlated with increased genomic instability. We will study the role of Y-family DNA polymerase, Pol kappa (Polk) that can bypass unstable DNA lesions to maintain cell survival in post-mitotic neurons in healthy aging and AD genotype condition. Now immunostaining data provide compelling rationale that neuronal Polk nuclear expression is correlated with aging and AD, hence we will identify its associated repair pathways in neurons, establish Polk interactomes in neuronal nuclei and investigate Polk's protective role in maintaining neuronal genomic stability.

PHR: PROGRAM NARRATIVE There is a pressing need for a diverse workforce of physician scientists who have the skillsets to conduct rigorous interdisciplinary scientific research and develop novel approaches for improving diagnosis and treatment of human disease. To this end, the Tulane StARR program will provide a mentored research and career development program for medicine and pediatric residents to increase the number and diversity of highly trained physician scientists in heart, lung, and blood diseases research. The program engages outstanding preceptors with established track records of mentoring and conducting highly meritorious research, and will foster the next generation of physician scientists able to make discoveries and translate discoveries into improved human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Our study will inform novel appraisal of whether epigenetic age can be used to identify colon cancer patients at high risk for chemotherapy toxicity, dose reductions, and delays, and whether a resistance training intervention can reduce the rate of epigenetic aging, to mitigate that risk. Building on this analysis, we will evaluate whether epigenetic age can identify patients at greater risk for poor prognosis. We contend epigenetic age has the capacity to inform more personalized approaches to treating colon cancer patients to improve long-term outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Project Narrative Human papillomaviruses (HPVs) are highly transmissible causative agents of benign and malignant tumors in mucosal and cutaneous squamous epithelium and pose significant health and economic burdens in the US and worldwide. Building on our finding that the inhibition of cellular MEK signaling suppresses papillomavirus early gene transcription, we plan to formulate and optimize MEK inhibitory drugs for the treatment of pathogenic papillomavirus infections. Successful completion of this work will position us to carry out clinical trials investigating MEK inhibitors as the first antiviral therapies for papillomavirus-induced diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Daily continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) use is recommended for adults with type 1 diabetes (T1D) and can reduce the burden of diabetes management and improve health outcomes as a standalone tool and as a component of newer closed loop systems; yet, not everyone who adopts CGM sustains use over time. This project expands upon the parent K23 aims by applying mixed methods to investigate: remaining modifiable drivers of CGM discontinuation, including emotional distress; and factors associated with lower CGM usage and discontinuation. Results from these study aims will inform further optimization and tailoring of the ONBOARD intervention to promote sustained CGM use, which will in turn further maximize readiness for closed loop system adoption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Our proposed research is relevant to public health and addresses NIH RFA-TR-22-030 for Investigating Understudied Proteins since we aim to generate an improved understanding of three chromodomain- helicase-DNA-binding (CHD) proteins that are understudied and implicated in multiple rare diseases including Chiari Malformation. We will use advanced cell-free expression techniques combined with microscale reaction volumes to generate functional wild type and disease related mutant CHD proteins. We will then begin structural characterization using cryo-Electron Microscopy and Native Mass Spectrometry to reveal their molecular similarities and differences that influence DNA binding and protein-protein interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Chemical Biology Training Program (CBTP) supports a robust and rigorous training environment for Ph.D. students drawn from the Departments of Chemistry and Molecular and Cell Biology at UC Berkeley. The program will train students in the use of chemical approaches to study and manipulate biological systems, preparing them for diverse academic and translational careers in biotechnology, pharmaceutical industries, and medicine. In addition to classroom teaching and hands-on research training, the program will engage the students in career development activities, establish internships with industrial partners, foster the advancement of diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging, provide training in rigorous, reproducible, and responsible research, and build a culture of laboratory safety.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Anal (fecal) incontinence after childbirth is a significant public health problem estimated to affect 15-25% of women in the United States. This study aims to investigate whether a novel combination of neurotrophic and antifibrotic agents will prevent anal sphincter dysfunction in a preclinical animal model. These studies have a great potential for clinical translation to prevent childbirth injury related anal incontinence in women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE WHO wants novel, highly sensitive, and ultra-specific lateral flow assays (LFA) to support its endeavors to eliminate onchocerciasis, a disease also known as river blindness affecting 18 million people, with another 218 million living at risk of contracting the disease. Onchocerciasis is fought by mass drug administration (MDA). WHO critically needs new diagnostic tests to support decisions to start and stop MDA programs and released in 2021 the corresponding desired target product profiles (TPPs). The most stringent TPP criterion is that the test must be extraordinarily specific (≥ 99.8%). Built in a novel biplex format, our test detects IgG4 antibodies specific to two antigens of O. volvulus, the causative pathogen of onchocerciasis. Our test already meets both TPPs and, remarkably, its specificity is >99.8% even at the lower bound 95% CI. Based on independent evaluation performed at CDC, which confirmed these results, USAID has already committed funding to evaluate the assay in the field on approximately 10,000 individuals. Given these exciting results, the massive relevance for public health, and the big momentum already garnered with key players (USAID, CDC, Task Force for Global Health), we are now requesting Direct-to-Phase II funding to swiftly progress the assay to manufacturing and commercialization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Epigenetic cancer therapies hold great promise as alternative treatment for a variety of human cancers. The present proposal attempts to develop chemical modulators of a key epigenetic regulator of gene transcription: the polycomb repressive complex 2. This complex of proteins is responsible for the methylation of lysine 27 at histone 3 (H3K27me3), a highly repressive histone mark whose dysregulation is strongly linked to a wide array of metastatic malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Public Health Relevance We have developed an efficacious intervention to promote physical activity adoption among breast cancer survivors. The intervention has been implemented successfully by peer mentors at the American Cancer Society. However, to reach more survivors and scale up the intervention so that it can be used by other cancer care organizations in the US that also have peer mentoring programs, we propose to adapt and modify our intervention (Moving Forward Together) using a web platform that has already shown success in supporting peer mentoring for medication adherence and dietary changes in other patient groups such as those with poorly-controlled diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Endothelial cells regulate arterial contractility. Dysfunctional endothelial cell control of contractility is a hallmark of several cardiovascular diseases, including hypertension, but pathological mechanisms involved are poorly understood. We will investigate the novel hypothesis that PKD1 and PKD2 proteins regulate arterial contractility, investigate signaling mechanisms involved and test the concept that vasodilation mediated through these pathways is dysfunctional during hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Survivors of early-stage cancers are susceptible to cardiovascular disease due to pre-existing cardiovascular risk factors and receipt of potentially cardiotoxic cancer treatments. Our automated electronic health record (EHR)-based tool addresses the growing burden of cardiovascular disease among cancer survivors in the United States by empowering oncologists to discuss cardiovascular health with their patients and facilitating appropriate care for cardiovascular disease risk factors. In this study, we will test whether our pragmatic EHR-based cardiovascular health tool – which incorporates patient risk factor and cancer treatment data – will improve cardiovascular health discussion, completed visits, and cardiovascular risk factors in a real-world setting, with the ultimate goal of improving cancer survivors' morbidity and mortality. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE Oklahomans, on average, suffer from poor health combined with lower educational attainment. There is a need to expand scientific education at all levels, with a particular need to train a diverse cadre of doctoral students who can assume university-level faculty positions, and thus serve as role models and mentors for younger students. The Post-Baccalaureate Research and Education Program focuses on recruiting and training promising, under-represented students so that they can be competitive for admission into biomedical doctoral programs, and ultimately become skilled scientists and advocates for a scientific approach to decision-making.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The public health relevance of this project lies in its comprehensive approach to studying the genetic and sociocultural contributions to the development of childhood and adolescent sleep and health in an ethnically and socioeconomically diverse sample. The results yield a better, genetically-informed understanding of developmental pathways among sleep and health during puberty to identify dynamic processes that longitudinally predict mental health and inflammation. The knowledge to be gained informs intervention and prevention through identification of modifiable targets that impact adolescent sleep and health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH: Our studies are relevant to the development of vascular calcification (“hardening of the arteries”), which is a frequent and clinically important complication of vascular disease. The goal is to understand how the so-called endothelial cells, derived from capillaries and the inner lining of vessels, contribute to the formation of calcified vessels. Such understanding may be used to develop new strategies to specifically target the endothelial cells in limiting vascular calcification.

PHR: Project Narrative Hyperactive signaling by the G protein ? q subunit (G? q) is known to contribute to cardiac hypertrophy and heart disease, the latter of which is the leading cause of death in the developed world. This proposal will investigate how G? q signaling leads to cardiac hypertrophy by (1) probing for novel target proteins downstream of G? q and (2) determining whether any of these targets are involved in cardiomyocyte hypertrophy or apoptosis. These efforts will afford valuable insights into G? q signaling and may inform therapeutic strategies against heart disease.

PHR: More than half of all proteins in nature are decorated or modified by sugar structures called ‘glycans’. This project aims to collect a vast amount of molecular data related to biological and biochemical processes that regulate cellular glycosylation, and to organize these in a query-able computational framework. Such studies aim to outline the fundamental mechanisms regulating glycosylation in blood cells participating in innate immunity, and related leukocyte-endothelial cell adhesion processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Medulloblastoma is a common and highly malignant childhood brain tumor. Although current therapies are effective in some patients, over 70% of the MB patients with GLI2-amplification suffer from tumor relapse that eventually leads to death. In this application, we propose identifying the underlying mechanisms of tumorigenesis and developing novel and focused therapeutic approaches to combat this devastating disease effectively.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE (PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT) Our studies are directly relevant to the missions of the Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD) Fertility and Infertility Branch “to encourage, enable, and support scientific research aimed at alleviating human infertility, uncovering new possible pathways to control fertility, and expanding fundamental knowledge of processes that underlie human reproduction” and the NICHD Contraception Research Branch to develop “new and improved methods of contraception”. Despite the abundance of genes expressed in post-natal male germ cells (~4% of the mammalian genome), the functions of many of these genes and the pathways through which they act remain unknown. To address this deficiency and respond to the NICHD Strategic Plan 2020, our R01 renewal proposal will focus on placing six male fertility-essential proteins into molecular, biochemical, and genetic pathways “to understand human development”, translate this information to “improve reproductive health” by enabling the diagnosis and treatment of conditions in which these pathways are disrupted in men, and apply this knowledge to develop novel non-hormonal male contraceptives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Acetaminophen (paracetamol), the most commonly used painkiller, is safe when used within therapeutic doses, but its overdose can lead to liver injury, liver failure, and even death. While pathways that trigger acetaminophen-induced liver injury have been extensively studied, those that lead to disease progression or recovery from acetaminophen toxicity are poorly understood. This project will investigate how liver toxicity is halted and liver repair is controlled endogenously during acetaminophen-induced liver injury. The proposed studies are expected to uncover previously unknown regenerative mechanisms in the liver and suggest new therapeutic approaches against acetaminophen-induced liver disease.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed research is relevant to public health because rates of obesity and eating disorders are increasing and there are significant health and financial costs associated with this increase. Understanding the neural mechanisms that underlie feeding, and especially those underlying non-homeostatic feeding, which can drive feeding in the absence of energy deficit, is necessary to identify new targets and approaches to treat obesity and other eating disorders. Thus, this proposal is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to fostering fundamental basic science discoveries, using innovative approaches, with the goal of ultimately improving health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Natural killer (NK) cells can recognize and kill cancer cells; however, their use in adoptive cancer therapy has been limited by several factors including limited supply of cells and host immune responses that interfere with NK cell survival and targeting of cancer cells. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Proper cell division requires proteins in the kinetochore complex to sense tension exerted on chromosomes to ensure they are segregated correctly. Although harmful genome imbalance known as aneuploidy results when this process goes awry, the regulation and molecular details of this tension-sensing activity remain unknown. In this proposal, we will investigate how cells regulate protein factors to control kinetochore tension-sensing and also how these proteins function to carry out these mechanisms, which will give insight into how aneuploidy arises and how to prevent it.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Tissues of the female reproductive tract, and the endometrium in particular, undergo cycles of proliferation and differentiation that are coordinated by the female sex hormones estradiol and progesterone, respectively. We recently established that members of the progesterone receptor membrane component (PGRMC) family are essential for estradiol-induced proliferation of epithelial tissue within the endometrium. In this application, we seek to establish the mechanism(s) by which these proteins function to ensure that estradiol-induced proliferation is allowed to normally occur.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epidemiology and population genetics suggest that non-familial forms of PD (90% of PD cases) result from a complex interaction between age, genetic, and environmental risk factors. Elucidating how non-coding risk variants and their target genes, specifically glycoprotein nonmetastatic melanoma protein B (GPNMB), functionally contribute to disease pathogenesis will facilitate identification of new therapeutic targets for etiological treatment of PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is the leading cause of cancer related deaths worldwide with frequent recurrence and limited treatment options. Despite advances in immune checkpoint therapies, a disconnect remains in patient expression and treatment response, highlighting the need to determine the mechanisms that facilitate therapeutic resistance. Our proposed studies will uncover mechanisms of immune checkpoint expression and define a new targeted treatment for lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Evaluating the Influence of Culture and Risk Perception on HPV Vaccination Intention among Haitian Immigrant Women Living with HIV Project Narrative Affective dimensions of risk perception and cultural worldviews may have a significant role in Haitian immigrant women’s intention of undergoing HPV vaccination. When there is no prior experience of a disease, and minimal knowledge is available, emotions along with cultural influences can shape an individual’s appraisal of their disease risk and guide their behavior decisions. This proposed study aims to understand how affective dimensions of risk perception, which are shaped by cultural worldviews, influence the HPV vaccination intention among Haitian immigrant women with and without HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Given the foundational importance of early brain development for subsequent psychopathology, it is imperative to capture children’s everyday experiences with their caregivers in relation to changes in infant brain development. Addressing the need for more ecologically-valid approaches to our understanding of children’s early experiences, this study uses a newly developed wearable device that can dynamically, unobtrusively, and continuously measure patterns of physical proximity between children and caregivers, regardless of location. The proposed project will yield extraordinary insight into the early environment from a child-centered perspective during the first 18 months of life, with relevance to NIMH’s mission to determine the biological and psychological mechanisms by which the environments affect neural and behavioral development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicide is the second-leading cause of death among adolescents ages 10-14, making identification of risk factors for self-injurious thoughts and behaviors (SITBs) in early adolescence a research priority. Weight discrimination, among the most common types of discrimination reported by adolescents, might be one such risk factor and may disproportionately impact sexual and gender minority (SGM) adolescents who are at particularly high risk of SITBs. The proposed study will analyze associations between weight discrimination and SITBs and whether they differ for SGM adolescents in a large national sample of early adolescents, informing future interventions to promote mental health, prevent suicide, and reduce disparities in this population by addressing social determinants of health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE Current approaches for the diagnosis of early breast cancer (i.e. mammograms) in particular in women with dense breast tissue have major limitations leading to delayed or missed diagnoses as well as false positive results. This research will develop a new ultrasound imaging platform that allows diagnosing breast cancer with high sensitivity and specificity to enable rapid and effective detection of breast cancer at an early, still curable stage. The widespread and easy availability of ultrasound system in the clinics further improve the applicability this technique and save the lives of many patients through early diagnosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Malignant relapse is the biggest reason for failure in treatment of lymphoma. Natural killer (NK) cells can target lymphoma, and we will study genetically engineered, off-the-shelf NK cells directed to multiple targets on lymphoma as new “smart bomb” cellular treatments to limit relapse. Future improvements to enhance NK cell persistence and potency may make this therapy safer, cheaper, and even more effective.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Microglia, which comprise nearly 10-15% of total cells within the mammalian brain, have been linked to neurodegeneration. To understand the mechanisms of microglia-driven neurodegeneration we propose to identify genes that drive microglia-mediated neuronal damage. The identification of genes that govern microglial inflammatory and neurotoxic activation are important for the development of novel therapeutic approaches against neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Chronic non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) of the liver is a public health priority because it leads to scarring, or fibrosis, and is the fastest rising cause of primary liver cancer development, affecting millions of individuals worldwide. We propose to clarify the behavior of fibrogenic cells known as hepatic stellate cells that generate scar in this disease, and characterize how they contribute to primary liver cancer. New insights expected to emerge from these studies could significantly advance our understanding of how to prevent and treat liver fibrosis and cancer in patients with NASH, thereby improving the lives of patients with liver disease, which is highly relevant to the NIDDK mission, throughout the developed and developing world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Alcohol use disorder and other addictions have their origins in early development; consequently, the next generation of addiction researchers should be trained to conduct rigorous work that uses developmental approaches to characterize antecedents leading to these conditions and strategies to mitigate these outcomes. The T32 training program in Development and Neuroadaptations in Alcohol and Addictions (DNA2) at Binghamton University addresses this critical gap by providing highly qualified pre- and post-doctoral trainees with an interdisciplinary training program that focuses on research into developmental influences on drug and alcohol use and use disorder from a translational perspective.

PROJECT_TITLE: Development and Neuroadaptations in Alcohol and Addictions (DNA2)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECTIVE NARRATIVE Suicide is the second leading cause of death among youth in the US; however, effective suicide prevention programs are often difficult to disseminate because their implementation is labor intensive. In response to this gap, Oui Therapeutics seeks to determine the efficacy of Aviva-Y: a mobile technology tool designed to help youth reduce their risk of suicide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative:  Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2) is a key epigenetic regulator of cell identity maintenance; dysregulation of PRC2 function is linked to human cancers and developmental disorders. PRC2 is recruited to CpG island chromatin to mediate trimethylation of histone H3 lysine 27 (H3K27me3), hallmark for gene silencing. The overall goal of the proposed research is to reveal the structural basis of catalysis and chromatin targeting of PRC2 and to connect the structural mechanisms to PRC2 function in cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on identifying mechanisms of detection, resistance and co-option of three food-borne toxins of medical importance: isothiocyanates, cardiac glycosides and cytolethal distending toxins. Although these toxins cause human illness, each is also being used or is in development for treatment of common and debilitating diseases, including Parkinson’s disease, congestive heart failure, and cancer. The proposed research is relevant to that part of the NIH mission that pertains to seeking fundamental knowledge about the nature and behavior of living systems and to that part of the NIGMS mission that supports basic research toward understanding how living systems function across levels of biological organization, from molecules, to cells, tissues, individuals and populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Ion transfer across biological membranes is an essential physiological process mediated by ion channels and is central to nerve excitation, muscle cell contraction, signal transduction, and hormone secretion. The immense physiological importance of ion channels is reflected in the fact that their dysfunction underlies a variety of disabling human diseases including seizures, deafness, ataxia, long QT syndrome, and cardiac arrhythmias. We aim to perform structural and functional analyses of eukaryotic organellar cation channels which play important roles in regulating organelle ion concentrations and cytosolic Ca2+ signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this research program is to gain detailed mechanistic insight into retrotransposition and pre-mRNA splicing. Retroelements and spliceosomal introns comprise ~70% of the human genome and defects in their function results in many human diseases. We aim to use the molecular insight into these essential genetic mechanisms as a foundation for the development of RNA therapeutics.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/ RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Nearly 20% of women in the U.S. (1 million women per year) experience clinically significant depressive symptoms during pregnancy or postpartum, and the majority of these women suffer “in silence” due to various barriers to care. A promising internet-based approach for preventing perinatal depressive symptoms, “Mamma Mia”, has been developed and tested in Norway; we propose to build upon this work by evaluating an adapted version through a multi-site randomized controlled trial in a large group of diverse women in the U.S. If successful, the proposed project has high potential to change self-management of perinatal depressive symptoms because it is practical, internet-based, and low-cost.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative A significant number of pregnancies fail at very early stages in embryonic development for reasons that have been difficult to ascertain due to limitations in studying human development. We propose to investigate the developmental mechanisms the human embryo uses at these early stages to pattern its initial form through an innovative combination of micron-scale stem cell engineering technologies and optogenetic tools, that enable the systematic variation of the signaling patterns thought to drive human embryonic pattern formation. In addition to understanding these mechanisms, enhanced control of natural patterning mechanisms of human stem cells promises to boost the efficiency and precision of engineered tissues for regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Bipolar androgen therapy (BAT) is a promising new strategy to treat prostate cancer patients that have developed metastatic castration-resistant disease and would otherwise be left with no other therapeutic options. We have found that BAT induces the expansion of monocytic-myeloid derived suppressor cells (M-MDSCs) in patients who do not respond to this treatment and hypothesize that these cells could be partly responsible for limiting its efficacy. We propose to use new high resolution technologies to study these cells in 2 cohorts of patients exposed to BAT, coupling this to the use of animal models of prostate cancer, to determine if targeting M-MDSCs in combination with BAT might form the basis of a future approach to boost therapeutic efficacy.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Moral Injury (MI) is defined as the lasting psychological, biological, spiritual, behavioral, and social impact of perpetrating, failing to prevent, bearing witness to, or being the victim of acts that transgress deeply held moral beliefs and expectations. Until recently, there has been no gold standard measure of MI and no information about the extent of this problem among Veterans. This proposal entails the first national representative epidemiological survey study of reports of exposure to potentially morally injurious events, and the extent of MI in US Veterans. Because there is no way to define clinical cases of MI, we will use the survey results to generate a cut-score on a new gold standard measure of MI that indicates clinically impairing levels of MI symptoms and report the prevalence of such cases. We will also determine the clinical value of MI, relative to PTSD and Depression, in explaining functional problems in Veterans. Finally, we will interview a random set of MI cases and controls to examine risk and resilience and the clinical care needs of Veterans with MI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Neonatal thyroid hormone signaling in the liver modifies the future susceptibility to liver steatosis and obesity. We discovered that this is explained by differential DNA methylation that affects how genes are expressed in the adult liver. Here we will explore how the neonatal peak of thyroid hormone signaling affects DNA methylation and their physiological consequences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Lung tissue removed for transplantation currently cannot be preserved for more than 8 hours, and even then, damage to the lung tissue likely contributes to the low survival rate following lung transplantation (50% of patients do not survive more than 5 years). Our studies seek to improve lung tissue preservation and transplant outcomes; we will test using a liver cell bioreactor to improve lung tissue metabolism and reduce inflammation while the lungs are being transported for transplantation. Ultimately, our work will address current limitations in lung transplantation by helping to extend donor organ transportation time and distance beyond 8 hours and to improve post-transplant patient survival.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic musculoskeletal (MSK) pain is a major health concern in late adolescents and young adults (AYAs) that is associated with significant functional disability, psychosocial impairment, and unique challenges during the transition to adulthood. Approaches to mitigate maladaptive pain-related outcomes and enhance protective factors that promote healthy adaptation to pain (e.g., resilience) during this vulnerable developmental stage of life are limited, but of critical importance. The proposed work will elucidate resilience factors across multiple domains of functioning in late AYAs with and without chronic MSK pain, explore how these factors are associated with improved pain, disability, and pain modulatory capacity over time in youth with chronic MSK pain, and inform the development of prevention and intervention strategies for improved pain management in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a deadly lung disease of unknown cause, characterized by progressive lung tissue scarring and airflow limitation, with limited treatment options. Our proposed studies will investigate matrix-associated glycoproteins (Magps), which are highly expressed during fibrosis and appear to play an inhibitory role in the progression of the disease. We will evaluate potential mechanisms by which Magps may attenuate fibrosis, and characterize the cell populations that produce Magps, to identify exploitable pathways for IPF treatment.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Over one million Americans rely on their upper extremities for manual wheelchair propulsion. Shoulder overuse injuries are prevalent among manual wheelchair users and these injuries often result in shoulder pain. Severe shoulder pain can lead some wheelchair users to transition from manual to powered mobility, complicating transportation, and reducing independence in activities of daily living. This project will expand our understanding of a new wheelchair design that allows better positioning of the hand rims and allows for different gearing. We will study steady-state propulsion efficiency with different gear ratios and develop a new system with multiple gear ratios. The advanced gearing will allow for a low gear when initiating movement, going uphill, or when moving over carpet, and then a higher gear option for movements on hard flat level terrain. This system has the potential to dramatically improve shoulder ergonomics and reduce pain in many future manual wheelchair users.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Approximately 800,000 Americans experience a stroke each year, including about 15,000 Veterans, with a cost of care in the hundreds of millions of dollars. After a stroke, balance deficits often limit functional mobility and increase the risk of falls, decreasing quality of life for thousands of individuals. While the role of altered sensation in these balance deficits is often acknowledged, clinical interventions tend to focus on motor function due to the difficulty of directly manipulating sensation. This project will investigate whether a novel approach to multisensory augmentation has the potential to improve standing balance in people who have experienced a stroke, as well as the extent to which personalizing the augmentation to individual participants has beneficial effects. The results of this work have the potential to motivate a new approach to balance rehabilitation, which could increase the quality of life of thousands of Veterans and save millions of dollars.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because cerebral palsy (CP) is the most common cause of physical disability in children. Physical disability in CP is caused by the failure to learn or refine motor control during the first two years of life, yet very little is known about how infants and toddlers with CP learn (or fail to learn) to move. This project is relevant to the missions of NICHD and NCMRR because characterizing the longitudinal evolution of locomotor learning in infants with CP will inform the development of rehabilitative treatments that increase the chance for these children to achieve their full potential and lead a healthy and productive life free from disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) is a deadly disease, affecting 89,000 people in the United States, for which there is no cure. We have found that changes in the metabolism in lung fibroblasts significantly contributes to fibrosis (scar formation) in the lungs. We aim to identify mechanisms by which metabolism is regulated in lung fibroblasts and mechanisms by which altered metabolism contributes to fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project develops novel tools for measuring nonverbal social communication as manifested through facial and bodily expressions. Using advanced computer vision and machine learning methodologies, we will quantify humans’ communicative social behavior. The results of this project will impact public health by facilitating a rich characterization of normative development of social functioning, providing access to precise phenotypic information for neuroscience and genetics studies, and by measuring subtle individual differences to determine whether some interventions or treatments work better than others.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent clinical need to identify new therapeutic approaches to simultaneously treat non-alcoholic fatty liver disease and atherosclerosis, which often manifest together. We uncovered the N-acyl amino acid metabolism, linking lipid and amino acid metabolism, as a common pathway dysregulated in both diseases, creating a new point for concurrent intervention. We will study its role and underlying metabolic mechanisms and will evaluate an intervention based on N-acyl amino acids, with the ultimate objective of accelerating development of a novel therapy for the simultaneous treatment of these two prominent diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Individuals with diabetes are at higher risk of developing critical limb ischemia (CLI), which occurs due to excessive atherosclerosis in the lower extremities and can lead to surgical complications such as amputation. There are currently no tailored therapies to prevent such complications in surgical patients with diabetes and CLI. Our group discovered that targeting a biochemical process responsible for generating lipid molecules in the peripheral arterial system may be a viable target for future tailored therapies for patients with diabetes and CLI. In this proposal we will test this in mouse models that have diabetes and are prone to developing peripheral arterial occlusive disease.

PHR: Narrative Patients requiring cardiac or vascular surgery often have brief reductions in blood flow to the kidneys, which unfortunately can result in kidney injury, decreased kidney function, development of chronic kidney disease, and/or death. In this setting, kidney histone deacetylase enzymes and mircoRNA are activated and may lead to excessive scarring in the kidney. The purpose of this proposal is to determine the epigenetic regulation of myofibroblast activation following kidney injury leading to chronic kidney disease transition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will assess how cortical feedback modulates the activity and sensory processing in the cortex. Cortical feedback pathways are thought to mediate cognitive processes such as attention, prediction, expectation, and awareness. Altered feedback communication has also been associated with certain neuropsychiatric disorders, so the results of this project will provide fundamental knowledge about the brain that may help reduce the burden of disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Persons with Parkinson’s disease (PwP) frequently experience cognitive dysfunction, which has a profound negative impact on quality of life and daily function and thus increases public health burden. Pharmacologic therapies are often ineffective for treating cognitive dysfunction in Parkinson’s disease and no medications are known to halt cognitive decline. This study will investigate deep sleep as a marker of rehabilitation-induced improvement in cognition in Parkinson’s disease to guide selection of the optimal exercise prescription for individual PwP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative: This project seeks to describe the basic principles that govern maternal RNA recognition and regulation in early development. Analysis of how post-transcriptional regulatory mechanisms, and more broadly how maternally supplied proteins and mRNAs, contribute to cell fate specification events in early development will ultimately lead to a better understanding of how developmental processes fail in disease. This project focuses on regulation mediated by the 3’UTR of maternal RNAs, and includes a variety of experiments to establish which regulatory events are most important for reproductive health, and how regulation works at a mechanistic level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to examine whether innovative local tobacco control policies restricting sales of flavored tobacco products can reduce tobacco use and disparities in tobacco and, ultimately cancer. The study will examine trajectories of flavored tobacco use in a large longitudinal national cohort of youth and young adults among those exposed and not exposed to policy. It will also examine youth and young adult non-tobacco user exposure to tobacco marketing and subsequent tobacco use outcomes in real-time in eight communities with different flavor policy variants and will have a particular focus on assessing differences in policy impact across vulnerable group status.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative There are no vaccines or treatments available for either respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) or metapneumovirus (MPV), two of the leading causes of bronchiolitis in young children, immunocompromised adults and the elderly, which collectively results in millions of infections and tens of thousands of hospitalizations each year in the U.S alone. To meet the urgent need for a treatment for both, Mucommune is developing MM-004, a muco- trapping bispecific monoclonal antibody against both RSV and MPV that can quickly clear both viruses from infected lungs. Building off of our promising data against RSV in lambs, this FastTrack proposal will first demonstrate in vivo proof-of-concept efficacy in a hamster model of MPV infections in Phase 1, followed by development of cGMP-compliant cell lines and IND-enabling studies in Phase 2.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is an incurable neurodegenerative disease that progressively destroys patients’ cogni- tive functions causing enormous social and economical impact. With its underlying cause poorly understood, new imaging technologies are in demand to provide more comprehensive etiological investigation of AD over large-scale complex nervous systems, such as whole brains. In this proposal, to address this unmet need, we are to develop advanced optical imaging tools that can enable 3D brain-wide visualization of AD pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Often cancer cells are “addicted” to specific DNA repair pathways to support rapid cell proliferation and resistance to radiation and DNA-damaging chemotherapeutics. DNA repair mechanisms, which cancer cells depend on to a much greater extent than normal cells, offer targeting opportunities for discovery of new effective therapeutic agents. The vast chemical space afforded by natural products will allow us to generate leads that will be employed to develop specific and non-toxic inhibitors of key DNA repair proteins RAD52 and RAD51 whose activities many cancers depend on.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Dr. Michelle C. Sabo [MD, PhD] is an Acting Instructor/Senior Fellow in the Department of Medicine, Division of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, at the University of Washington. For this K23 award, she aims to evaluate the relationship between vaginal microbiota and cervical immune cells in female sex workers in Mombasa, Kenya, which has the potential to provide a mechanistic link between bacterial vaginosis and HIV acquisition risk. This research is combined with a career development plan focused on six key learning objectives, including epidemiology, clinical studies, global health, high dimensional data analysis, mucosal immunology, and the vaginal microbiome, which will provide Dr. Sabo with the additional training, experience, and mentorship she requires to become an independent physician scientist.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fostering children’s social and behavioral skills in the early childhood years has the potential to create long- term benefits for individuals and society at large. Understanding how early educational settings help to promote them is still unclear. This study will use three large, national datasets to examine how preschool and kindergarten environments, and the alignment across them, shape young children’s social and behavioral development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Despite the improved short-term outcomes in kidney transplantation (KT), comparable progress in long-term allograft survival has not been achieved with chronic allograft dysfunction (CAD) accounting for most cases of graft loss. Results from our proposed studies will provide a unique understanding of the early molecular triggers that determine graft outcomes and ultimately lead to CAD. Novel prognostic biomarkers will enable the early identification of patients at higher risk for progression to CAD, such that their use in patient monitoring as well as the development of new therapeutic modalities targeting our identified molecular triggers have the potential to avoid irreversible graft injury and improve long-term outcomes in KT recipients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Clostridium perfringens enterotoxin (CPE) is responsible for the symptoms of several very important intestinal diseases, including the 2nd most common bacterial foodborne illness in the USA. This proposal will address four major gaps in understanding CPE-action and CPE-mediated diseases, namely: i) whether pore formation is required for CPE intestinal activity, ii) the importance and mechanism of indirect effects, like bystander cell killing, on CPE-induced intestinal damage, iii) the mechanistic basis for CPE binding, oligomerization and pore formation and iv) the effects of intestinal lumen contents on CPE processing and C. perfringens sporulation, which is essential for CPE production. This proposal will address these knowledge deficits by using a combination of in vitro, ex vivo and in vivo studies, with the eventual goal of elucidating processes that could be inhibited by therapeutics.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Our previous work suggests that there is a pathway downstream of NUMB that confers “gonadal” competence on cells that have entered the gonad from the coelomic epithelium. Many lines of evidence point to the hypothesis that bHLH proteins are this missing link and are opposed by SOX factors in the male pathway. We will test this hypothesis and also discover how these transcription factors mediate chromatin conformational changes that alter accessibility of genes associated with the male or female pathways.

PHR: Project Narrative Olfactory function is important for many aspects of human health and is influenced by numerous factors including physiological states. This project is designed to test the role of neurons found in the hypothalamus that respond to food deprivation and sleep states on olfactory function. The ultimate goal of this proposal is to determine the contribution of melanin-concentrating hormone to detection and discrimination of odors in the environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Drugs of abuse alter gene expression and epigenetic modifications in brain reward circuits, but it is not clear what molecular mechanisms regulate this process or how drug experience can result in long-lasting epigenetic changes. This proposal will examine the role of Gadd45b, a gene linked to experience-dependent DNA methylation changes, in regulation of the molecular and genetic mechanisms that contribute to cellular and behavioral responses to cocaine. This research will contribute fundamental knowledge to our understanding of how brain circuits drive motivated behaviors in the context of substance abuse disorders, and has the potential to identify novel cellular targets for addiction therapeutics.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a life-threatening condition in adults, especially in male individuals, because estrogen and estrogen receptors have protective roles against AAA in females. A new mechanism was identified by which a factor, KLF14, inhibits inflammation and increases estrogen receptors in macrophages. The information generated from this study will promote the development of more effective drug therapies for the prevention of rupture or to promote reversion of AAA, which currently are not available.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Sarah L. Krein, PhD, RN is an active and productive health services and nurse researcher. She uses her clinical knowledge and research expertise to conduct and collaborate on studies to improve healthcare safety, quality, and effectiveness as well as Veteran health outcomes. She also works with clinician and non-clinician scientists who are beginning their research careers, assisting them in learning new research skills and supporting them as they move on to leading their own research studies. The support provided by the VA senior research career scientist award will allow her to continue to use her research expertise and experience to continue conducting research that improves VA healthcare delivery and patient safety, educate new researchers, work with local, national and international collaborators and contribute to activities that support the VA research, education and care delivery missions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The defining morbidity of heart failure is exercise intolerance, and while exercise training is known to benefit these patients, the molecular transducers of exercise’s benefit to patients are unknown. This study will investigate the proteomic profiles of exercise training in heart failure patients and compare them to proteomic profiles in healthy adults. The results will not only identify biological pathways for further investigation as potential drug targets for symptom reduction, but also provide a proteomic framework for exercise training response in heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed K01 project will use multimodal magnetic resonance imaging and machine learning techniques to elucidate the structural and functional brain mechanisms underlying treatment failure in young adults receiving treatment with injectable extended-release naltrexone (XR-NTX) for opioid use disorder. This project will unveil the neural mechanisms underlying individual variability in XR-NTX treatment response in a population of high importance to the efforts to curb the opioid crisis. It will facilitate Dr. Zhenhao Shi's transition to an independent computational addiction neuroscientist and help inform future research of, and intervention strategies for, opioid addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: Component A, Delaware PRAMS (Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System) Project Project Narrative The overall purpose of PRAMS (Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System) is to reduce infant morbidity and mortality and to promote maternal health by influencing maternal and child health (MCH) programs, policies, and maternal behaviors during pregnancy and early infancy. The information obtained from PRAMS will lead to improvement in the health of mothers and infants in the state of Delaware. Implementing the state-wide PRAMS project will help in identifying risk factors specific to Delaware mothers and infants for intervention, modification of existing prevention and service programs based on study findings, and community awareness of risk factors for birth complications disseminated through research results.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DP21-001 Delaware PRAMS (Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System) Project

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: Oklahoma Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PRAMS)  Component A Core Surveillance Project Narrative The overall goal of PRAMS is to reduce maternal and infant morbidity and mortality. Data gathered by PRAMS are used to: 1) document trends in adverse birth outcomes and other reproductive health and MCH outcomes; 2) identify subpopulations at greatest risk for the adverse birth outcomes, and inform prevention strategies and program development; 3) inform the Title V needs assessment process to help states plan for and allocate MCH block grant funds and to provide background information for states that apply for other grant funds; 4) develop and evaluate programs and policies that support improvement of maternal and child health; 5) investigate merging issues in reproductive health; and 6) support health professionals to incorporate the latest research findings into their standards of practice. Relevance to Public Health Oklahoma PRAMS data contribute to maternal and child health planning and decision-making state-wide. The information derived from PRAMS furthers the core public health function of assessment for pregnancy-related health issues in Oklahoma. Oklahoma PRAMS data are routinely used in the assessment of maternal and infant health status, determining accessibility of preconception, pregnancy, and postpartum services, examining prevalence of emerging health issues, and in the identification of maternal and infant health hazards.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DP21-001 The Oklahoma Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PRAMS)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Olfactory loss is reported as an early symptom and predictor for COVID-19. The supporting sustentacular cells but not the olfactory sensory neurons in the olfactory epithelium are permissive for SARS-CoV-2 infection. The goal of this proposal is to better understand the innate responses in sustentacular cells upon SARS-CoV-2 infection and how these responses contribute to olfactory dysfunction.

The PRAMS data are used to identify groups of women and infants in Kansas at high risk for health problems, to monitor changes in health status, and to measure progress towards goals in improving the health of mothers and infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research investigates the effects of enrollment in private Medicare Advantage plans versus traditional Medicare on health care use, health care quality, and patient outcomes. The analysis will focus on recent policies in several large states mandating that retired state workers receive their health benefits through Medicare Advantage, which shifted public retirees between traditional Medicare and Medicare Advantage. Given growing enrollment in the Medicare Advantage program, the findings from this project will provide important evidence of the program’s effect on patient health.

PHR: Project Narrative The mission of the Massachusetts Department of Public Health (MDPH) is to prevent illness, injury, and premature death, to assure access to high quality public health and health care services, and to promote wellness and health equity for all people in the Commonwealth. MDPH aims to provide timely access to data to reduce disparities and improve outcomes, address the social determinants of health which contribute to health inequities, and eliminate institutional and structural racism.The Massachusetts Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PRAMS) provides data on maternal experiences and behaviors before, during and shortly after pregnancy that can be used to inform and improve maternal and child health programs and policies, furthering the mission of MDPH and promoting the health of Massachusetts families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
ORG_NAME: ALABAMA STATE DEPT OF PUBLIC HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  The Alabama Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PRAMS) Project is a survey sent to women who have recently given birth. The survey covers various topics concerning their health behaviors and experiences before, during, and after the pregnancies. The PRAMS survey is a comprehensive tool that provides an accurate picture of the health of mothers and infants in Alabama. PRAMS data will be used to create informational materials (e.g., fact sheets, data brief, infographics) to educate the public and providers on health and safety topics, such as the importance of receiving dental care during pregnancy, safe sleep for infants, and nutrition during pregnancy. PRAMS data will be presented to highlight the importance on overall health care during pregnancy and barriers to care faced by pregnant women in Alabama. PRAMS data will be used by the state of Alabama to plan and review programs and policies aimed at reducing health problems among mothers and babies. The data will also be shared with other state and local agencies that have important contributions to make in planning maternal and infant health programs and to develop partnerships with those agencies.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DP21-001 Alabama Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PRAMS)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our aged TB chemotherapeutic regimen is insufficient to treat drug resistant tuberculosis (DR-TB) patients. Accumulating evidence has shown that DR-TB develops through cyclic formation of persisters, a phenotypic variant that is tolerant to all TB antibiotics. In this proposal, we will show that persister metabolic remodeling plays an important role in the development of DR-TB, thereby serving as a potential source of adjunctive drug targets to synergize antibiotic effects with the conventional TB treatment regimen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Arkansas PRAMS  Component A PRAMS survey data can be used to improve public health by improving the health of mothers and their infants. The data helps us to understand mothers' experiences and behaviors that affect their health and the health of their infants. The long-term goal of the Arkansas Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PRAMS) survey is to reduce infant mortality and morbidity. The specific objectives of the Arkansas PRAMS program in meeting these goals are the following: 1) Collect population-based data of high scientific quality on topics related to pregnancy and early infancy, 2) Promote the use and increase the visibility of the PRAMS data to encourage translation of the data into programs, policies, or strategies to improve maternal and child health, 3) Analyze and disseminate PRAMS data to inform the healthcare community about behaviors and experiences that affect infant and maternal health, and 4) Provide data and technical assistance to organizations or programs interested in using PRAMS data. Arkansas PRAMS has met these objectives by: 1) Providing non-CDC funding and in-kind personnel to carry out the day-to-day PRAMS operations, including funding to pay contractors for both the telephone surveys and mail survey data entry, 2) Improving mail operations to encourage mothers to complete the survey and increase response rates through various strategies such as increasing incentives, launching a media campaign, and adding a third mail out, 3) Developing and disseminating PRAMS reports (e.g., chart books, surveillance reports) to the health community, 4) Collaborating with internal (e.g., Maternal and Child Health Branch/Arkansas Department of Health) and external programs (e.g., Arkansas March of Dimes, University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences) to analyze the PRAMS data for programmatic purposes, and 5) Responding to data requests from and providing technical assistance to a variety of internal and external programs that have a mission related to maternal and child health.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-DP-21-001 Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PRAMS) Grant

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: Component A: Core Surveillance – Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System PD/PIs: Paulette Valliere, MPH; David Laflamme, PhD, MPH New Hampshire Division of Public Health Services Public Health Relevance Statement The public health relevance of PRAMS consists in the collection and analysis of data which is translated to explain and provide an understanding of maternal and child health needs, behaviors and outcomes. This is critical to the design and implementation of programs and policies to improve health. PRAMS data fill a crucial information gap and provide standardized data which can be compared to and aggregated with the data from other PRAMS projects across the United States.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DP21-001 Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PRAMS)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: Oregon PRAMS Project Narrative The Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PRAMS) surveys mothers of 2-3 month old babies about their and their child’s health. By answering questions about health and behavior before, during, and after pregnancy, PRAMS participants help us learn more about challenges facing Oregon mothers and babies. We use this information to improve programs, create policy, and support families throughout the state.

PROJECT_TITLE: DP21-001 Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring Systems (PRAMS), Component A: Core Surveillance

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
ORG_NAME: CONNECTICUT STATE DEPT OF PUBLIC HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The Connecticut (CT) Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PRAMS) is designed to provide the Department of Public Health (DPH) with important data about maternal health, experiences, and behaviors during the perinatal period; advance knowledge about risk and protective factors among CT mothers; and investigate the associations between these factors and birth outcomes and maternal and infant health. CT PRAMS data will be integrated into efforts to address state maternal and child health priorities, as well as statewide plans and initiatives to reduce low birth weight, preterm birth, infant mortality, and health disparities.

PROJECT_TITLE: DP21-001 Component A (Core Surveillance): Connecticut Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PRAMS)

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Cells in the developing embryo need cues from their environment to instruct them what cell type to become or when to start or stop growing and dividing. Here we will study how cells in the early mammalian embryo interpret such cues, focusing on the role of mechanical inputs, and how they process this information through the activity of the conserved signaling effector Yes-associated protein (YAP), to make an informed decision about the type of cell they should become. As mis-regulation of YAP activity is known to be frequently associated with malignant tumor formation, our work will reveal important insights into the regulation of this pathway during normal development, and serve as a basis for understanding how it goes awry in cancer.

The survey asks women about their attitudes and experiences before, during, and shortly after pregnancy. Iowa’s priorities for use of PRAMS data include reducing racial disparities in maternal and infant outcomes and reducing infant morbidity and mortality. PHR: Maine Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (Maine PRAMS) – Component A Project Narrative The Maine Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (Maine PRAMS) intends to collect data on maternal experiences and behaviors before, during, and after pregnancy to better inform healthcare, social services, and communities. Maine PRAMS aims contribute to the current resources of maternal and infant health data in the state of Maine and on the national stage. This data is collected with the ultimate purposes of infusing policy and practice to improve the health and well-being of Maine’s mothers and infants and decrease the maternal and infant mortality and morbidity rate in Maine.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative The project seeks to gain a quantitative understanding of the molecular networks within cells that control the generation of key progenitor cell types that arise during human brain development. To do so, it will develop modeling and computational tools as well as test these tools on human embryonic stem cell lines. In the longer term, a quantitative understanding of the circuits within cells that control development will allow us to uncover mechanisms underlying developmental disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: There are currently no effective treatments for tauopathies, such as Alzheimer’s Disease (AD). Uptake and spreading of pathogenic tau is recognized as a key driver of AD pathology, and is primarily mediated by tau's interaction with the cellular receptor LRP1. Molecular dissection of the tau-LRP1 interaction will enable us to devise new therapies for AD.
