IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Iron regulatory proteins and Argonaute-2 are RNA-binding proteins that respectively coordinate cellular iron regulation and microRNA-mediated regulation, mechanisms essential for the proper execution of early embryonic development. The objective of this project is to dissect the specific roles of post-transcriptional regulation by microRNAs and iron regulatory proteins on cell fate decisions in early mammalian development and to build in vitro and in vivo biosensor platforms to model cellular iron utilization in early mammalian development. A comprehensive understanding of the dynamic relationships of iron regulatory proteins, microRNAs, and their functional targets during this critical developmental window is needed and will provide a roadmap for functional rewiring in stem/progenitor cell-based regenerative therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Transfer RNAs (tRNA) represent one of the most abundant forms of RNA and chemical modifications to tRNA are critical for structure and function. We will investigate tRNA expression and modifications for blood feeding insects to determine their potential role during feeding and reproduction. Understanding tRNA expression patterns and modifications will develop the resources for new research lines that could provide novel targets for vector control and new mechanisms to reduce disease transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE) Asthma is a common disease that has major impacts on human health, health care costs, and economic well- being. Airway passages are lined by a protective mucus barrier that becomes detrimental in asthma, resulting in impaired mucociliary clearance and disrupted breathing. My research focuses on understanding the specific mechanisms of MUC5AC and MUC5B polymerization and trafficking along the secretory pathway and how they could lead to novel and potentially more selective interventions strategies.

PHR: Narrative.  The goal of this geroscience project is to show that a cocktail of drugs targeting well accepted processes of aging will alleviate neuropathology and restore normal cognitive function in a mouse model of Alzheimer's disease (AD). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to investigate how unusual nucleotides produced by bacteria control their cell physiology in a way that facilitate infections. These nucleotides are produced by bacteria in response to changes in their surroundings, including unfavorable conditions encountered during the course of mammalian infections. The study will be conducted with a bacteria from the genus Enterococcus, which is the 3rd most common cause of infections in hospitalized patients and an emerging public health threat due to the continuous rise of strains that are resistant to most clinically-useful antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Twenty five percent of human cancers have mutations in subunits of the chromatin remodeling SWI/SNF complex. This research proposal describes an innovative approach to study the tumor suppressor activity of SMARCB1, a core member of the complex, which is lost in nearly all cases of an aggressive and lethal pediatric cancer named malignant rhabdoid tumor. The long-term goals of this project are to determine both how SMARCB1 regulates the SWI/SNF complex composition and targeting, and how SMARCB1 affects higher-order chromatin structure, in order to better understand how cancers arise when the complex is mutated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative One of the biggest challenges in rare disease is accuracy and timeliness of patient diagnosis. Genetic risk predictions can improve diagnosis, with particular clinical utility in the specific setting where large barriers to diagnosis exist – such in the case of the rare sleep disorders Narcolepsy and Circadian Rhythm Sleep Wake Disorders. To address the challenge of timely patient diagnosis in Narcolepsy and Circadian Rhythms Sleep Wake Disorders, we propose to leverage large exome sequence repositories to generate rare variant risk scores, expand the current known common polygenic scores to multiple genetic ancestries, and ultimately test the ability of both the rare and common polygenic scores to address misdiagnosis of Narcolepsy and Circadian Rhythm Sleep Wake Disorders in large-scale hospital database with the goal to integrate flags in patient records.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will define the novel molecular mechanisms that govern the targeting of G protein-coupled receptors to the functional destination. These receptors regulate a variety of cell functions under the physiological and pathological conditions and are the most heavily investigated drug targets. The successful completion of these studies may create new avenues for drug design and treatment of diseases involving aberrant trafficking and function of G protein-coupled receptors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) is a leading cause of death in the U.S., affecting 350,000 individuals annually, and is associated with high mortality and morbidity. The proposed RED- CASO (Reducing Ethnic-racial Disparities in Cardiac Arrest Survival Outcomes) study will identify best resuscitation practices at EMS agencies with the highest survival rates for OHCA, especially at EMS agencies that work in majority Black or Hispanic communities. This research is relevant to the mission of the National Heart Lung and Blood Institute because it will identify best practices, improve outcomes, and has the potential to reduce racial and ethnic disparities in survival for a condition with high public health burden .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cystic fibrosis (CF) remains one of the most common, life-limiting genetic disorders due to chronic bacterial lung infections that do not respond to traditional antibiotic therapy. The proposed research will achieve a thorough understanding of how the immune system fails to respond to bacterial infections in CF in order to develop targeted therapies to prevent life- limiting bacterial lung infections. The proposal is relevant to public health and the NIH's mission as the findings will impact the treatment and understanding of immunodeficiencies and lung diseases associated with chronic bacterial infections.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: ZVITAMBO INSTITUTE FOR MATERNAL AND CHILD HEALTH RESEARCH
PHR: Project narrative HIV-exposed uninfected (HEU) children in sub-Saharan Africa have higher mortality, more illness episodes, poorer growth and impaired cognitive development in the first 2 years of life compared to HIV-unexposed children. It is important now to evaluate long-term growth, health, physical and cognitive function as HEU children start school, and to identify the network of factors in early life that drive these health disparities. This would identify targets for intervention in early life to improve long-term health, growth and human capital in HEU children, so that this vulnerable population can survive, thrive and reach their full potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARATIVE Talaromyces marneffei is a fungus endemic in Southeast Asia that kills one in three infected persons with a compromised immune system. The current culture diagnosis is poorly sensitive and is protracted leading to delayed treatment and poor patient outcomes. In this application we propose to validate multiple new non-culture tests for rapid diagnosis and to test whether human infection is a result of airborne exposure to guide disease control and management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The challenge in curing HIV-1 is the persistence of a latent viral reservoir (LVR) that primarily resides in resting CD4+ (rCD4) T cells despite effective antiretroviral therapy (ART). The proposed study will evaluate the LVR spatially, genetically, phenotypically, and immunologically in multiple compartments among people living with HIV, undergoing renal transplantation, and receiving different T cell induction strategies prescribed for prophylactic allograft rejection. These studies will provide critical information on feasibility and mechanisms of potential HIV cure strategies by modeling re-seeding of viral populations in allograft and lymphoid tissues and determining driving mechanisms of clonal proliferation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The correct duplication of genetic information encoded in DNA is essential for cell growth and survival, and dysregulation of this process is linked to human diseases such as cancer. This proposal aims at uncovering mechanisms that control DNA replication onset in multicellular organisms at a molecular and structural level. The knowledge gained from this work will be important for advancing our understanding of disease mechanisms related to DNA replication and for developing novel therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Diverse physiological processes depend upon movement of protein and lipid molecules within and between cellular membranes. Defects in these crucial membrane trafficking pathways drive a variety of human diseases, including cancers and serious neurological disorders like Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and the spastic paraplegias. We study molecular mechanisms of vesicular and tubular coat assembly and regulation on membranes to ensure vital cargo molecules are delivered to the correct cellular destinations in a timely manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The molecular cause of myotonic dystrophy type 1 is known to be a toxic expanded CUG-repeat RNA (CUGexp RNA) that forms ribonucleoproteins (RNPs) that localize in nuclei of skeletal muscle myofibers. The nature of the CUGexp RNP is poorly characterized. The goal of this project is to use proximity labeling to identify the protein and RNA components that contribute to the complex dynamics of the CUGexp RNA RNP and the pathological impact on skeletal muscle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Every animal that develops from a zygote starts life on a path dictated by maternally provided molecules, and subsequent development involves an interplay of maternal and zygotic genetic effects. To understand how these maternal and offspring genomes jointly shape developmental variation and evolution, this research experimentally dissects the contributions of each genome to phenotypic variation within populations of model organisms that vary in their population genetic characteristics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The prevalence of dementia in the population is increasing and there are currently no effective therapies or blood-based biomarkers to detect people at high risk. We plan to investigate the role of circulating immune cells as risk factors for dementia, Alzheimer's Disease and cognitive decline and to test whether associations differ in men and women and by genetic risk. This work will yield insights into the relationship between circulating immune cell types and brain aging, identify new biomarkers for cognitive decline, and may reveal novel therapeutic targets aimed at immune cell alterations to prevent and treat dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative For more than 15 million major surgeries performed in the United States annually, surgeons must decide whether the patient should receive close monitoring by specialists in a high-cost intensive care unit (ICU) or intermittent monitoring on a general ward, and when the patient can be safely discharged home. Prior work suggests that artificial intelligence models can identify cases in which doctors have opportunities to make better decisions. The purpose of this project is to design a real-world framework to help doctors make the right decision at the right time so that patients receive the resources they need while recovering safely from major surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite dramatic improvements in outcome for children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), up to 25% of children fail frontline therapy and their prognosis is dismal. While patients with prolonged remission have a better prognosis, most eventually succumb to their disease due to the emergence of resistant clones, despite increased intensity of frontline therapies. In this study, we will investigate how the reorganization of 3D chromatin architec- ture contributes to patients’ relapse in acute pediatric leukemia.

PHR: This project examines the strategies that viruses use to promote the expression of their genes, which is fundamental for understanding pathogenic viruses. In addition, when viruses infect a human cell, they use the human cell’s machinery to promote their own gene expression. Therefore, by determining how viruses regulate their genes, the mechanisms of human gene regulation will simultaneously be discovered.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This research is relevant to public health as more than 1 in 5 Americans die in intensive care units (ICUs), and the majority of patients are older adults with advanced illness. This proposal will generate information to reduce distress among older ICU patients on mechanical ventilation who are transitioning to comfort focused care, and an intervention with the ICU team of nurses, doctors and therapists to improve symptom control. First, to better understand the patient experience and providers’ perspectives, ICU patients over 60 years old will be followed prospectively during the process of removing ventilator support; Second, a checklist intervention for the ICU team will be developed to improve the process of removing ventilator support; Finally, a pilot study will determine if the intervention is feasible to conduct and provide information for future studies to gauge efficacy in reducing episodes of distress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to unravel the mechanisms underlying pathology and disease progression in early CAA. If BP, a modifiable risk factor, is confirmed to be associated with bleeding events and/or tau deposition, it is conceivable that targeted BP therapy could change disease course in early CAA. Such a low-cost feasible intervention could have tremendous benefit for the large numbers of individuals with early or even asymptomatic disease by reducing their risk for the CAA-related outcomes of hemorrhagic stroke and dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The relevance of the proposed studies to public health is that they will define mechanisms by which the Heat Shock Protein molecular chaperones and protein unfoldases function as cell stress responders that dissolve toxic protein aggregates and amyloids. These studies propose to use cryo-electron microscopy and biochemical/biophysical approaches to determine structural snapshots which identify how these proteins interact and mechanically unfold their substrates. The resulting information will provide insight into mechanisms that protect cells from deleterious protein misfolding and aggregation, events that underlie the cause of many neurodegenerative diseases including Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study will examine the feasibility and initial efficacy of a stakeholder-informed, home-based, remotely supported and supervised exercise training program for wheelchair users with multiple sclerosis (MS). The proposed exercise training program was iteratively developed in partnership with community members using semi-structured interviews, a community advisory board, and focus group feedback wherein community members provided insights to develop and refine an exercise training program that suit the needs and preferences of wheelchair users with MS. Ultimately, the proposed study extends this line of research and may initiate a significant paradigm shift in rehabilitation research and practice by providing a critically needed home- based exercise training program for enhancing health, quality of life, participation, and independence of wheelchair user with MS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biomolecular modeling and simulation is a key technology for leveraging the $14B global investment in biomolec- ular structure data in the protein databank to understand the basic molecular mechanisms underlying biology and disease and the development of new therapies. In this proposal, we aim to expand the development of OpenMM, a free and open source biomolecular modeling and simulation package that can exploit a wide range of consumer-grade and high-end graphics processing units (GPUs) to enable researchers and applications built on OpenMM to achieve high performance with extreme ﬂexibility. A key aspect of this proposal is to accelerate research in the emerging ﬁeld of biomolecular machine learning by tightly integrating OpenMM with modern ma- chine learning frameworks, enabling researchers to build, use, and deploy machine learning potentials, collective variables, and integrators to advance the state of biomolecular modeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The proposed research will test the efficacy of conversation treatment for individuals with aphasia and explore whether the effects of treatment differ as a result of treatment size (large group or dyad), group composition (heterogenous versus homogenous profiles of aphasia) and/or the severity of the aphasia. The results will inform health care delivery models to optimize both treatment outcomes and utilization of financial and other resources. The results will also help develop and refine a hypothesized model about the mechanisms underlying conversation treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE All animals encode and express long double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) that must be distinguished from viral dsRNA. The proposed research will use the model organism C. elegans, biochemistry, and structural biology, to elucidate pathways and mechanisms involved in distinguishing “self” from “nonself” dsRNA, ultimately providing information relevant to the health of all animals, including humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE Research proposed here will uniquely advance knowledge of the physiological and perceptual relevance of olfactory oscillations in the human brain, and may enable us to infer mechanistic principles at the level of local neuron ensembles. Our findings should have a far-reaching impact not only on basic models of olfactory system function, but also more generally on the role of theta oscillations in neural information processing. Finally, given the high degree of overlap between the olfactory system and brain networks implicated in temporal lobe epilepsy, our studies may enhance understanding of the neurophysiological derangements underlying epilepsy, and could provide insights into establishing novel diagnostic interventions that improve spatial localization of epileptogenic foci in cases of non-lesional epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Our proposed studies will unravel that the hyperglycemia-PKCα axis feedforward regulates the crosstalk between iron metabolism and diabetes. Hyperactive PKCα promotes intestinal iron absorption resulting in hepatic iron loading that in turn exacerbates liver injury related to diabetes. The current project may lead to the development of potential novel treatment modalities in diabetic control through the control of iron absorption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cystic fibrosis (CF) remains one of the most common, life-limiting genetic disorders due to chronic bacterial lung infections that do not respond to traditional antibiotic therapy. The proposed research will help us achieve a thorough understanding of how the immune system responds to treatment with novel CFTR modulators, and how these responses correlate with important clinical outcomes. The proposal is relevant to public health and the NIH’s mission as the findings will impact the treatment and understanding of immunodeficiencies and lung diseases associated with chronic bacterial infections and genetic or acquired CFTR dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with comorbid substance use (SUD) and anxiety disorders (AD) experience increased risk for relapse and require novel integrative treatment strategies leveraging new technologies. The Unwinding Anxiety (UA) mobile app can fulfil this need for a digital, evidence-based training in a manualized, scalable, and high-fidelity manner. We will comprehensively investigate user experience of UA for patients with SUD-AD and identify customizations to develop a scalable evidence-based intervention for comprehensive integrative therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Youth-onset type 2 diabetes (T2D) is increasing in prevalence and is accompanied by a greater degree of insulin resistance, more rapid deterioration of β-cell function, and earlier onset of life-threatening complications than seen in adults. However the causes and biomarkers of youth-onset T2D are not well-understood. We will bring our expertise in research methods, recruitment and retention of youth and their families, as well as lessons learned from our stakeholder engagement activities to help the Consortium design and implement a longitudinal study to identify youth at greatest risk and identify the factors driving this growing public health problem.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Excess fetal adipose tissue growth during intrauterine development increases future obesity risk. Development of brown adipose tissue, a highly thermogenic organ in utero, may affect postnatal energy expenditure, thus influencing obesity risk. This novel mentored F32 application is designed to understand the developmental origins of energy balance by examining maternal and neonatal factors that influence neonatal brown adipose tissue and to quantify its physiological relevance to energy expenditure in human neonates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Semi-volatile organic compounds (SVOCs) are ubiquitous environmental contaminants, and human exposure is widespread. We will investigate whether early-life exposure to SVOCs adversely affects children’s immunity to common pathogens. Identifying modifiable environmental factors that influence the development and function of the immune system has long-term implications for improving health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the relevance of the pro-stress corticotropin-releasing factor and norepinephrine and the anti-stress nociceptin systems in the sexually dimorphic behavioral aspects of AUD, their sex-specific cellular mechanisms and interactions in the amygdala have not been fully delineated. Thus, this proposal will elucidate the neuroadaptive changes induced by ethanol dependence and withdrawal in these systems in the amygdala. Identifying the potential neuroadaptations occurring with chronic alcohol is essential for the development of more effective targeted pharmacotherapeutics for treatment of AUD sufferers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is the most common liver disease in the world, affecting 8% of all children and 34% or more of those with obesity. This study will determine and validate the role of skin surface lipids, which can be collected using painless tape stripping, as novel, non-invasive biomarkers of disease presence and severity in youth with NAFLD. The results have the potential to revolutionize clinical practice and to enhance therapeutic discovery, which is currently limited by the need for invasive liver biopsies to accurately detect and stage disease severity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breast cancer brain metastasis (BCBM) is a lethal malignant disorder with prominent breast cancer cell growth to cause malformations and dysfunctions in brain. Our proposed research aims to determine the molecular mechanisms of astrocytes in the initiation and progression of BCBM. The proposal has strong clinical relevance to understand the novel mechanisms of neuropathological impact on breast cancer patients and other malignant diseases with brain colonization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will develop statistical methods and use multi-regional International epidemiology Databases to Evaluate AIDS (IeDEA) data to support a worldwide evaluation of the Treat-All policy regarding the global HIV/AIDS epidemic. The methods will bring robustness in understanding HIV disease evolution subjected to data complexities, the effectiveness of WHO's Treat-All policy, and the patient, clinic, and country characteristics that modify the policy's impact. In addition, the findings from this project may lead to the development of more precise intervention and resource-allocation options that take these factors into account and ultimately improve overall outcomes for people living with HIV.

PHR: Project Narrative Identification of the growth factor pathways involved in cell fate specification of peripheral oral sensory neurons may shed light on the regenerative capacity of these neurons and their target taste buds. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Quality of life remains suboptimal for people living with HIV taking anti-retroviral drugs due to persistent infection and its negative impact on health. Persistent infection generates virus RNA and protein that contributes to chronic low level immune activation. This project will focus on the therapeutic potential of reducing viral RNA and protein burden by understanding and altering the chemical state of HIV RNA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Daily oral HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis with emtricitabine/tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (FTC/TDF) has been shown to reduce new HIV infections in different settings. When used in pregnancy, however, the standard FTC/TDF dose is associated with lower drug concentrations, raising concerns about reduced efficacy. We seek to identify and evaluate the optimal FTC/TDF dose for pregnant women, with a focus on pharmacokinetic and safety outcomes. Our study will be conducted in Zimbabwe, where—like much of sub-Saharan Africa—the burden of HIV is high and the need for HIV prevention is great.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our goal is to elucidate the mechanisms governing the regulation of cardiac and skeletal muscle contraction at a fundamental molecular level by determining the atomic structures and changing interactions of muscle proteins that control muscle activation and relaxation. A complete understanding of muscle regulatory switching mechanisms is essential to define how mutations linked to the muscle control proteins perturb muscle activation and relaxation and then lead to cardiomyopathies and skeletal muscle disease. In turn, our atomic level structures provide a platform to design compounds that specifically target the control proteins to modulate muscle activation or relaxation and thus will be able to reverse initial stage pathophysiology and delay or treat disease progress and symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is a common comorbidity of type 2 diabetes (T2D) that can progress to nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma. The increased prevalence of these metabolic disorders presents a significant threat to public health worldwide, and treatment strategies that address the underlying pathological processes in liver are urgently needed. In the current proposal we will reveal novel physiological and molecular mechanisms of insulin sensitization with the goal of identifying novel strategies to target these metabolic diseases in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Advanced stage ovarian and pancreatic cancers with intrinsic or acquired resistance are considered incurable primarily due to the poor response rate of salvage chemotherapies, such as irinotecan and topotecan. The two main mechanisms that induce or promote chemoresistance are drug efflux mediated by ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporters and DNA damage repair. This proposal will engineer the first light-activatable nanotechnology platform that combines photochemistry and drug repurposing strategies to selectively damage ABC transporters and inhibit DNA damage repair enzymes for improved outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES

PHR: Tumor suppressor microRNAs (miRNAs, in this case miR-205) extends the ability to turn off specific genes or pathways associated to cancer cell survival, metastasis and drug resistance, however, efficient delivery to tumors is hampered to due to stability and toxicity issues. Therefore, we propose to use a dual layered magnetic nanoplatform of miR-205 to CRPC tumors which can significantly improve tumor treatment, lower drug resistance and recurrence. In addition, this SCORE Program SC01 application will promote the research competitiveness of Dr. Yallapu at the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley (UTRGV), which has focused on training and graduating students from backgrounds nationally underrepresented in biomedical research.

These viruses are a major cause of human sickness and mortality, and therefore the proposed research is relevant to public health and relevant to the NIH's mission of reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative: Positron emission tomography (PET) imaging is a non-invasive molecular imaging technique that allows real-time in vivo monitoring of physiological processes via administration of a radiotracer (a molecule tagged with a PET radioisotope) to a patient. Currently, PET imaging finds application in drug discovery, disease diagnosis and monitoring, and personalized medicine. Approximately 2 million PET scans are conducted annually, and there is significant room for further growth. However, the impact of PET cannot be fully realized without both new synthetic methods for the assembly of radiotracers as well as the translation of these synthesis methods to routine clinical production. The overall objective of our research is to develop new chemistry for preparing currently inaccessible PET radiotracers, use machine learning techniques to optimize production yields with these new methods, and introduce automated cassette technology that will allow easy and confident use of this new chemistry to produce PET radiotracers for clinical trials and routine standard of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative – Relevance to Public health Heart failure remains a leading cause of mortality in the United States. The underlying molecular mechanisms of pathological cardiac remodeling and dysfunction in heart failure are not fully understood. Our goal is to advance our understanding of the molecular and cellular bases of heart failure, which may lead to the identification of novel therapeutic targets and strategies for treating heart failure. This project is to elucidate the functions and underlying mechanisms of dysregulating cyclic nucleotide phosphodiesterase 10A (PDE10A) expression in pathological cardiac remodeling and dysfunction, particularly from the perspective of revealing the therapeutic potential of PDE10A inhibition in pharmacological intervention of cardiac disorders. Given the clinical trials of PDE10A inhibitors for schizophrenia and Huntington’s disease, PDE10A has been proven to be a safe drug target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative A central question in dementias including in Alzheimer's disease (AD), Lewy body dementia (LBD) and frontotemporal dementia (FTD) is how synapse loss occurs and whether (and if so, how) synaptic and memory loss can be attenuated or halted. This effort seeks to uncover the role of αSyn on tau expression, tau aggregation, tau deposition and tau-mediated cognitive impairment. We will be using a series of genetic approaches to assess whether constitutive or conditional ablation of the SNCA gene encoding αSyn modulates human tau expression, alleviates tau pathology and tau-induced cognitive deficits in a model of tauopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breast and prostate tumors are dependent for growth on estrogen receptor or androgen receptor respectively and harbor mutations in the PI3K pathway. As such, they are treated with endocrine therapies and PI3K inhibitors but the clinical benefit to these therapies in limited by the emergence of drug resistance. In this proposal we are studying the molecular mechanisms of the epigenetic regulators KMT2D and SMYD2 in the regulation of nuclear receptor function and treatment outcome with the goal of designing and developing improved therapeutic strategies for these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The SIM-STI Program aims to develop an innovative biomimetic model of the lower reproductive tract to study aspects of the sexually transmitted infections (STIs), chlamydia and gonorrhea, that are not achievable in humans or with current animal or cell models. The ultimate impact of this research will be to improve public health by reducing the incidence of STIs in humans. Therefore, it is relevant to the field of public health and to the mission of the NIH, in that it seeks to improve women’s well-being by generating critical research, pre-clinical tools and additional knowledge, both fundamental and action-oriented.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative The blood vessels in our brains form a complicated three-dimensional network that varies from person to person. Neurosurgeons need a roadmap of this vascular network to effectively treat neurovascular disease, which can cause devastating and life-threatening injury to the brain. We are developing ways to create patient-specific models of neuro-vasculature that show how blood moves to different parts of the brain, and software that allows surgeons to interactively explore these models to enable safer and more effective treatment of these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study aims to assess the availability of the alpha7 nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (α7-nAChR) in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI). This project will use positron emission tomography and [18F]ASEM, a new radiotracer developed to image the α7-nAChR, in brains of patients with MCI and cognitively normal individuals, the latter serving as a comparison group. We will also assess the relationships between the α7- nAChR in the brain and 1) cognitive performance and 2) circulating autoantibodies to the α7-nAChR and other biofluid markers at baseline and 2-year follow-up.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The opioid epidemic has been associated with a sharp increase in hospitalizations for drug use-associated infective endocarditis (DUA-IE), a severe infection of the heart valves resulting from injecting drugs. Little is known regarding long-term outcomes following DUA-IE or about patients’ knowledge and preferences surrounding addiction treatment in this setting. This proposed research aims to address these fundamental gaps in knowledge, generating foundational data that can help inform treatment protocols as well as individual and structural interventions to improve DUA-IE patients’ outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: In humans, accumulating evidence links mutations in a number of core ribosome components and in particular ribosomal proteins (RPs) to congenital birth defects, including Diamond-Blackfan anemia (DBA) characterized by specific congenital birth defects including limb abnormalities, cleft palate, growth failure, as well as bone marrow failure. In all of these cases, the mechanism(s) that would account for these cell and tissue specific phenotypes remain poorly understood. Defining at a more basic level the specificity and dynamics of ribosome-mediated control gene regulation will be invaluable for our understanding of how deregulations in the ribosome alter accurate control of gene expression underlying human congenital birth defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative In the United States, seventy percent of all males report the consumption of alcohol, while forty percent drink at a binge level. While fetal alcohol spectrum disorder is undoubtedly linked to maternal alcohol consumption, emerging evidence suggests a significant male contribution to this debilitating condition. This proposal responds to `PA-18-507 - Effects of In Utero Alcohol Exposure on Adult Health and Disease' and will define the basic fundamental mechanisms by which male preconception exposure to alcohol impacts the developmental program of the fetus and contributes to the incidence of birth defects.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The health of over 200,000 individuals with Down syndrome (DS) in the US is unmeasured, despite increased life expectancy, established syndrome-specific guidelines from the American Academy of Pediatrics, and the NIH’s INCLUDE initiative aiming to improve the health and well- being in DS. This proposal presents a five-year research career development program with training that will position me with a unique set of cross disciplinary skills to enable transition to independence as a physician scientist to study, measure, and improve the health of individuals with DS. The proposed research will result in creation of a validated instrument to measure health status in DS – the Down Syndrome Health Instrument (DHI) – to measure patient- reported health in DS for the first time, allow measurement of health as an outcome to improve care, and to expand the repertoire of measurements for future research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to evaluate and understand cumulative lifetime exposure and life course exposure to air pollutants and climate factors during the sensitive time windows of (1) gestation, (2) childhood/premenarche, and (3) adulthood to determine whether prenatal or adult exposures confer greatest risk. We will additionally evaluate disparities in AP exposures and MCC outcomes in a SafetyNet hospital population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative (2-3 sentences) As a class of endogenous regulatory molecules, microRNAs play a key role in proper gene expression and are necessary for stem cells maintenance, cellular and organ development, response to cellular signaling or stress, and proliferation. Almost all microRNAs undergo mandatory maturation steps to become functional and understanding the molecular mechanism of microRNA biogenesis and its regulation will be fundamentally important for a wide range of diseases including cancer, developmental diseases, diabetes, and metabolic syndromes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The germinal center (GC) is a fascinating microanatomic structure in the immune system that is the major source of strong and long lived antibody-mediated immunity. This is critical for how vaccines work and why we don’t get naturally reinfected. The GC is inhabited by B lymphocytes (responsible for antibodies) that differ greatly from non-GC B lymphocytes, and these differences must be critical for function, but they are not understood. This proposal investigates the deep cellular and molecular mechanisms that underlie how GC cells function and interpret signals that lead them to make such effective and long-lived cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Spinal cord injury disrupts systemic organ function, including prolonged fat accumulation and inflammation in the liver, which negatively affect overall recovery and systemic metabolic function. This increases the risk for diabetes and cardiovascular disease, a leading cause of death in the SCI population. This pre-clinical work seeks to identify therapeutic targets to reduce liver pathology and improve after overall metabolic health SCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative HIV is not able to be cured with current therapies and patients continue to have profound immune abnormalities with increased morbidity and mortality when compared to age-matched HIV negative controls. These increased co-morbidities are related to immune activation that we believe is caused by ongoing low- level virus production and/or replication in lymphoid tissues during ART. The primary hypothesis we will explore is that IA during ART is driven by virus producing cells and/or cells expressing viral antigens that is caused by intracellular concentrations (IC) of antiretroviral (ARV) drugs in LT that do not completely inhibit virus replication which creates a barrier to cure and complete immune reconstitution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative / Relevance The circadian clock in the hypothalamic suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) of the mammalian brain is a compact neural net- work which can be studied as a simplified model of the entire central nervous system. A major limitation in investigations of neural circuits to-date has been the need to section the brain, destroying most of the network, and divorcing it from its sensory inputs or behavioral outputs. We propose to employ in vivo real-time Ca2+ imaging in the SCN to study cell-type specific rhythmic generation, the network processing of light input that leads to changes in the circadian behavioral rhythm, and how these mechanisms falter during the process of aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Immunotherapy is a promising new approach for cancer treatment, but only a fraction of patients respond to treatment, with a majority experiencing drug related side effects. Current screening methods for immunotherapy biomarkers rely on biopsy, which is invasive and does not always provide an accurate readout of biomarker status in whole tumors. This proposal will develop a whole-body optical imaging technique that can quantify biomarkers non-invasively, thereby enabling the efficient development of new combination treatments and more accurate screening for predictive biomarkers, potentially saving non-responders from ineffective treatments and life-threatening effects.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are many barriers that patients with Chagas Disease have to overcome to obtain a diagnosis, adequate treatment, and appropriate follow-up. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Integrations of transposable elements (TE) account for ~45% of our genomes, and although most are now inactive, they have provided the genetic diversity to shape the evolution of our cellular and organismal responses to stress. Here, we expand on findings that the RNA-binding proteins (RBPs) that bind to these TE have critical roles in the regulation of endothelial cell activation and immune cell recruitment in the inflamed arteria intima. Our findings will provide important insight into this special class of RBPs, to better understand and treat chronic inflammation in atherosclerosis, aneurysm, and other cardiovascular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: C-C Bond formation is central to chemical synthesis. We have pioneered a broad, new family of metal-catalyzed carbonyl reductive couplings that exploit feedstock pronucleophiles in combination with safe, inexpensive feedstock reductants (H2, 2-PrOH, HCO2H), and related H2-autotransfer processes (ROH = reductant & proelectrophile) that directly convert lower alcohols to higher alcohols. In the proposed funding period, this reactivity pattern will be extended to couplings of α-olefins and C-X pronucleophiles, the use of amine proelectrophiles, the formation of quaternary stereocenters and use of base metal catalysts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE Cirrhosis–the end-stage result of chronic liver disease–is an increasingly common condition that results in significant morbidity and frequent hospitalization, all disproportionately affecting racial/ethnic minorities and socioeconomically disadvantaged patients. This project represents the first necessary step in developing interventions to reduce these disparities and improve survival in racial/ethnic minority and socioeconomically disadvantaged populations. We will follow a large group of patients with cirrhosis to identify factors that explain these health disparities, with a special focus on reasons that can be changed with prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative There is increasing evidence that disruption of our 24-hour (circadian) clock impairs the immune response increasing the risk to several different diseases, including cancer, obesity, diabetes, and chronic diseases of the gut. Despite this general knowledge it remains largely unknown how disruption of the 24-hour clock impairs human immunity at a molecular and cellular level. Here we propose to delineate how the complement system affects immunity and inflammation in a circadian dependent manner, which may lead to novel therapeutic targets for the treatment of disease pathologies caused by disruption of the 24-hour circadian clock.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  microRNAs are an extensive class of ~22 nucleotide RNAs that mediate broad networks of gene regulation, and their dysfunction is linked to disease and cancer. We uncovered new mechanisms that govern selective microRNA biogenesis, and linked this to specific cancers. We will integrate biochemical, molecular, genetic and genomewide approaches to elucidate new microRNA mechanisms, their exploitation as gene silencing vectors, and their impact on disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative:  Spinal cord injury (SCI) generates a cascade of events resulting in loss of voluntary movement and muscle degeneration. This study is innovative because it seeks to slow down this degenerative process through the use of Tamoxifen, early after SCI, and to maintain the contractile properties of skeletal muscles, as well as the appropriate expression of myosin heavy chain proteins in muscle fiber. We will also determine some of the mechanisms activated or de-activated by TAM in muscle cells using metabolomic analyses and if the drug provides an appropriate environment for satellite cell proliferation and/or muscle regeneration in male and female rats, which may lead to novel therapeutic strategies to enhance functional recovery early after SCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to understand how cholesterol interacts with physiologically important membrane proteins to control their signaling functions through modulating conformational changes. We will use a diverse set of biophysical techniques to study cholesterol interactions with Scap, the master regulator of mammalian cholesterol homeostasis, and GPCRs, which transduce signals from hormones and neurotransmitters to intracellular G proteins. Further understanding how cholesterol influences the conformations of these proteins will benefit public health, since Scap is a potential therapeutic target for fatty liver disease, and different GPCRs are important for treating many disorders such as asthma, cardiovascular disease, and Parkinson's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal adapts West Virginia’s successful SEPA-funded Health Sciences & Technology Academy (HSTA) for the innovative purpose of building the pipeline of students to STEM health-related fields including nursing, nurse faculty, nurse scientists, and other biomedical fields from those underrepresented in the nursing workforce and from underserved rural communities in Alabama. HSTA-Alabama will provide professional development to teachers to build science content and pedagogical skills for use with HSTA-Alabama students and to use in their classrooms. Through a focus of addressing obesity in Alabama and its corresponding sequelae including cardiovascular diseases, other risk behaviors, and opioid use prevention, using a citizen science approach, we will mentor and facilitate professional preparedness of high school students from underserved communities for college and careers in STEM fields, and in particular into academic nursing and nursing science by empowering them to become agents of change in their own communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In order to understand, disseminate, support and incentivize high quality communication in serious illness, we need measurement methods that can be scaled for larger clinical studies and routine health service quality reporting. We propose to apply state-of-the-art artificial intelligence methods (Deep Learning Neural Networks) to develop such measures using existing cohort data that includes more than 12,000 minutes of audio- recorded palliative care conversations in the hospital setting. We focus initially on conversational pauses that are indicative of human connection in serious illness conversations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to provide a high-resolution description of the tear film lipid layer which is a thin layer of oil-like molecules that separate tears on the surface of the eye from the ambient air. Physical and chemical properties of the tear film lipid layer have been implicated in the development of dry eye syndrome, which affects 7 million Americans. With an improved, high-resolution description of the tear film lipid layer, researchers can test competing hypotheses about structure, properties, and function of the lipid layer and its relationship to the development of dry eye syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with by with patients to principles with cirrhosis have increased surgical risk relative to patients with cirrhosis, and the decision to proceed surgery or pursue non-surgical management is often challenging. This decision however, is heavily driven clinician recommendations given an empiric lack of understanding the perspective and preferences of patients  cirrhosis. This proposal will use a mixed-methods approach to elucidate outcomes that are valued by with cirrhosis when deciding to pursue elective abdominal hernia repair, thereby creating a framework  promote shared decision-making between patients and clinicians and to support patient autonomy — key of medical ethics. ,

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to determine how CD14, a protein best known for its role in the recognition of bacterial lipopolysaccharide, facilitates the inflammatory cytokine production, cell death, and in vivo septic immune responses triggered by TNFα, a cytokine that is a prominent effector of septic injury in humans. Based on our preliminary data and our discovery that CD14 has coevolved with TNFα and its receptor, we will examine how CD14 modulates the signaling pathways set in motion by TNFα. While CD14 is understood to play a role in the initiation of inflammation by pathogen-sensing receptors, these studies will clarify how CD14 contributes to runaway sepsis via feedback effects on host cytokine signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because respiratory distress in ADRD patients is common in the nursing home and can lead to poor care outcomes. We propose to test the use of a radio sensor to track breathing and implement machine learning methods to predict when a patient may be experiencing respiratory distress. This research aims to contribute to knowledge in our understanding of respiratory distress in the ADRD population living in the nursing home setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Project Narrative: The erythropoietic and prothrombotic effects of Erythropoietin in anemic patients implicates the Megakaryocytic- Erythroid progenitor as a direct target, and a useful model to explore mechanisms that uncouple the production of erythroid and platelet-producing megakaryocytic cells. This application describes a small, discrete, well-defined project to identify candidate proteins and target genes that propagate phenotypic and functional changes downstream of Erythropoietin signaling in human hematopoietic progenitors destined to give rise to erythrocytes and platelets. Results from the proposed studies will improve our understanding of the mechanisms of action of Erythropoietin in human bone marrow leading to advancements in treatments for anemia, and will support the lab during transition to independence by generating preliminary data for a future R01 application.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Child maltreatment is a serious problem and an estimated 1 in 7 children are maltreated each year. Strong support networks, or safety nets, are a protective factor associated with child abuse prevention, yet we know little about the safety nets of families involved with child protective services. This project has the potential to inform child welfare policy and practice nationwide by determining the effects of safety nets on child permanency and mental health outcomes over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This project is an important first step in understanding how vaping nicotine and menthol affects neuronal function and seizure susceptibility. Electronic nicotine delivery systems (ENDS) have been marketed as a safer alternative to conventional cigarettes, but there are increasing reports of adverse health effects and seizures associated with their use. This proposal seeks to elucidate the neurobiological consequences of ENDS use by evaluating the propensity for seizure activity and neuronal hyperexcitability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Histoplasma capsulatum, a dimorphic fungal pathogen, is the most common cause of fungal respiratory infections in immunocompetent hosts, and a significant source of morbidity and mortality in immunocompromised patients. Development of inducible/repressible gene expression technologies and improving episomal DNA maintenance in Histoplasma will allow us to generate knockdown and over expression mutants with stable expression levels and phenotypes. These technologies will enable us to characterize putative regulators of host-associated yeast phase of Histoplasma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) is a form of paralysis initiated by prior infection with Campylobacter jejuni. Antibodies that are induced to target bacterial surface sugars mimicking similar sugars concentrated on our nerves can then cross-react and cause damage and paralysis. We will isolate GBS patient antibodies, inactivate them, and use those antibodies to block further damage and reverse paralysis to create a new GBS treatment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly one in five older youth in the United States struggle with basic reading skills, and are consequently placed at a greater risk for unemployment and poor health outcomes compared to their typically developing peers. These persistent reading problems may be due to brain-based difficulties in learning and remembering new words, especially words that sound similar to each other. In the proposed study, we will use non-invasive brain stimulation to test a model of how the brain supports learning and remembering new words in older youth with reading difficulties, which will lay a necessary foundation for future work that will evaluate the potential of non- invasive brain stimulation as an adjunct to treatment in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osteoarthritis (OA), a disease that affects 30 million people in the United States, is characterized by a progressive degeneration of articular cartilage that is frequently initiated by joint trauma. To gain insight into the response of cartilage cells to injury throughout the tissue, we propose to measure and analyze, using a new large data and machine learning based technique, the real time response of cells throughout a cartilage tissue after it is impacted with an indenter. Understanding how the distribution of cell phenotypes is altered when the tissue is exposed to different impact strengths, or when specific calcium signaling or bioenergetic pathways are enhanced or suppressed will enable us to develop an understanding of the mechanisms that govern cell fate after traumatic injury and ultimately identify targets for interventions that could protect impacted tissue from further degradation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hospitalists provide care to hospitalized patients at most US hospitals. Unfortunately, high burnout and poor mental health of hospitalist clinicians may be associated with increased risk for turnover, which may have high institutional costs as well as negative impacts on patient quality and safety. This work will provide insights into the impact of burnout and poor mental health on hospitalists and the costs associated with turnover and the impact of workloads and work models on these outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Research Narrative Although dysbiotic airway microbiome is associated with asthma, our knowledge about the dynamic changes of the airway microbiome and their relationships with asthma exacerbations is limited. This proposed study will characterize the changes of the airway microbiome over time in patients with asthma and identify patterns and taxa that are correlated with asthma exacerbations. The results will fill a knowledge gap in the field of asthma airway microbiome and advance the development of airway bacteria-based asthma therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Bacteria rapidly evolve new capabilities, such as virulence, by acquiring genes from other bacteria through a process called horizontal gene transfer (HGT). HGT occurs by different routes, one of which is the transfer of DNA carried by bacteria infecting viruses (phages) or virus-like agents, known as transduction. This project uses innovations in next-generation DNA sequencing, metagenomics, and metaproteomics to uncover the identity and magnitude of transduced DNA in the microbiota and intestinal pathogens, and is a first step in understanding how transduction of bacteria influences human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Overconsumption of fructose-rich food and beverages has emerged as a significant risk factor for the development of obesity, nonalhocholic fatty liver disease and type 2 diabetes. Extensive fructose metabolism in the liver has been shown to contribute to liver lipids accumulation, however, fructose metabolic role in other tissues especially brown adipose tissue is not well understood. Therefore, determining the metabolic impacts of fructose metabolism in brown adipose tissue could shed light on understanding of feeding-induced brown adipocyte energy substrate intake, utilization, and storage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Aging of blood forming stem cells can cause anemia, immune deficiency and hematologic malignancies in older adults. We will develop a first-in-class regimen by inhibition of the small GTPase Cdc42 in aged human blood stem cells with a small molecule in a closed circuit stem cell manipulation apparatus. The product will be applicable to aged bone marrow transplant patients to rejuvenate the declined function of their aged blood stem cells to benefit the lives of older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to provide talented students from underrepresented populations formative experiences and training that will contribute to their scientific development and guide them towards successful careers in the biomedical workforce. To achieve this goal, we will recruit outstanding underrepresented minority students and subsidize their tuition, wages, and housing costs for the Summer Program in Neuroscience (SPIN) at Boston University School of Medicine, an existing summer program that integrates mentored neuroscience research with small group graduate-and medical level neuroscience education, and exposure to clinical activities focused on the diagnosis and treatment of brain disease. Graduates of our program have mentioned it has been a life changing experience that has motivated them to pursue careers in science and medicine; we expect that SPIN will provide positive and motivating experiences for underrepresented minority students, and help to increase the numbers of underrepresented minorities in the biomedical workforce.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Well-being in adulthood depends on having an adequate social life and a network of people who can help when they are needed. Decisions and experiences during the transition to adulthood—especially with romantic partners—may have a long-term influence on adult well-being. This project proposes to use existing data to characterize young adulthood experiences with romantic partners, and to collect new data about established adulthood well-being from those same respondents ten years later, to see how those experiences are linked over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Herpes simplex viruses cause cold sores and sexually transmitted infections, and can also cause the serious complications of neonatal infections, blindness, and fatal encephalitis. The purpose of this research is to determine how the herpes simplex virus initiates infection in humans by studying the virus interaction with host cell lipids. Greater understanding of the virus entry process will help to identify novel approaches to prevent herpes infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE Several inflammatory diseases are linked to the intestine, including primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), an immune-mediated disease hallmarked by liver fibrosis. There is no therapy that prevents PSC from getting worse, and liver transplant is the only cure—although sometimes, PSC can return even after liver transplant. This project will offer specific cell types for targeted approaches to treat diseases linked to the intestine, including PSC-linked liver fibrosis, an unstoppable disease that has no cure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE Sensing and controlling inflammatory activity is critical for understanding brain function in health and disease. However, current methodologies are limited in their ability to noninvasively image and manipulate specific cellular functions, specifically manipulating inflammatory states dependent on the activation of a kinase of interest involved in the inflammatory process. The goal of this proposal is to develop novel indicators and genetic circuits that will address limitations of current technologies to enable non-invasive reporting of inflammatory state and dynamic control over inflammatory processes in genetically defined cell types in the brain as a tool to treat various inflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rehabilitation for people with persisting symptoms of imbalance and dizziness after concussion focuses on improving one’s ability to integrate sensory signals for balance control. However, daily life also requires a cognitive application of this sensory integration to remember one’s position and navigate through the environment. This project will use state-of-the-art virtual reality technology and tests of dynamic sensory integration during navigation and balance to determine the effects of concussion on spatial navigation to guide targeted rehabilitation strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This Exploratory/Developmental Research Grant proposal seeks to advance the state of the art in diagnostic ophthalmic imaging with a novel, robotically-aligned optical coherence tomography system capable of automatically measuring a retinal biomarker that cannot currently be reliably identified with standard of care OCT devices. The research is directed towards developing an automatic method for measuring this biomarker without the need for a trained operator and demonstrating its use in a clinical setting. We believe our technology will allow for increased access to a new diagnostic for monitoring patients with major retinal diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Intracellular microbes such as pathogens, symbionts, and mitochondria have profound impacts on animal physiology and health, but there is limited functional understanding of what factors regulate interaction and inheritance of the intracellular community. This research will use insect models combined with a suite of molecular tools and multiplex fluorescent microscopy to define how intracellular infections establish and evolve stable associations with other co-inherited microbes. The simplicity and tractability of this model will inform our understanding of intracellular communities in far more complex systems, particularly those that impact human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A vaccine to prevent congenital transmission of human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) infection is needed to significantly reduce birth defects and brain damage caused by this most common congenital infection, yet a vaccine that can elicit potent immune responses and effectively prevent infection during pregnancy remains elusive. Fc-mediated antibody effector responses have been implicated in prevention of placental HCMV transmission, but HCMV encodes proteins (viral FcγRs) to evade this key immune response; thus, this proposal will employ novel strategies to target viral FcγRs through active vaccination to modify current vaccine strategies with the goal of yielding stronger responses that will impact CMV transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to investigate the complex relationships between the compliance of interbody metamaterial fusion cages, load-sharing, and the progression of spinal fusion in vivo. We hypothesize that the proposed metamaterial interbody cages with local compliance and reduced stiffness foster more consistent load-sharing and lead to a faster bone formation and better fusion. The proposed experimental concept paves the way for the design of next-generation compliant metamaterial orthopedic implants and fixation devices for therapeutics of fracture repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pseudomonas aeruginosa causes serious and frequently fatal hospital-acquired infections, particularly in neutropenic patients like those with hematologic malignancies or who are undergoing hematopoietic cell transplantation. High-risk strains, such as ST111, which are associated with increased virulence and antimicrobial resistance, tend to be clinically dominant in these populations, although the causes have remained unclear. Our preliminary data indicate that the dominance of ST111 is driven by two factors which this grant will study: suppression of other P. aeruginosa sequence types by a secreted protein complex and by exploiting quorum-sensing signals secreted by other bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Inborn errors of immunity (or primary immunodeficiencies) comprise a large, diverse group of inherited genetic defects that can cause a variety of serious human diseases. While these defects are often individually very rare, studies to define their underlying molecular basis can offer an unparalleled opportunity to acquire new fundamental understanding of immune system function. Here, we propose such mechanistic studies of a newly identified, disease-causing variant of an innate immune protein which may ultimately reveal novel aspects of its role in connecting two distinct cellular anti-viral pathways.

PHR: NARRATIVE Fungal infections are difficult to treat because they form biofilms that reduce drug efficacy. These biofilms are also in difficult-to-access locations, such as the gut. We will engineer a probiotic yeast that senses whether a fungal biofilm is present, and if it is, produces drugs to degrade the biofilm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE ADNP mutations in humans are one of the most common single-gene causes of autism spectrum disorder (ASD). We have recently found that pigment epithelium-derived factor (PEDF) plays a critical role in neurite formation, spine formation, and calcium signaling and that Adnp is a potential downstream effector of PEDF signaling. Therefore, we will investigate whether the PEDF-derived peptide treatment can normalize abnormal neuromorphology and neural connectivity in the Adnp+/- mice.

PHR: Communication between fat cells and immune cells is critical to the normal function of fat tissue. In obesity, the ways fat cells respond to immune cells can change, leading to inflammation and dysfunction in fat tissue. Results of these studies will reveal new cell communication patterns that can be leveraged to treat obesity and other metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The ability to leverage early biomarker, clinical, and demographic data to accurately predict a patient’s likely recovery trajectory following moderate-to-severe traumatic brain injury (TBI) is paramount to allow definition of appropriate therapeutic strategies and to evaluate medical (as well as ethical and legal) decision-making including withdrawal of life-supporting therapies. Here, we develop, and compare to existing clinical algorithms, two novel strategies that leverage non-parametric models and machine learning techniques to fuse and incorporate routine multimodal and multiplex MR signals into prediction frameworks. Ultimately, this project aims at developing a broadly accessible platform that can be used by practicing clinicians all over the world to supplement prognoses with quantitative and spatial multimodal MR data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: As witnessed in Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic, inflammation-induced thrombosis could lead to elevated disease severity, worsened clinical outcomes and increased mortality. Due to the high biological safety risk, the blood samples of patients with infectious diseases are limited to access for in vitro experimental investigations of the mechanisms underlying the processes of thrombus formation. In this application, we propose to develop a new predictive multiscale and multiphysics framework enhanced with deep learning techniques to elucidate the connection between the pathogenesis of microthrombosis and the clinical outcomes of patients with COVID-19 and this proposed framework can be extended to test new hypothesis for hyperinflammatory prothrombotic disorders in various infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Bacteriophages are a threat to human health due to harmful effects on human microbial community as well as due to losses in fermentation industry caused by bacteriophage infections. CRISPR adaptation is the fundamental mechanism by which bacteria fight off phage infection where in a short piece of the intruder genome is sequence specifically inserted into the bacterial genome for offering immune protection. The proposed study will reveal the distinct mechanistic features promoting site-specific DNA insertions from different subgroups of type II- A CRISPR system, the results of which will enable biotechnological and biomedical applications such as programmed DNA insertions, improved phage therapy to fight drug-resistant bacteria, and development of superior bacterial strains for the fermentation industry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Atherosclerosis is driven by the accumulation of cholesterol in the aortic intima that deposits within “foamy” macrophages present in plaque. We will address the mechanisms that Trem2 uses to promote foamy cell formation through cholesterol uptake, and regulation foamy macrophage lipid metabolism and cholesterol efflux. Finally, we will test a novel therapeutic drug that binds and triggers activation signal through Trem2 for treatment of existing atherosclerotic plaques, knowledge that is necessary for translation of these findings into future patient studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: HENRY M. JACKSON FDN FOR THE ADV MIL/MED
PHR: Project Narrative High doses of ionizing radiation cause profound and chronic inflammation in affected tissues and subsequent fibrosis that is related to the activation and altered polarization of macrophages. Radiation impacts macrophages through DNA damage and the activation of aberrant transcription, which both trigger specific intracellular nucleic acid receptors and downstream signaling pathways, resulting in differential expression of type I interferons and inflammatory modulators. In this project we will explore the distinct role of RNA and DNA sensors and their signaling pathways in prolonged radiation-induced inflammatory activation of macrophages and their response to increasing doses of irradiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT There is an urgent need to increase the number of scientists from diverse backgrounds who are committed to the study of oral biology and its relation to overall health. The MUSC RAISE program seeks to overcome barriers that have prevented or hindered undergraduate students from gaining experiences that would engage and inspire students to continue their professional careers in the field of oral biology. The ultimate goal of the RAISE program is to foster the development of a cadre of diverse scientists who will become part of the scientific workforce dedicated to improving oral health and overall health for all.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Drug abuse and addiction is inextricably linked with HIV/AIDS pandemic. Among them, methamphetamine abuse has been associated with worse disease outcome and higher mortality rate among people infected with HIV. This study aims to investigate 1) the molecular mechanisms of methamphetamine on inflammation and immune dysfunction in people living with HIV and 2) the therapeutic potentials of autophagy inducers for treating hyperinflammation in HIV infection and methamphetamine abuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to design a new class of osteoinductive biomaterials for in situ bone regeneration in the absence of exogenous growth factor. The proposed approach will circumvent the current clinical limitations associated with the use of supraphysiological doses of growth factors. The completion of the proposed work will provide a new class of biomaterials for cranial bone reconstruction, and eventually advance bone regeneration approaches for humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 2 diabetes disproportionately affects the health and wellbeing of rural Hispanics in the US; however, access to evidence-based diabetes preventive services is limited for this population. Using implementation research and community-engaged methods, we will design and pilot-test a health unit model that provides diabetes risk screening, counseling, and referrals to Hispanics living in rural Indiana. This project represents a new iteration of outreach strategies to better serve rural Hispanic populations.
