IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Non-AIDS comorbidities are a significant cause of mortality in people living with HIV in the cART eRA due to the inability to erradicate HIV reservoirs in diverse anatomical sites. Gene therapy approaches directly targeting HIV are largely ineffectual due to escape mutants and a lack of an in vivo delivery mechanisms for transgenes. Combining broad spectrum in vivo delivery of CRISPR-based approaches with selective and self-limiting expression only in HIV-infected cells can overcome these limitations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Although alcohol use disorder affects 9% of the US population, less than one in ten affected individuals receives any treatment. Despite being present in up to 18% of surgical patients and being a modifiable risk factor, alcohol use disorder-specific interventions are rarely provided by perioperative clinicians. The Leveraging Alcohol Use Disorder Screening for Treatment in Routine Perioperative Care: AllUsCare proposal will extend alcohol use disorder screening into perioperative interventions and lay the groundwork to test optimized alcohol use disorder intervention bundles most likely to be acceptable, feasible, and effective in a future pragmatic multi-center clinical trial.

ORG_NAME: HENRY M. JACKSON FDN FOR THE ADV MIL/MED
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Our risk of radiation exposure, whether terrestrial or during space flight, continues to increase creating an urgent need to identify radioprophylactics to combat irradiation injury. Remarkably radioresistant naturally occurring fungi offer a unique and powerful system to identify irradiation countermeasures. Our proposal will test dietary supplementation with radioresistant fungi using Drosophila to identify radioprophylactics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Pathological fracture calluses are deficient and very often fail to ossify despite anti-cancer drug therapy, radiation therapy and anti-resorptive agents including Rank:Fc antibody (denosumab) or bisphosphonates (zoledronate). There is no mechanistic understanding as to why fractures do not heal well in the presence of certain types of breast cancer cells. We expect to establish a novel mechanism-based therapeutic paradigm for devastating patients suffering from pathological fractures secondary to breast cancers, the most common cancer in women and causing fractures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The Summer Undergraduate Research Experience in Aging and Neurologic Diseases at Washington University recruits undergraduate students with diverse backgrounds and disciplinary interests for an eight-week introduction to research on the prevention and treatment of neurologic disorders in older adults. Students join a laboratory focused on one of three neurological conditions (stroke, Parkinson’s disease, or dementia) for a closely mentored research experience. They also gather together for lectures, discussions, field trips, and professional development seminars to nurture their knowledge, skills, professional identity, and momentum as scholars.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While the emotional toll of bereavement is well-recognized, resulting disruptions to social connection often go unnoticed and unaddressed, leaving millions of Americans at risk for the well-established harms of social isolation. The proposed study will identify intervention targets and adaptive strategies for mitigating social isolation and for retaining, repairing, and rebuilding social connections following what is widely acknowledged as the most devastating form of loss: the death of a child. Applying the public health model of bereavement care tailored to individuals’ support needs, the long-term goal of this research is to provide healthcare systems with empirically-based resources that can be used for bereavement support and community education.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV-1) causes a chronic, incurable infection, and while existing therapies can suppress the virus, people with HIV develop more comorbid conditions than uninfected individuals. This proposal aims to investigate the impact of nicotine on NLRP3 inflammasome activation in people with HIV and substance use disorders by infecting human tonsil explants and iPSC-derived microglia with HIV-1, and characterizing how nicotine impacts HIV latency and the activation of inflammasomes in CNS cells, and using scRNAseq on post- mortem brains. The study team has extensive expertise in HIV virology, inflammasome biology, and substance use disorder, and successful completion of the proposed studies will inform future therapeutic targeting of the NLRP3 inflammasome in mitigating the inflammatory sequelae associated with HIV and nicotine use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will provide the first comprehensive analysis of the early events in fetal innate and adaptive immune programming to viral infection and inflammation across gestation and how immune signaling influences cellular stress-response in the fetal brain. Creation of a fetal immune atlas in response to viral infection and inflammation will provide a critical foundation for understanding how immune signaling can be targeted by novel therapeutics for fetal neuroprotection.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The ovulatory surge of luteinizing hormone (LH) induces a plethora of events within the ovary that ultimately result in release of a fertilizable oocyte and conversion from an estrogen to a progesterone producing tissue, both of which are essential for fertility. LH accomplishes this through many mechanisms and our laboratory has recently determined that circular RNAs are induced by LH and that they may play a key role in this process. Our study focuses on understanding how LH regulates circRNA biogenesis in ovarian follicular (granulosa) cells and how specific circRNA mediate functional impacts in ovarian events, such as hormone production and release of the oocyte.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the tremendous advancement in organ-on-a-chip technologies, liver allograft rejection on-a-chip models have not been developed. Therefore, the overarching goal of this proposal is to engineer a vascularized liver- on-a-chip model comprised of multicellular organotypic microstructures that will recapitulate the pathophysiology of cellular and humoral rejection of liver allografts. Our goal is to offer a novel platform for studying transplant immunology, particularly the kinetics of donor-recipient interactions leading to rejection or tolerance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antibodies are critical mediators of immune protection against pathogens, simultaneously acting to neutralize entry and activate innate immune cells through interaction between the antibody Fc domain and Fc-receptors on innate immune cells. Our proposal aims to define the underlying mechanisms and pathways through which antibodies leverage different innate immune cell types to provide protection through the temporal analysis of gene regulatory pathways induced by a panel of SARS-CoV-2 monoclonal antibodies that will contribute to our fundamental understanding of how antibodies orchestrate immunity which can be applied to current and future monoclonal antibody therapeutics against infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC), driven by tobacco and alcohol use as well as HPV infection, is the sixth most common cancer worldwide. This debilitating disease presents a significant health care challenge as cases are rapidly rising in the United States and around the world. The proposed studies will decipher the mechanisms driving immune suppression in HNSCC and will develop new therapeutic approaches that can offer new promise for the successful treatment of this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parasitic diseases are responsible for great morbidity worldwide, yet there is only one partially protective vaccine currently in use for malaria prevention. Here, we will explore using mRNA vaccines as a tool to achieve protection against parasitic infection not previously possible with other technologies. We propose to test targets that are highly shared between parasites to elicit antibody responses that block the invasion process in Toxoplasma gondii and to prevent diseases caused by Apicomplexa parasites with information gleaned from this project.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to public health because it involves developing drug-like molecules that target the SUF-like pathway of iron-sulfur cluster biogenesis, which was recently identified as a potentially viable target for new antibacterial agents for which there is not yet resistance. The proposed work includes the first known systematic screen of small molecules against the SUF-like pathway as well as hit-to-lead development to create first-in-class, lead-like molecules that are metabolically stable and effective against S. aureus, E. faecalis, and S. pneumoniae. Lead-like molecules generated by this work have the potential to combat other pathogens that also rely on the SUF-like pathway, such as M. tuberculosis and parasites that cause malaria, adding a powerful new tool to improve human health and well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding enzymes—their physical and chemical properties and evolutionary trajectories— is fundamental to biology and of profound practical importance to industry and medicine, yet no current tools provide the in-depth biochemical analysis at the scale needed to achieve the next levels of conceptual, empirical, and practical understanding. We present a suite of new tools that meet this challenge, providing kinetic and thermodynamic data for thousands of enzymes with the precision and information content of traditional enzymology but at a small fraction of the time and cost. Applying these tools to multiple enzymes, we will systematically dissect energetic coupling to the active site and throughout the enzyme and do so for multiple functional parameters, while also providing a wealth of “ground truth” measurements to thoroughly test existing and emerging models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Postsynaptic kinase/phosphatase networks in amyloid b-induced synaptic dysfunction  In Alzheimer’s disease (AD) overproduction of amyloid beta (Ab) protein fragments from the amyloid precursor protein (APP) is thought to interfere with the normal signaling functions of brain synapses during aging to interfere with learning and memory and cause dementia. Elucidating how Ab interferes with synaptic function is an important first step for understanding the mechanisms underlying cognitive impairments associated with AD and could result in the identification of novel drug targets and therapies. However, very little research to date has shed any light on the mechanisms by which Ab engages and interacts with specific, local synaptic signaling pathways to cause neuronal dysfunction and cognitive impairment. Here, with the use of assortment of innovative cellular and molecular imaging methods and genetic manipulations, we will test the novel idea that Ab activates signaling that impairs synaptic and cognitive function through a type of postsynaptic receptor called a Calcium-permeable AMPA receptor (CP-AMPAR) that is in turn regulated by a protein called Protein Kinase A (PKA) that is specifically anchored at synapses by a protein called AKAP150. Importantly, these studies will investigate whether targeted disruption of AKAP150-anchored PKA signaling regulation of CP-AMPARs and/or interfering with additional upstream regulators and downstream targets could be worth exploring as viable therapies for preventing synaptic and cognitive dysfunction in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Aging worsens outcomes of acute ischemic stroke. We evaluate the hypothesis that age-dependent reductions in endothelial cell (EC) autophagy account for this relationship. Moreover, we explore the possibility that restoring EC autophagy or its ability to regulate EC nitric oxide generation and arterial vasodilation will serve as a novel therapeutic strategy for mitigating stroke outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Trypanosoma brucei and related trypanosomes are deadly pathogens that cause tremendous human suffering worldwide. Transmission and pathogenesis of trypanosomes requires signal transduction systems to enable the parasites to adapt to diverse external environments in the mammalian host and insect vectors that transmit them, but the underlying signaling mechanisms are very poorly understood. cAMP signaling has emerged as an important pathway for transmission and infection by T. brucei and in the current project we will define mechanisms of cAMP signaling in these parasites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Persons infected with HIV now have a life expectancy near that of the general population, but they remain at a significantly higher risk of developing cognitive impairment. Recent human neuroimaging studies have identified the cortical brain circuits that are centrally involved in such cognitive decline, but the underlying pathways and molecular mechanisms remain poorly understood, and the potential therapeutic options are very limited. The current project builds on several recent discoveries and will use advanced dynamic functional brain mapping, systems biology approaches, and high-dimensional structural equation modeling to identify whether parameters of inflammasome activation and/or the mitochondrial redox environment drive cognitive and brain dysfunction in persons with HIV, and whether regular cannabis use therapeutically modulates these parameters.

PHR: Component A: Core Surveillance Illinois PRAMS Project Narrative  By monitoring the behaviors and experiences of women before, during, and after pregnancy, the Illinois Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PRAMS) surveillance project provides epidemiologic surveillance that enables analysis of trends, identification of emerging issues, and demonstration of priority need areas. State and local maternal and child health programs, academic partners, and others rely on this information to identify priorities, to plan health programs, and to create policies that improve the health and well-being of women and infants and reduce morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have seen reduction of a molecule called miR320 in human muscle that is developing weakness due to disuse, and we showed that changes in miR320 has the potential to be causing this weakness. We have now created a knockout mouse with reduced amounts of miR320 in muscle. This project proposes to use this mouse, and other models, to investigate the role of miR320 in muscle growth and maintenance. The work promises to lead to new candidates for treatment of muscle wasting diseases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Prostate cancer is the common cancer diagnosed in the Veterans population. African American (AA) men represent ~1/3 of all Veterans diagnosed with prostate cancer. In the U.S., AA men are more likely to be diagnosed with and die from prostate cancer compared to European American (EA) men. It is not well understood what differences in prostate tumors might contribute to these large disparities. To develop a molecular understanding of prostate cancers in AA men, we will perform state-of-the-art sequencing of prostate cancers from AA men to determine the genetic changes that are associated with ancestry and with aggressive prostate cancers. To study how certain genes drive prostate cancer, we will develop new prostate organoid models derived directly from prostate tissue and test the effects of altering these genes. Overall, these studies will advance our understanding of the mechanisms of prostate cancer in AA veterans and all veterans and will inform new strategies to reduce prostate cancer disparities.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Although Colorectal Cancer (CRC) endangers males and females of all the population, Veterans show a higher incidence rate of colon cancer than the general population. It is estimated that each year the Veterans Affairs manages and treats ~175,000 CRC patients. It is therefore an urgent necessity to find novel early detection and therapeutic strategies to curb CRC-malignancy to increase the survival and quality of life for Veterans diagnosed with this disease. Identifying markers that are highly specific to the premalignant/malignant precursor lesions and the metastatic CRC to develop novel early detection and therapeutic approaches would not only decrease patient mortality among VA-CRC patients but will also help reduce associated financial burden for the Veterans Administration. We hypothesize that CLDN-1 can serve as a powerful adjunct for imaging SSA/P polyps and resection of metastasis.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: New approaches to suicide prevention are much needed in US Veterans, given their persistent increased suicide risk relative to demographically matched general population. Increasing evidence links suicide with persistent inflammation, oxidative stress and endothelial dysfunction. These physio-pathological processes are ameliorated by statins , independent of their known metabolic and cardiovascular benefits. Add on statins have been reported to be beneficial in mental illness (depression, schizophrenia, cognitive disorders) and for common immune-mediated conditions (IMCs) - infections, allergies, and autoimmune disease – and traumatic brain injury (TBI) . These upregulate inflammation, and have been predictively associated with suicidal behavior. Our three aims are to examine: 1) if IMCs and TBI interact synergistically in elevating suicide risk, 2) if persistent statin treatment reduces the hazard of suicide and 3) what are the characteristics of the Veterans who would benefit the most from statin add-on treatment to ameliorate their suicide risk.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Breast feeding is associated with intestinal health, but the specific components of breast milk and the mechanisms underlying these associations are not fully understood. Building from our novel discovery that offspring fed with antibody deficient breast milk generate dysregulated intestinal immune responses, I propose to understand the consequences of these dysregulated responses as they relate to host-microbe mutualism. The resulting data may help advance the development of treatments or therapeutics aimed at promoting beneficial host-microbiome interactions in early life, particularly in children who are not breastfed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This grant builds upon a large ongoing randomized clinical trial (PREDIMED-Plus) to examine the effects of an intensive lifestyle intervention consisting of an energy-reduced Mediterranean diet, increased physical activity and weight loss on changes in body composition, plasma and stool metabolites, and risk of type 2 diabetes. It will also evaluate whether the benefits of the lifestyle intervention on diabetes risk differ by individuals’ metabolic profile. The findings may enhance our understanding of the metabolic pathways through which lifestyle interventions reduce diabetes risk including changes in metabolites and gut microbiome and inform the development of more effective personalized nutrition and lifestyle interventions for the prevention of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE  Collagen degradation mediated by proteolytic endogenous enzymes is strongly associated with the progression of periodontal disease and the breakdown of the dental substrate/restorative material interface, which together are the cause for almost 80% of the tooth extractions in the United States. This project aims to develop two independent cutting- edge platforms based on polyphenols sequestered in enzyme-responsive nanomicelles and nanobodies immune proteins, in order to modulate metalloproteinases (MMPs) -2, -8, and -9 activity in periodontal pockets and at dentin-adhesive interfaces and, ultimately, prevent/cease undesirable dental tissues. It is expected that this proposal leads to the development of biologically-responsive and immunomodulatory-based dental biomaterials capable of suppressing the collagen enzymatic degradation activity in different therapeutic niches while addressing the NIDCR priorities to develop interdisciplinary, unique, and innovative approaches to promote oral health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE African Americans (AAs) have the highest colorectal cancer (CRC) incidence and mortality that we hypothesize can be attributed to their higher prevalence of obesity, intake of low fiber, high animal protein and saturated fat diets and a higher abundance of gut bacteria known to metabolize bile acids to metabolites that are genotoxic and tumor promoting. Obesity and diet determine the extent to which bile acid metabolism is a risk factor for CRC. This proposal will determine if the largely plant-based Mediterranean Diet alone, weight loss alone or the two interventions combined can affect the bile acid-gut microbiome axis ultimately revealing critical information on how weight loss and diet can address CRC risk in AAs, but also in other high-risk populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Treatment of premenopausal women at high risk of breast cancer recurrence with endocrine therapy plus ovarian suppression decreases breast cancer recurrence. However, a high proportion of patients discontinue treatment early, primarily because of aggravating symptoms. Identifying an effective approach that improves persistence with therapy and reduces development of bothersome toxicity has the potential to improve disease outcomes while maintaining quality of life for young women with breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE Classification of cells within human tissues is essential for understanding states of health and disease. In this proposal, we will develop a new class of fluorescent label that increases the number of molecular classification markers for cells by an order of magnitude. These labels function within intact, three-dimensional tissue, an attribute that we will use to map the local environments of adipose tissue immune cells that are thought to determine comorbid outcomes of obesity.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Suicide prevention is VA’s highest clinical priority, and, yet, little is known about causal factors and mechanisms for suicide; and, thus, little progress on salient interventions reducing risk of suicide. The proposed CDA-1 will provide necessary and relevant knowledge on causal factors associated with suicide risk in mid-to-late-life Veterans—a subpopulation that encompasses the greatest number of Veteran lives lost to suicide. This project will leverage an existing cohort of 5 million Veterans 50 years and older with multiple linked national large-scale datasets, including national suicide data. The current longitudinal cohort includes ~12,000 suicide deaths and over 20,000 nonfatal suicide attempts. The CDA-1 proposal is directly aligned with VA’s mandate to prioritize research that helps to develop targeted suicide interventions by finding out why certain Veterans are at risk of suicide and eliciting expert knowledge to improve upon the clinical utility of such information; ultimately, advancing the current landscape of VA’s suicide prevention and intervention programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Preeclampsia is a severe disorder that affects 5% of all pregnancies and is characterized by elevated blood pressure and increased urinary protein; treatment options remain limited. Here, we propose to leverage a large multi-ethnic study with genomic and intermediate molecular phenotypes (metabolites and circulating microparticle transcripts and proteins) to identify maternal and fetal determinants of preeclampsia and causal biologic pathways altered in pregnancy. Since preeclampsia is a leading cause of maternal mortality and preterm birth worldwide, and increases women’s future cardiometabolic disease risk 2-4-fold, improved preventative and therapeutic interventions based on underlying mechanisms have a great potential to positively impact public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project proposes to adapt the community health worker model to encourage and support use of advanced diabetes technologies in young adults from underrepresented minority groups (YA-URMs) with type 1 diabetes (T1D). Community health workers are a cost-effective intervention that enhance team-based care by leveraging their unique position between communities and health systems to advocate for underserved patients and provide extra support for providers. This proposal is the natural next step to testing a model of T1D care aimed at root causes of disparities to reduce inequity in care delivery and outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it seeks to understand how genetic mutations cause brain cell hyperexcitability and change the way these cells process information and learn, leading to seizures, developmental delays, and cognitive impairments. Our research will define how deficits in neuron excitability and synaptic communication interact to alter plasticity in a transgenic mouse model of Generalized Epilepsy with Febrile Seizures Plus and Dravet syndrome, severe childhood epilepsy disorders. Our work aligns with the mission of the NINDS because we seek to uncover causes of neurodevelopmental disease, discover avenues for therapy development, and ease the burden of this disorder on patients, their families, and society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Spinal injury that involves the cervical cord can severely impair hand function in humans and result in loss of independence. We use clinically relevant models of spinal injury in the monkey and rat to study central neural mechanisms responsible for the recovery of hand function. Our findings will provide novel insight into the neuronal reorganization that takes place post-injury, which is needed if patients with spinal injuries are to be treated more effectively.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on identifying a novel pathway that regulates CD8+ T cells, which are critical immune cells that provide protection and long-term immunity against viral infections. This proposal will define how maintenance of appropriate protein quality control regulates CD8+ T cells at homeostasis and following viral infection. An understanding of pathways that regulate CD8+ T cell immunity will provide mechanistic insights to guide design of therapeutic strategies to enhance protective T cell responses, such as following infectious diseases or vaccination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kidney stone patients are at risk for future symptomatic kidney stone episodes. Preventive interventions can reduce recurrence risk, however selective therapy as guided by 24-hour urine studies have not been evaluated against empiric therapy. This study will evaluate comparative effectiveness of selective versus empiric intervention strategies on urinary risk profiles of kidney stone patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Public health relevance Our current knowledge base regarding knee osteoarthritis (KOA) cannot clearly distinguish between individuals who will progress and those that will not. Accumulating data suggest that lipid mediators may be central mechanistic mediators of chronic low-grade synovial inflammation and joint pathobiology. The utilization of mass spectrometry will allow us to characterize these inflammatory mediators in a large cohort of individuals at high risk of KOA, the Osteoarthritis Initiative (OAI) cohort, and address the question of whether circulating bile acids has the potential to effectively predict KOA progression in this cohort.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative New strategies are needed to attack deadly microbes such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the causative agent of tuberculosis (TB). Because of their unique cell wall, mycobacteria can survive in human hosts under conditions that would kill most microbes; therefore, the focus of this project is on understanding how mycobacteria build and remodel their cell envelope. By uncovering the weak links in the mycobacterial cell wall, new antimycobacterial strategies that exploit these vulnerabilities can be discovered.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: There are over 1,600 major limb amputations to-date in military operations OEF, OIF, and OND (CRS Report). Additionally, in 2013 alone there were nearly 27,000 (QUERI) Veterans with spinal injuries (SCI) and related disorders cared for by Veterans Affairs who all stand to benefit directly from this project. This Merit Award project aims to build fundamental knowledge of how motor cortex (MI) controls voluntary, as well as stereotypic, lower limb movements, and then to design both a brain-spine interface leveraging a fully implanted hardware system combining wireless neural recording, stimulation, and motion capture technologies borrowed from industry and born from our laboratory, with the mathematical tools to explore use of a neuroprosthetic for therapeutic delivery of spinal stimulation. By establishing a robust understanding of the cortical control of hind limb movement, and piloting a fully implanted brain-spinal interface, we will have obtained the critical scientific information needed to advance toward a first-in-human study of a restorative BSI in Veterans with paraplegia.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our proposal focuses on the frequent exacerbator phenotype of asthma. This asthma subgroup, disproportionately affects urban populations, is responsible for considerable asthma morbidity and healthcare costs, and is grossly understudied. Our studies will use multilayered omics approaches to delineate the pathogenomics of the frequent exacerbator.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease is one of the most serious conditions affecting the pediatric hip as 50% of patients will develop debilitating osteoarthritis. The project will develop new necrotic bone reconditioning and immunomodulatory treatments to target chronic inflammatory macrophage response that hinders bone regeneration in this hip disorder. Successful completion of this project will have immediate clinical impact by providing a proof-of-concept for the minimally invasive, yet potentially highly effective, tissue engineering strategies to overcome current barriers to successful bone regeneration in Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Bone is highly vascularized. Chronic, high doses of glucocorticoids reduce bone vasculature, which is a unifying histologic feature of glucocorticoid-induced osteoporosis and osteonecrosis. Basic and translational research dissecting the mechanism how glucocorticoids impair bone vasculature will identify potential biomarkers and drug targets to diagnose and treat people with glucocorticoid-induced skeletal side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), a condition that affects a quarter of American adults, triples the risk for cardiovascular diseases and increases all-cause mortality. Standard therapy with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) does not improve cardiovascular risk. Based on our mechanistic observation that the abnormal cycle of endothelial inflammation can be disrupted with statin therapy, we now propose randomized clinical trial of statins vs. placebo to determine its effects on endothelial dysfunction in OSA patients treated with CPAP, which may provide the basis for practical clinical trials of statins for reducing cardiovascular risk in OSA.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Notwithstanding recent success in immunotherapy, Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC) is often lethal, especially if not diagnosed and treated at an early stage. Moreover, MCC disproportionately affects Veterans and imposes a growing impact on Veteran healthcare. This project aims to ascertain a potential new therapeutic paradigm for advanced MCC in the emerging field of antibody-drug conjugates (ADCs). Leveraging our unique and highly clinically relevant biological resources, we are ideally positioned to determine the safety and efficacy of a novel ADC, m276-SL-PBD, and lend insights to biomarkers of response and resistance. Successful completion of proposed studies will validate and accelerate a therapeutic paradigm shift, helping Veterans and others who become resistant to immunotherapy, or to serve as definitive treatments for MCC patients who are ineligible for immunotherapy due to comorbidities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This T34 U-RISE@NSU program at NSU aims to provide an enhanced training experience to STEM undergraduate students from underrepresented populations, supporting them to enter and complete biomedical graduate programs. The program stands on two key pillars necessary for this kind of proposal: an excellent research infrastructure and an extensive minority population of Hispanics and other underrepresented minorities, with doctoral career aspirations. The program will achieve its objectives by development and implementation of 1) a foundational education program in the biomedical sciences, 2) a collaborative laboratory-based research experience, 3) a summer research experience, and 4) a career development program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa causes life-threatening infections in immunocompromised and hospitalized individuals, and a better understanding of how it causes infections will be instrumental for the development of new treatments. This research aims to understand how P. aeruginosa senses its environment during an infection in order to produce a toxic molecule that degrades human tissue and subverts the immune system in lung, wound, and eye infections. Findings from this research could support the development of new treatments for P. aeruginosa infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Of the estimated 5.2 million Americans reporting cocaine use in the year of 2020, 1.3 million met the criteria for cocaine use disorder (CUD) – a disease for which there are no FDA-approved treatments. Cocaine-induced disruptions of circadian (24-hour) and diurnal (night/day) rhythms are significant risk factors for the development of CUD and relapse. The proposed studies will examine the influence of chronic cocaine intake patterns on diurnal rhythms of acetylcholine and DA release to provide new mechanistic targets and pose times throughout the day that may be most effective in treating CUD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis frequently use glucocorticoids (GCs) despite their known toxicity and the risk of adverse symptoms when they are tapered. Clinicians cannot predict how a given patient will respond to GC dose reduction, as existing studies do not examine taper-related symptoms as predictors of taper success, or evaluate how patient factors may affect such symptoms. The proposed research will a) prospectively evaluate tolerance to GC dose reduction among RA patients; b) develop multi-dimensional phenotypes of GC taper response that can be used to design tailored GC tapering strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: Project Narrative Invasive lobular carcinoma (ILC) is the second most common subtype of breast cancer and demonstrates unique features supporting its highly invasive and metastatic nature. Despite this, lack of effective models has left ILC largely understudied with no insight into the mechanics underlying its invasive potential. This proposal aims to dissect the tumor-extracellular matrix interactions of invading ILC cells, in search of novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Project Narrative The most common forms of congenital birth defects (e.g., Down’s syndrome) and about 35% of miscarriages are caused by defects in chromosome segregation during meiosis in one of the parents. Dr. Wahls and his colleagues are using fission yeast as a model organism to determine what regulates the positioning of meiotic recombination, which is essential for proper chromosome segregation. This work will help us to understand the causes of Down’s syndrome and miscarriage and will identify targets of potential diagnostic value.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  We have recently discovered a new class of highly potent and drug-like aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AHR) immune modulator derived from an indole-pyridine scaffold, which are suitable for oral administration and display promising pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic profiles. We have confirmed that these compounds potently increase IL-22 production, accelerate gut mucosal healing, and restore intestinal integrity in a murine model of colitis, as well as induce IL-22 expression in human T cells from healthy adults and adults with active inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Significantly, we have identified stringent structural requirements for ligand- induced activation of AHR that provides a framework for the rational design of intestine-selective agonists, which we believe will represent an important advance for the treatment of IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE There remains a major unmet need for developing novel imaging platforms to visualize network-scale activity dynamics during complex, unrestrained behaviors. We propose to develop a novel head-mounted computational miniature mesoscope that applies computational imaging principle to enable recording cortex-wide Ca2+ dynamics with single-cell resolution of neural activities in freely behaving mice. We will apply this new technology to visualize the cross-area, network-scale activity dynamics that guide social interactions between familiar partners - one of the most integrative, multi-sensory, and cognitively demanding forms of neural processing.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Otherwise healthy children who have been introduced to complementary foods outside of a critical developmental window can develop structural abnormalities of the orofacial region and aberrant chewing behaviors. While a sustained liquid diet can safely provide nutrition to these children, how to best remediate and safely facilitate maturation of their chewing patterns is not known. This project will test two treatment strategies on the recovery of oral function in an animal model to guide clinical decisions about feeding rehabilitation in healthy children and lay the groundwork for clinical decision-making for healthy preterm infants and children with underlying physical and/or neurological disabilities that delay the acquisition of oral skills.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE: The proposed research study will investigate the relationship between the timing of prenatal alcohol exposure (PAE), DNA methylation at birth, and longitudinally-measured depressive symptoms across development in youth from two large population-based cohorts (the Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children; ALSPAC; and Generation R; GenR), consistent with a discovery and replication approach. This research will identify the specific trimesters in pregnancy when prenatal exposure to alcohol may have greater influences on child DNA methylation and subsequent depressive symptoms in childhood and adolescence, as well as the role of DNA methylation in linking PAE to increased risk for depression. These findings will highlight key sensitive periods and potential therapeutic targets that might explain the multiple adverse outcomes linked to PAE and that can be harnessed in interventions and treatments aimed at reducing mental illness in people with fetal alcohol spectrum disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This study will evaluate the complex relationships and interactions between sleep and aerobic fitness as they impact cardiovascular disease risk factors early in life. We will include state-of-the-art assessments of sleep along with neurocognitive assessment to the pediatric arm of the NIH Common Fund Molecular Transducers of Physical Activity Consortium (MoTrPAC) study. Results will direct future clinical trials focused on improving sleep and aerobic fitness in developing youth to improve cardiovascular disease risk factor and ultimately improve prevention of disabling disease.

PHR: Project Narrative Rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) is a pediatric cancer long overdue for potent treatments that target pathways specific to the disease. Myogenic differentiation factor 1 is a strong growth dependency specific to RMS, and this study aims to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying this relationship. Knowledge gained from this proposal will advance understanding of RMS pathophysiology and provide a foundation for investigation of novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative / Public Health Significance This study aims to find an effective and sustainable approach to reducing disparities in accessing depression treatment and fall prevention services for an underserved and growing population group of low-income, racially diverse, homebound older adults. It will compare integrated approach to treat depression and prevent falls utilizing bachelor’s-level lay providers collocated in aging service agencies. The findings are expected to provide research evidence to guide implementation of a care delivery model that is scalable in the real world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Osteoporosis and low bone mass are major public health problems, often accompanied by diminished bone formation, increased bone resorption, and impaired marrow vasculature. This proposal will investigate the multifaceted roles of a newly identified bone marrow adipose cell (MALP) in regulating bone development, homeostasis, aging, and injury repair. Discoveries from this study will be important for understanding the disease mechanism of osteoporosis and other bone disorders and identifying new therapies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Almost 15% of Americans have chronic kidney disease (CKD), with an even higher rate in Veterans due to common risk factors such as high blood pressure and diabetes. People with CKD have a high risk of cardiovascular (CV) diseases, such as heart attacks, heart failure, and strokes. Extra fluid in the body, called volume overload, may lead to CV disease in people with CKD. It is unknown if volume overload develops in the earliest stages of CKD, when treating it with common, inexpensive medicines called diuretics may improve long-term CV outcomes. The first study will lay important groundwork to answer this question in Veterans with early CKD by comparing two ways to measure volume overload and studying the change in common symptoms like fatigue and short-term CV function after treatment with diuretic medicines. The second study will look at past medical records to determine if lowering blood pressure with diuretic medicines was associated with less CV disease in Veterans with CKD, which could affect choices of blood pressure medicine in patients with CKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: CRISPR/Cas9 based genome editing is a transformative technology that has the potential to cure some of the most severe human diseases. In this proposal we will develop new gene editing approaches to treat homozygous Familial Hypercholesterolemia. A major thrust of this work involves strategies for promoting the survival and growth of cells harboring therapeutic transgenes in the liver- which will be broadly applicable many monogenic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The difﬁculties faced by individuals with autism to recognize the faces of others and read emotional and social cues from facial expressions can pose signiﬁcant challenges that negatively impact their quality of life by increasing anxiety and furthering social isolation. This study aims to use functional neuroimaging to investigate the underlying neural mechanisms of facial processing in individuals with autism to ascertain the precise contribution of the face processing regions to this core deﬁcit by combining the latest engineering modeling techniques and cognitive neuroscience. Our goal is to elucidate aberrant functional brain mechanisms that may underly facial processing differences and identify how this information may contribute to our understanding of the trajectory of autism, potentially add to autism screening criteria, and facilitate reﬁnement of interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuropsychiatric manifestations are common in Rare Genetic Disorders (RGDs), affecting brain development and functioning throughout the lifespan; copy number variants (CNVs) at 22q11.2 and 16p11.2 loci are among the most common RGDs impacting developmental psychopathology. We propose to capitalize on highly informative samples and integrate prospective dimensional and categorical phenotyping with whole genome sequencing across these reciprocal CNVs. This work will identify convergent risk mechanisms for developmental neuropsychiatric disorders that have relevance to the broader population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging in women is associated with diminished ovarian responses to follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) as well as the oocyte quality. Our studies using novel genetic models expressing different age-specific FSH glycoforms will not only provide mechanistic insights but unequivocally test the role of FSH-mediated signaling pathways in vivo in the ovary which produces estrogen and eggs. Thus, our studies may lead to developing novel FSH-based therapies to preserve and enhance ovarian function in women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 2 diabetes mellitus incidence has increased dramatically, yet the prognosis for many of these subjects is poor, impacting healthcare costs, substantially. The proposed experiments are relevant to public health because they will enhance our understanding of the pathogenesis of diabetes-induced heart failure and provide information regarding targets for preventive and therapeutic interventions that will aid in the treatment of diabetes mellitus in the type 2 diabetic patient. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH’s mission that pertains to the pursuit of fundamental knowledge to extend healthy life and reduce the burden of illness.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atrial fibrillation, the most common cardiac arrhythmia in adults, is associated with increased morbidity and mortality. This application aims to elucidate how alterations in cardiac nerves increase susceptibility to atrial fibrillation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Information in the nervous system is relayed at synapses, where neurotransmitter is released with great precision from a presynaptic terminal on to a post-synaptic cell via the fusion of membrane bound synaptic vesicles with the cell membrane. The components of these vesicles are subsequently retrieved and recycled for reuse. This grant aims to understand how fusion and retrieval of vesicles influences membrane tension in these small structures and conversely how the speed with which the cell membrane flows influences synaptic function. PHR: Project Narrative  Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and type 2 diabetes are two major metabolic disorders that affect up to 30% of the population in the United States. In this project, we will characterize a newly-identified metabolic regulator, named mitochondrial NAD kinase (MNADK), which plays key roles in preserving energy homeostasis and insulin sensitivity and thus mitigating the risk of NAFLD and type 2 diabetes caused by overnutrition. The proposed studies on the function and mechanism of MNADK in metabolism will have important implications in the prevention and treatment of human metabolic disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Since 1999, 9% of all Veterans nationwide have been diagnosed with skin cancer. Unlike other cancer types, patients will often develop multiple skin cancers, and half of skin cancer-related deaths occur among those with 10 or more skin cancers, and these patients with 10 or more skin cancers have a 25% risk of metastasis. Skin cancer risk is thus heterogeneous, but little progress has been made in determining which patient will develop numerous skin cancers. This study will address the critical knowledge gap of how to identify a priori Veterans at high risk of skin cancer morbidity and mortality, starting with a high-incidence population. Organ transplant recipients (OTR) have up to 100-fold greater rates of skin cancer than non-OTR. We will examine clinical pharmacogenetic, and genomic factors associated with the development of 10 or more skin cancers within 10 years after transplant. These factors can provide clues to the relative importance of mechanisms of carcinogenesis of skin cancer and have the potential to be generalizable to the broader Veteran population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Until now, researchers have focused on examining the genetic mutations that drive lung cancer. At present, thanks to innovative sequencing technologies and computational tools, it is possible to investigate the molecular mechanisms that trigger lung cancer more deeply. By leveraging these modern tools, we aim to study the altered non-coding RNA post-transcriptional modifications, specifically A-to-I editing, in lung cancer progression and drug resistance with the scope of identifying new molecular targets and possibly new future therapies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The proposed CDA-2 will provide Dr. Malaktaris with the training and data to advance research aimed at improving psychological comorbidities and chronic pain (CP) disability among Veterans. The proposed study will include a randomized controlled trial to investigate the efficacy of Cognitively-Based Compassion Training for CP with Psychological Comorbidity (CBCT-CP+) compared to Health Education while Living with Pain (H.E.L.P.) using a sample of 126 Veterans with comorbid mental health symptoms and CP. This will be the first study of a compassion meditation intervention targeting comorbid mental health symptoms and CP disability within the VA, which would further the VA's commitment to improving the mental health and well-being of Veterans detailed in the 2018-2024 VHA Strategic Plan. Results from this study will directly inform patient care among Veterans with chronic pain and psychological comorbidity, and will be used to inform development of future clinical trial and implementation studies that seek to improve the lives and functioning of Veterans.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The diaphragm is an essential mammalian skeletal muscle, as it is vital for respiration and serves as a barrier between the thoracic and abdominal cavities. Development of the diaphragm requires the integration of multiple tissues that derive from several embryonic sources, and defects in diaphragm development are the cause of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) a common birth defect (1 in 3000 births) that results in severe morbidity and 50% mortality. Our research will elucidate the genetic, molecular, cellular, and environmental mechanisms regulating development of the diaphragm and CDH and provide important insights into CDH's phenotypic and clinical variability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Anemia is a nearly universal diagnosis in preterm infants and is associated with increased morbidity and mortality worldwide. When severe enough to be treated with RBC transfusion, critical adverse effects can be seen; one such consequence is necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), an inflammatory bowel necrosis of preterm infants characterized by monocyte infiltration and activation. In this application, the investigators propose sequential studies to investigate the ontogeny of implicated monocytes, the mechanism(s) involved in their recruitment, and potential strategies to prevent their activation in the progression to NEC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The cell cycle regulator p16 is deleted or silenced in >30-40% of melanomas, but no current treatment strategies exist to target this patient population. In this study, we will investigate the role of p16 loss in upregulating pro- tumorigenic nucleotide metabolism by a newly-defined ATR-mTORC1 axis and evaluate inhibition of this signaling pathway in p16-low melanomas alone or in combination with current standard-of-care treatment. The results will have a direct impact on the development of novel therapeutic strategies to obtain a therapeutic response in melanoma patients with low p16 expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Osteoarthritis (OA), a common joint disease, associated with cartilage damages and affecting millions of American every year, currently has no effective cure. While regenerative engineering methods have shown some encouraging results to enhance cartilage healing for the treatment of OA, the use of potentially toxic growth factors in such approaches has limited their application. Here, we propose a new regenerative engineering strategy of employing a biodegradable piezoelectric nanocomposite cartilage-graft and study an optimal exercise to obtain a novel piezoelectric stimulation which can promote healing of cartilages and treat OA in large animals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Relevance to Public Health: The proposed research project is focused on the “sodium pump”, an enzyme that transports sodium and potassium across cell membranes. This is a critical function in all cells, and it is carefully regulated by interactions with small proteins that increase or decrease the activity of the pump. By studying how the pump is controlled, we may find new ways to improve its function when it is disrupted in diseases including heart disease, schizophrenia, Parkinson’s disease, and Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Mucous metaplasia is commonly seen in acute respiratory illnesses, and is also a characteristic feature of chronic lung diseases including fibrosis, COPD and asthma. Here, we use a combination of mouse models, organoid culture and single-cell analysis to address how abnormal VEGF/KDR signaling contributes to mucous metaplasia. The proposal will provide novel insights into fundamental mechanisms with broad scientific and clinical implications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Life-threatening fungal infections are an escalating problem due, in part, to increasing numbers of immune- compromised individuals and the evolution of drug resistance. Few treatment options exist to combat systemic infections caused by drug resistant pathogens and there is a dire need for new molecular targets to spur novel antifungal drug development. Recent evidence suggests the Cdc14 phosphatase family is an attractive antifungal target and this project will characterize the mechanisms by which Cdc14 regulates virulence-related processes like cell wall integrity, echinocandin drug sensitivity, and hyphal development in the prominent human pathogen Candida albicans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative A precise understanding of RAS’ interaction with membranes and trafficking is essential to understand RAS action and to intervene in RAS-driven leukemias. This work uncovers RAB27B GTPase that is crucial to oncogenic NRAS lipid modification, trafficking, signaling and cell growth. It serves the basis for future therapeutic strategies for molecular targeting of various myeloid malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Myeloproliferative Neoplasms (MPN), namely polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia and myelofibrosis (MF) are chronic hematologic diseases that arise from a malignant hematopoietic clone and have the potential to progress to more overt phases of MF and MPN-blast phase, which both have limited treatment options and portend a poor prognosis. A subset of MPN patients have an activating mutation and/or overexpression of PPM1D, a serine-threonine phosphatase, which has been implicated in promoting clonal stem cell fitness. This proposal through a multipronged approach utilizing mouse models, patient-derived induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC) lines and primary specimens from MPN patients will elucidate the role of PPM1D in MPNs and investigate its potential as therapeutic target using a novel PPM1D degrader.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Individuals born with malformations in the brain's cerebral cortex suffer from a number of disease phenotypes ranging from mild speech problems to severely debilitating diseases, such as cerebral palsy and uncontrollable epilepsy. Our research goal is to identity new gene mutations that are responsible for causing these malformation diseases, as well as to study the basic blueprints for building a normal cerebral cortex. Further, we will also explore the mechanisms behind a novel cortical malformation disease rooted in ion channel dysfunction, termed “developmental channelopathy”.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our overall goal is to develop non-invasive brain stimulation/recording techniques for the human brain that can selectively up- or downregulate a specific connection between two brain areas as well as record the conduction delay and connectivity strength between them. This is useful, because many brain-related disorders reflect net- work-level changes where the connectivity strengths between specific areas have been pathologically reduced or increased. The techniques will be applicable to clinical and research applications in a wide spectrum of neu- rological and psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and AD-related dementia (ADRD) are increasingly affecting older adults and has no cure. Aerobic exercise has been shown to be a promising treatment in AD/ADRD. but results from previous studies have shown inconsistent cognitive effects due to individual differences and large variations in exercise responses. This trial is the first in AD/ADRD to examine the effect of alternative exercise programs to elicit the best responses in each individual.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a chronic, debilitating condition that disproportionately affects Veterans. Prolonged Exposure (PE) therapy is a “gold standard” treatment for PTSD. However, approximately one-third of Veterans fail to receive an adequate dose of treatment because they prematurely drop out of PE therapy. There is also room to improve PE treatment outcomes. Consistent with the VA Office of Research and Development initiative to develop effective treatments for PTSD, the proposed randomized clinical trial will examine the ability of oxytocin (as compared with placebo) combined with PE to reduce PTSD symptom severity, improve the rate of PTSD symptom reduction, and to enhance PE treatment retention and adherence. This two-site study will leverage the investments made in the nationwide rollout off PE therapy and has the potential to significantly improve mental health care among Veterans, advance the science in this area, and identify mechanisms underlying positive PTSD treatment response.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PTSD is common among Veterans with serious mental illness (SMI). Co-occurring PTSD and SMI lead to poorer mental health and physical functioning than either diagnosis alone and is a critical obstacle to rehabilitation and recovery. Despite known high prevalence rates of PTSD in SMI populations as well as disparities in prevalence and treatment use for Black, Indigenous, and other people of color (BIPOC), little research has been done to: a) evaluate leading treatments for PTSD in individuals with SMI, and b) develop culturally responsive methods to integrate with PTSD treatments for SMI Veterans. This study aims to address research and clinical gaps by: a) testing the feasibility and acceptability of Written Exposure Therapy (WET), a VA evidence-based psychotherapy for PTSD in Veterans with SMI, and b) incorporating culturally responsive assessment methods. Results from this study will inform whether WET and culturally responsive assessment are feasible to implement, acceptable to Veterans with SMI, and worth examining in standard or optimized form in a larger clinical trial.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The placenta has a complex vascular structure that balances maternal supply of oxygen and nutrients to fetal demand. The objective of this proposal is to implement and validate a multi-modal magnetic resonance imaging approach to comprehensively study maternal and fetal-side placental perfusion characteristics in a translational animal model. This will enable the development of tools to identify pregnancies at-risk of placental insufficiency and facilitate future clinical diagnostic and management strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Malaria remains one of the deadliest diseases in the world today and accounts for over 200 million clinical cases worldwide each year along with roughly half a million deaths, mostly children under the age of five and pregnant women. With increasing drug resistance and the absence of a clinically available vaccine, there is an urgent need and continuous search for novel, affordable, and safe drugs for prevention and treatment of malaria. We have developed a novel antimalarial acridone chemotype that is potent against both blood stage and liver stage malaria parasites, with single-dose cure ability and potential to prevent relapsing infection, that warrant further preclinical development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims at elucidating the molecular mechanisms of astrocyte-based neuromodulation, and the causal role of this form of signaling in cognitive functions and in the behavioral effects of cognitive enhancers. Success in this research program will identify new operating principles that govern input-output fidelity in astrocytes, which will be applicable to many pathways. In addition, defining a tractable relationship between astrocyte signaling and cognitive behavior, and its activation by clinically tested therapeutics, will establish a new benchmarks for considering astrocyte biology in the treatment of cognitive disabilities and mental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Loss of function mutations in MeCP2 cause Rett syndrome (RTT), a leading monogenetic neurodevelopmental disorder with a hallmark of progressive loss of acquired motor and cognitive skills. Recent work in our lab has found that Mecp2-null mice are still capable of developing motor skills, and that this motor learning benefits the mice in other domains. This proposal will deepen our understanding of motor cortical function at the circuit level in both mutant and wild-type animals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: CHILDREN'S HOSPITAL MED CTR OF AKRON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to the public health because therapeutic advances have changed acute illnesses with high child mortality into chronic diseases that children, adolescents, and young adults may live with well into their fourth decade. There is a significant need to define quality domains inclusive of all stakeholders’ perspectives on symptom management and quality of life, to further future practice guideline development, health outcome and quality improvement studies helping children and adolescents live well with significant conditions. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to multiple parts of NIH’s mission, particularly through NINR, that pertain to i) enabling rapid translation of needs and best practices for the integration of palliative care into home and community settings; ii) addressing social and environmental factors affecting end-of-life and palliative care; and iii) considering the environment and unique needs of each patient to facilitate high-quality end-of-life and palliative care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Physical inactivity is prevalent, costly, and deadly, particularly among individuals with cardiometabolic conditions. While mind-body exercise interventions (e.g., yoga, tai chi), which include several therapeutic components (e.g., physical exercise, mindful attention), are promising for improving physical activity levels, it is difficult to optimize these interventions for physical activity promotion without understanding the effects of these core components on health behavior change processes. Using metabolic syndrome as a model, this project will assess the feasibility and acceptability of a factorial design that examines the effects of two mind-body exercise components, exercise and mindful attention, on key health behavior change processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breast cancer is the most frequently diagnosed women’s cancer (271,270 estimated new cases diagnosed in 2019) and even in the wake of novel treatment regimens and revised screening criteria, it remains a leading cause of cancer death among women, predominately due to malignant transformation and treatment resistance. Analyzing patient blood samples for genomic disturbances, such as gene fusion products involving the estrogen receptor, would be both more efficient and accessible for patients at risk of metastases and for monitoring development of treatment resistance in those already diagnosed with late-stage breast cancer. The proposed study will utilize molecular techniques, breast cancer models, including a patient derived xenograft, and clinical samples to examine the functionality, structure-function relationship and prevalence of gene fusions as well as analyze the feasibility of extracting gene fusion products from liquid biopsy isolated exosomal RNA that could ultimately lead to improved diagnosis, outcomes and treatment guidance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to continue the development and implementation of a training program designed to encourage and enable undergraduate students from under-represented and disadvantaged backgrounds to pursue biomedical research careers in areas related to heart, lung or blood pathophysiology. Our program was developed on the premise that the principal barrier to diversity in science is not a lack of talent, but rather a lack of opportunity. Thus, our program was built around an intensive research experience with an individual mentor, complemented by activities important to building communication and networking skills, such as making presentations in journal club and at a closing poster session, as well as seminars and workshops that address issues relevant to career-building in biomedical sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Taste loss contributes to malnutrition, depression, and reduced quality of life in affected patients. In this project, we will investigate the role of inflammation in taste loss using both a transgenic approach and a respiratory viral infection model. Our goal is to characterize the relationship between inflammation, taste loss, and taste bud regeneration to provide mechanistic insights for future therapies aimed at correcting or preventing immune-related taste dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Antibacterial resistance is an urgent public health threat, particularly in hospital-acquired infections from bacteria like Pseudomonas aeruginosa where few treatment options exist. Cationic antimicrobial peptides (CAPs) are currently used as last resort treatments for infections with multidrug-resistant P. aeruginosa, but CAP- resistant strains have been encountered. The proposed research aims to develop and characterize small molecule inhibitors that block the CAP-resistance pathway for use as a combination therapy with a CAP to clear infections with CAP-resistant P. aeruginosa.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative  This project will conduct the 2021 wave of the Child Development Supplement (CDS) to the Panel Study of Income Dynamics (PSID). CDS-21 will collect follow-up interviews of children's primary caregivers (typically mothers) and of older children (ages 12–17 years in 2021) who participated in the 2019 wave of CDS. This new wave of CDS in 2021 will, in conjunction with data from earlier CDS waves, provide unique and valuable prospective panel data to study the effects of the Covid-19 pandemic, lockdown, and recession on children's health, family circumstances, schooling, development, and well-being.

ORG_NAME: ROSALIND FRANKLIN UNIV OF MEDICINE & SCI
PHR: Bacterial infections simultaneously activate several innate immune responses with beneficial but also deleterious effects on the host. The present grant proposal aims at clarifying beneficial and deleterious responses triggered by caspase-11 in epithelial or endothelial cells focusing on their role in eicosanoid synthesis and coagulation. Our studies will potentially facilitate development of therapeutic interventions to encourage the protective responses and inhibit the deleterious ones.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Variants in genes encoding multiple subunits of the BAF chromatin remodeling complex are a cause of genetic neurodevelopmental disorders. The BAF complex has been shown to interact with Fos, a major activity- dependent transcription factor known to be important in neurodevelopmental processes, but how Fos and the BAF complex regulate neuronal activity-dependent genetic programs remains unclear. This project will study the role of Fos and the BAF complex in regulating activity-dependent processes and how these are perturbed in a model of BAF-related neurodevelopmental disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE HIV-infected, antiretroviral-treated women are more likely to have adverse birth outcomes, and their infants have altered immunity even in the absence of HIV-infection. Here, we will investigate the impact of maternal vaginal microbiome and metabolites during pregnancy and immune regulation and inflammation in placentas at delivery on preterm birth risk in HIV-infected women. We will utilize a long-standing cohort study population in Cape Town South Africa to determine which immune events at the fetal-maternal interface contribute to spontaneous preterm birth in HIV infection, and whether these relate to impaired newborn immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer is the second leading cause of mortality worldwide, with an estimated 9.6 million cancer- related deaths worldwide in 2018 (source – the World Health Organization). One of the major hurdles in treatment of cancer is the cancer cell’s ability to survive under adverse conditions and acquisition of drug resistance. Our proposal aims to study the mechanism(s) by which cancer cells successfully adapt to stress and maintain viability. The successful completion of our studies may provide new targets for therapeutic intervention in cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many identified psychotic disorder risk-related genomic variants are eQTLs located in noncoding DNA. It is likely that noncoding risk eQTLs associated with synaptic genes represent disrupted genomic enhancers that are typically active during synaptic organization. This proposal will test enhancer activity across development of synaptic gene eQTLs associated with psychotic risk and test allelic and cell-type differences of enhancers in the high-priority psychiatric risk gene CACNA1C.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hispanic young adults, including college students, have been the targets of tobacco marketing and this trend continues with the marketing of ENDS products on social media. Yet, we know little about the role of ENDS- related social media on the use of ENDS products by Mexican American college students, the largest subgroup of Hispanics. The proposed project will fill a void by examining the associations between ENDS- related social media exposure and engagement, and ENDS use among Mexican American college students, as well as the factors that explain and those that modify these associations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will define how interferon-gamma, a major T-cell cytokine abundant in atherosclerotic plaques, alters fuel utilization by the vascular cells that line the innermost layer of the coronary arteries, thereby making these vessels susceptible to atherosclerosis progression. This study, if successful, will improve our understanding of the adverse changes involving vascular metabolism in atherosclerosis and may lead to new therapeutic strategies to prevent heart attacks, strokes, and limb loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The immune system is adept at clearing bacterial infection, however, certain bacteria can pose a difficult challenge that stimulates the immune response to form a structure called a granuloma. This structure is seen in important infections such as tuberculosis, however, granuloma functions have been difficult to study due to a lack of model systems. We have discovered a new granuloma model that allows us to study basic granuloma biology in laboratory mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative: In older adults, emergency department (ED) return visits resulting in a hospital admission (RVA) have dramatically higher morbidity and mortality than patients admitted on their initial ED visit. We propose to develop an automated ED screening tool to identify older adults at risk of RVA within 72 hours following an initial ED visit, using machine learning to accurately predict this multifactorial event. Findings from this research will improve the ability of ED clinicians to identify this vulnerable population for subsequent risk-mitigating interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Dense desmoplastic stroma is a fundamental characteristic of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) and comprises up to 80% of the tumor mass. While the strategy to deplete PDAC stroma has failed in clinical trials, normalization of the stroma to allow chemotherapy to kill the tumor cells in the “nest” could be a promising strategy for PDAC therapy. In this proposal, we will evaluate how the PCBP2 siRNA enhances the anti-tumor activity of chemotherapy and immunotherapy for PDAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Improved Nanoparticle Targeting of Tissue Myeloid Cells for HIV-1 Long-acting Pre-exposure Prophylaxis Relevance to Public Health The female genital tract and rectum are primary tissue sites of HIV transmission. This project develops nanoparticle-based strategies to achieve long-acting antiretroviral pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) against mucosal HIV transmission in the female genital tract and rectum of a humanized mouse model. The proposed work provides the basis for future long-acting PrEP in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative The human genome contains approximately 20,000 genes; in order to function properly, individual cells in the human body must precisely regulate the rate at which they use each of these genes through processes called transcriptional regulation. Segments of non-coding DNA outside of genes called regulatory elements mediate these processes, and differences in DNA sequence within regulatory elements can predispose individuals to developing particular traits or diseases. This project aims to build a comprehensive resource of regulatory elements in the human genome, including deep-learning models of their regulatory syntax, which will help researchers to understand how these regulatory elements function and to better design follow-up research to understand and treat disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Insufficient sleep and circadian dysregulation cause, promote and exacerbate major medical health problems such as cardiovascular disease, obesity, diabetes, depression and respiratory disorders. The number of investigators being trained in transdisciplinary sleep and circadian research cannot keep pace with the accelerating health-care problems associated with insufficient sleep and circadian dysregulation. This training program will increase the number of researchers in the pipeline and facilitate the development of the next generation of scientific leaders; and thereby, this training program will ultimately contribute to knowledge of integrative physiological mechanisms and the treatment of disease that will advance the health and well-being of the public.
PROJECT_TERMS: Circadian Rhythms;Sleep;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Transdisciplinary Training in Sleep and Circadian Rhythms
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: NHLBI Institutional Training Mechanism Study Section[NITM(OA)]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative: The incidence of WHO Grade II, diffuse lower grade gliomas (LGG) is about 15% of all gliomas; the assessment of disease aggressiveness is a long-standing challenge for treatment decision-making and surveillance strategies in WHO Grade II gliomas because of the tremendous variability in the course of the disease. It is thus essential to develop integrative decision models that leverage existing clinical and genomic measurements along with novel, diagnostic imaging-derived predictors to empower the physicians to assess disease course and effectively manage patients: for instance, highly aggressive LGGs are often candidates for aggressive surgical resection, which requires an accurate assessment of LGG aggressiveness. Such tools will also enable the patients and their caregivers to understand their individual disease, and enable them to collaborate more effectively with their oncologist to design appropriately tailored treatment strategies.
